Description: ENGAGE YOUTH THROUGH EMPLOYMENT AND STORYTELLING 15.931: YOUTH AND VETERAN ORGANIZATIONS CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES THIS PROGRAM UTILIZES QUALIFIED NON-PROFIT YOUTH- AND VETERAN-SERVING ORGANIZATIONS TO CARRY OUT APPROPRIATE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION, EDUCATION, VOLUNTEER SERVICE AND EDUCATION PROJECTS ON DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR LANDS THROUGH AUTHORIZED NATIONAL PARK SERVICE PROGRAMS. C O CANAL NHP WILL ENGAGE YOUTH INTERNS, RECRUITED BY THE CONSERVATION LEGACY TO EXPAND YOUTH COMMUNITY OUTREACH. TO CONNECT WITH YOUTH, THE INTERNS WILL ENHANCE THE C O CANAL NHP IN-PERSON AND DIGITAL INTERPRETATION. THE YOUTH INTERNS WILL BE MENTORED BY INTERPRETATION STAFF.  YOUTH INTERNS WILL CONDUCT RESEARCH INTO THE MAIN PARK STORY AND UNDERTOLD STORIES. THEY WILL PLAN AND PREPARE PROGRAMS FOR A MAJOR INTERPRETIVE PROGRAM. THEY WILL PRESENT THE INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS DIGITALLY AND ON THE PARKS BOATS. THE YOUTH INTERNS WILL LEARN THE MISSION AND OPERATIONS OF THE NPS  THE PARK WILL DIVERSIFY ITS WORK FORCE  THE YOUTH INTERNS WILL DEVELOP INTERPRETATION SKILLS  VISITORS WILL BE ABLE TO PARTICIPATE IN THE BOAT PROGRAMS AT MANY LOCATIONS ALONG THE C O CANAL. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, CONSERVATION LEGACY, YOUTH INTERNS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL RECEIVE A BENEFIT FROM THE DEVELOPMENT AND EXECUTION OF THESE PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A THOROUGH INVENTORY OF MARYLAND STATE RARE PLANTS IN THE PISCATAWAY (PISC) UNIT OF NATIONAL CAPITAL PARKS  EAST.  THE PROJECT WILL BUILD ON PREVIOUS INVENTORIES AND MARYLAND NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM DATA.  THERE HAS BEEN NO INVENTORY SINCE 2011, SO A RE-INVENTORY IS NEEDED AS LANDSCAPE FACTORS SUCH AS CLIMATE AND INVASIVE SPECIES. ALSO, LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES HAVE CHANGED THE LOCAL ECOSYSTEM IN WHICH STATE RARE PLANTS ARE FOUND.  THIS IS AN EXCELLENT DEMONSTRATION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR SECRETARYS PRIORITY TO CONSERVE AT LEAST 30  EACH OF OUR LANDS AND WATERS BY THE YEAR 2030, PROTECT BIODIVERSITY AND SLOW EXTINCTION RATES. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).
HABITAT-FOCUSED RESTORATION OF NATIVE MUSSELS IN TWO OZARK RIVERINE PARKS

ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT OF CONGAREE NATIONAL PARK  THE ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT IS A RESEARCH STUDY THAT WILL BE CONDUCTED TO PROVIDE BASELINE DATA ON TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED GROUPS, THE PARK RESOURCES WITH WHICH THEY ARE ASSOCIATED, AND DESCRIPTION OF THE TRADITIONAL USES OF AND ASSOCIATIONS WITH THESE RESOURCES, HISTORICALLY AND CURRENTLY. PROJECT WORK CONSISTS OF THREE PHASES THAT INCLUDE A REVIEW AND SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING HISTORIC AND ETHNOGRAPHIC INFORMATION RELATED TO ASSOCIATIONS TO THE PARKS  FIELDWORK, INTERVIEWS, CONSULTATION, AND REPORT PREPARATION  AND THE RESULTS OF INTERVIEWS AND ANY OTHER ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTED DURING THIS PERIOD. THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHOSE CULTURAL HERITAGE AND IDENTITY WAS IS TIED TO THESE LANDS AND RESOURCES WILL BENEFIT BY RECONNECTING THEM TO THE PLACES FROM WHICH THEY HAVE BEEN REMOVED. UNIVERSITY STAFF AND STUDENTS WILL GAIN HANDS-ON SKILLS AND ADVANCE KNOWLEDGE ON THESE TOPICS. INFORMATION GLEANED FROM THIS RESEARCH WILL ALSO SERVE AS AN EDUCATIONAL BENEFIT OF THE PUBLIC.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION THAT INVOLVES CULTURAL SCIENCES NEEDED TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES. THE RECIPIENT WILL DEVELOP A UNIFIED VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK FOR CULTURAL RESOURCES IN THE NPS INTERMOUNTAIN REGION (IMR), AND UPDATE AND REFINE AN EXISTING CULTURAL RESOURCES VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT WEB APPLICATION DESIGNED FOR CULTURAL RESOURCE SYSTEMS IN IMR. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE PROJECT WILL BRING TOGETHER CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS FROM FOUR NPS MISSION PARKS INCLUDING TUMACACORI NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (TUMA), SALINAS PUEBLO MISSIONS NATIONAL MONUMENT (SAPU), SAN ANTONIO MISSIONS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (SAAN), AND PECOS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (PECO), AND UNIVERSITY PARTNERS SUCH AS UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA (UPENN), UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS AT SAN ANTONIO (UTSA), UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO (UNM), AND UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT (UVM) TO DEVELOP A BASELINE METHODOLOGY AND PROCESS FOR ASSESSING VULNERABILITY OF THESE MULTI-COMPONENT MISSION SITES (INCLUSIVE OF ARCHITECTURAL ELEMENTS, ARCHEOLOGICAL FEATURES AND CULTURAL LANDSCAPE COMPONENTS). THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONDUCT TWO WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP A BASELINE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT METHODOLOGY THAT CAN BE APPLIED BROADLY AT THESE MISSION SITES, AND REVIEW VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OUTCOMES FROM EACH MISSION SITE FROM FIELDWORK DONE BY UNIVERSITY PARTNERS. A FINAL COMPLETION REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED BY THE PIS TO THE PARK UNIT LEAD, DESERT SOUTHWEST COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNIT (DS-CESU), AND VT PROGRAM COORDINATOR. AS THIS PROJECT WILL BE DONE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE DS-CESU, SUBMISSION OF THE FINAL COMPLETION REPORT WILL COINCIDE WITH THE SUBMISSION OF THE FINAL PERFORMANCE REPORT ON, OR BEFORE, 90 DAYS FOLLOWING THE TERMINATION OF THE PROJECT AND WILL BE ENTERED INTO PMIS.THIS AGREEMENT FULFILLS A PUBLIC PURPOSE OF ENGAGING RECIPIENT, PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES, AND VISITOR IN SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, AND PROMOTING GREATER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN HISTORY PRESERVATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES. THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO THE NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH THE RESEARCH AND RELATED DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION. INFORMATION IDENTIFIED AND DEVELOPED BY WAY OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND SUPPORT FOR THE PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATIONS CULTURAL, HISTORIC, AND NATURAL RESOURCES.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION THAT INVOLVES CULTURAL SCIENCES NEEDED TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES. THE RECIPIENT WILL COMPLETE AN ARCHITECTURAL VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OF SELECTED STRUCTURES WITHIN TUMACCORI NATIONAL HISTORIC PARK (TUMA). TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE RECIPIENT WILL USE PAST, PRESENT, AND FUTURE CLIMATE DATA TO IDENTIFY CHANGING PATTERNS AND TRENDS OF WEATHERING AND SPECIFICALLY DETERIORATION AND TO INFORM REVISED SITE PRESERVATION METHODS IN RESPONSE TO THESE CHANGES. THE END RESULT OF THIS RESPONSE PHASE IS TO DEVELOP A PRESERVATION APPROACH THAT TAKES INTO ACCOUNT NEW MATERIAL MIXES (SOILS, AMENDMENTS), APPLICATION TECHNIQUES (SHELTER COATS, GROUTING), AS WELL AS SEASONAL TIMING OF APPLICATIONS TO BETTER WITHSTAND INCREASING CLIMATE-RELATED IMPACT TO THE UNITS. TRIBAL CONSULTANTS WILL BE INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT WITH DESCENDENT COMMUNITIES, CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR TRIBAL YOUTH AND OTHERS RESPONSIBLE FOR CULTURAL PRESERVATION TO BUILD RESILIENCY TO CLIMATE IMPACTS. UNDERSTANDING TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE FROM THE TRIBES PERSPECTIVE WILL HELP BUILD BETTER ALTERNATIVES TO PRESERVATION MATERIALS, APPLICATIONS, AND PRESERVATION WORKFORCE.THIS AGREEMENT FULFILLS THE PUBLIC PURPOSE OF ENGAGING THE RECIPIENT, PARTNERS, COMMUNITY, AND VISITORS IN SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMERGING PROFESSIONALS IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION TO FURTHER DEVELOP SKILLS IN, AND KNOWLEDGE OF, HISTORIC PRESERVATION THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN PRESERVATION TRAINING COURSES. PARTICIPANTS WILL APPLY CLASSROOM KNOWLEDGE OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION CONCEPTS IN A REAL-WORLD ENVIRONMENT AND WORK ALONGSIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTS TO ENHANCE PRESERVATION SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE. PARTICIPANTS WILL BE ENGAGED WITH A VARIETY OF SKILLED PRESERVATION PRACTITIONERS IN THE NPS AND ELSEWHERE, THEREBY BROADENING THEIR PROFESSIONAL NETWORK. PARTICIPANTS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT THE VARIETY OF PRESERVATION NEEDS OF AN EXEMPLARY COLLECTION OF HERITAGE RESOURCES WITHIN NPS UNITS IN THE WEST, AND COMPLETE SPECIAL PROJECTS FOCUSED ON THEIR PARTICULAR INTEREST AREAS WITHIN THE FIELD OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION. THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO THE NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH RESEARCH AND THE DISSEMINATION OF RESEARCH RELATED RESULTS.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE PROJECT IS A CO-LEARNING EXCHANGE BETWEEN THE ARGENTINE REPUBLIC (ARGENTINA) AND THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA (USA) THAT WILL DEVELOP MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL WAYS TO DELIVER HIGH-QUALITY VISITOR EXPERIENCES INFORMED BY THE EXPERIENCE OF THE US NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AS REPRESENTED IN THE US FEDERAL INTERAGENCY VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SOFTWARE, FIELD WORK TO COLLECT DATA, POST-PROCESSING, REPORT GENERATION, AND TRAINING. NEW AWARD - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: PROJECT TITLE: CESU-ASSESSMENT OF BISCAYNE NATIONAL PARK SUBMERGED AQUATIC VEGETATION SEAGRASS HEALTH TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION PRIORITIES.AWARD PURPOSE: THIS WILL INVOLVE SYNTHESIZING INFORMATION FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES TO ASSESS BISCAYNE NATIONAL PARK S SEAGRASS ECOSYSTEM HEALTH IN CONTEXT WITH THE LARGER LANDSCAPE WATERSHED THAT SURROUNDS THE PARK.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR AND A GRADUATE STUDENT WILL IDENTIFY RELEVANT DATA SOURCES THROUGH A LITERATURE SEARCH AND SURVEYS OF AGENCY DATA SOURCES.  DELIVERABLES AND OR EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE RESULTING INFORMATION WILL BE SYNTHESIZED IN A TECHNICAL REPORT INCLUDING GEOSPATIAL DATA ADDRESSING SEAGRASS HEALTH STATUS AND TRENDS IN THE PARK, A SOURCE LIST OF EXISTING DATA ON SEAGRASS RESOURCES IN THE PARK, A SUMMARY OF TOPICAL AND GEOSPATIAL GAPS IN EXISTING DATA, RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONSERVATION AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE PARKS SEAGRASS RESOURCES, AND PUBLIC MESSAGING RECOMMENDATIONS ON SEAGRASS HEALTH IN THE PARK AND PRACTICES TO PROTECT AND IMPROVE SEAGRASS HEALTH FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO CHARACTERIZE THE CURRENT CONDITION OF THE VARIOUS ASPECTS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITIES WITHIN FORESTED SYSTEMS AND TO IDENTIFY WHICH FACTORS STRESSORS ARE AFFECTING THESE CONDITIONS. NETN, MIDN, AND NCBN ARE ESPECIALLY INTERESTED IN ANALYSES THAT EVALUATE HOW THE CONDITIONS WITHIN THESE ECOSYSTEMS ARE CHANGING IN RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE, DEER BROWSE, AND THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE SPECIES AT BOTH LOCAL AND REGIONAL SCALES.THE OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK WILL INCREASE THE PUBLIC AND SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITYS KNOWLEDGE OF HOW A VARIETY OF LOCAL AND REGIONAL STRESSORS AFFECTS THE CONDITION OF FORESTED AND WETLAND COMMUNITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP ETHICS IN ITS PARTICIPANTS INCLUDING THE GREATER PUBLIC.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.  THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.  THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF A LONG-TERM VEGETATION AND FOREST HEALTH MONITORING PROGRAM AT FLIGHT 93 NATIONAL MEMORIAL. DATA WILL CHARACTERIZE AND DESCRIBE THE CONDITION AND HEALTH OF THE FOREST UNDERSTORY, MID-STORY, AND CANOPY IN TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING. THE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF SIX MONITORING PLOTS, FULLY COMPLETED DATASHEETS, AND A POPULATED, ERROR FREE, DATABASE CONTAINING PROJECT DATA. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE PUBLIC.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATECOOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OFTHE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATIONPRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. IN COOPERATION WITH UNIVERSITY OF WYOMINGS INSTITUTE FOR MANAGING ANNUAL GRASSES INVADING NATURAL ECOSYSTEMS (IMAGINE) AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS), THIS PROJECT WILL SEEK TO OPERATIONALIZE THE DEFEND THE CORE, GROW THE CORE PHILOSOPHY OUTLINED IN THE SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION DESIGN AND SAGEBRUSH KEYSTONE INITIATIVE. PART OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT WILL ENHANCE CONSERVATION EFFORTS BY APPLYING ACTIONABLE SCIENCE TO ASSIST LAND MANAGERS IN PARKS IN PRIORITIZING SPATIAL OPPORTUNITIES AND WHICH PRACTICES TECHNIQUES WOULD BE MOST BENEFICIAL TO PREVENT AND MANAGE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES. IMAGINE ALSO INTENDS TO EXPAND THEIR COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE TO HELP LAND MANAGERS AND PRACTITIONERS FEEL EMPOWERED TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN MANAGING INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZE INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS AS WILL PROVIDE FULL GEOGRAPHIC AND TOPICAL COVERAGE FOR RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE RESOURCES CONTAINED IN UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR LARGER REGIONS.THIS PROJECT AIMS TO SUPPORT VISITOR USE RELATED DATA COLLECTION AT ZION NATIONAL PARK (ZION). UNDERSTANDING BASELINE CONDITIONS OF VISITOR USE AS WELL AS TRENDS INFORMS CRITICAL PARK MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING. THE GOAL OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO DEVELOP A COLLABORATIVE WORKING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE PARKDATA RESEARCH TEAM TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN CREATING AND IMPLEMENTING VISITOR MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES, TO HELP SUPPORT VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING AT ZION NATIONAL PARK. THIS WORK AIMS TO FIND INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS TO DATA RELATED NEEDS AND TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH HANDS ON LEARNING EXPERIENCES THAT SPAN IDEA DEVELOPMENT TO FIELD IMPLEMENTATION. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS (PROJECT ABSTRACTS), OR CONTACT THE NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY OFFICE AT FINANCIAL ASSITANCE POLICY NPS.GOV.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE WALL STREET MILL, IN THE NORTH PION MINING HISTORIC DISTRICT, CONSISTS PRIMARILY OF A TIMBER FRAME STRUCTURE HOUSING A TWO-STAMP MILL  THE MILL SERVED AS AN IMPORTANT REGIONAL HUB FOR MILLING OPERATIONS IN THE NORTHERN PION MINING DISTRICT FROM 1931 UNTIL 1942, IS LISTED ON THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES, AND IS ONE OF THE MOST VISITED HISTORIC SITES IN THE PARK. THE CONDITION OF INDIVIDUAL ELEMENTS OF THE TIMBER FRAME RANGE FROM POOR TO FAIR, AND REQUIRE ASSESSMENT, DEVELOPMENT OF A PRESERVATION PLAN, AND PILOT TREATMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED IN TWO STAGES. IN STAGE 1, THE DEPARTMENT OF CIVIL   ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT (UVM) WILL CONDUCT AN ASSESSMENT OF THE STAMP MILL AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ITS PRESERVATION. IN STAGE 2, PRESERVATION TREATMENT OF THE MILL WILL BE ADDRESSED USING A FIELD SCHOOL FORMAT TO TRAIN FIELD SCHOOL PARTICIPANTS IN THE ASSESSMENT AND TREATMENT TECHNIQUES APPROPRIATE TO THIS EARLY-20TH CENTURY STRUCTURE. UVM STUDENTS, NPS STAFF, AND PRACTICING PROFESSIONALS WILL BE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN ALL PORTIONS OF THE WORK  THE PARKS DIGITAL MEDIA TEAM WILL DOCUMENT ASSESSMENT AND TREATMENT PHASES, AND CREATE A SERIES OF SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND NPS WEBSITE CONTENT THAT WILL DISSEMINATE BOTH THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION PHILOSOPHIES TO THE PUBLIC. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATIONPRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. NEW AWARD - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY: PROJECT TITLE: CESU  ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT OF CHRISTIANSTED NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE, BUCK ISLAND REEF NATIONAL MONUMENT, AND SALT RIVER BAY NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARKAWARD PURPOSE: THE ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT WILL BE CONDUCTED TO PROVIDE BASELINE DATA ON TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED GROUPS, THE PARK RESOURCES WITH WHICH THEY ARE ASSOCIATED, AND DESCRIPTION OF THE TRADITIONAL USES OF AND ASSOCIATIONS WITH THESE RESOURCES, HISTORICALLY AND CURRENTLY. IN ORDER TO MANAGE CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES IN AN EFFECTIVE, CULTURALLY INFORMED MANNER, THE NPS REQUIRES THE DOCUMENTATION AND ANALYSIS OF ETHNOGRAPHIC INFORMATION REGARDING PEOPLE WITH TRADITIONAL AND OR HISTORIC TIES TO SPECIFIC PARK AREAS.ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO PRODUCE A FINAL PRODUCT WHICH INTEGRATES ETHNOGRAPHIC, HISTORICAL, ARCHAEOLOGICAL FINDINGS, AND VISUAL ILLUSTRATIONS WITH COLLABORATIVELY-DERIVED TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE, ORAL AND WRITTEN HISTORY, ORAL TRADITIONS, AND RELEVANT CONTEMPORARY AND TRADITIONAL ARTS OF ASSOCIATED PEOPLES, WHICH CAN BE USED TO ENHANCE NOT ONLY PARK RECORDS, BUT ALSO GREATLY ENRICH THE AVAILABLE POOL OF RESOURCES FOR FUTURE USE IN INTERPRETATIONS AT THE SITES.DELIVERABLES AND OR EXPECTED OUTCOMES: DELIVERABLES, INCLUDING PAPER DRAFTS, DIGITAL MEDIA, AND THE FINAL REPORT.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATECOOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OFTHE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATIONPRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS THE EXTENT OF PHARMACEUTICAL EXPOSURE ACROSS MULTIPLE NATIONAL PARKS THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES. THE RECIPIENT WILL COLLECT AND ANALYZE SAMPLES FOR 95 COMMONLY-PRESCRIBED PHARMACEUTICALS IN TEN OCEAN AND GREAT LAKES NATIONAL PARKS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES TO ASSESS THE SCOPE OF PHARMACEUTICAL EXPOSURE. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO BEGIN TO PROVIDE QUANTITATIVE AND LONG-TERM DATA TO WHAT SPECIES AND STOCK WILL DO BEST IN A CHANGING CLIMATE AND WITH THE PRESSURE OF INVASIVE SPECIES, A LONG-TERM EXPERIMENT WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE FLOODPLAIN FORESTS OF THE UPPER MISSISSIPPI RIVER AS PART OF THE ADAPTATIVE SILVICULTURE FOR CLIMATE CHANGE (ASCC) NETWORK. THE SITE IS LOCATED AT CROSBY FARM REGIONAL PARK WHICH IS PART OF THE BROADER MISSISSIPPI NATIONAL RIVER AND RECREATION AREA (MNRRA) IN MINNESOTA. THE RESEARCH SITE WAS ESTABLISHED IN THE SPRING OF 2020 AND INCLUDES 18 DIFFERENT SPECIES AND SEED ZONE TYPES. INITIAL SURVIVAL (1- AND 2 YEAR) OF MANY OF THE SPECIES IS PROMISING. HOWEVER, IN A DYNAMIC ECOSYSTEM LIKE THE FLOODPLAINS, LONGER TERM RESULTS ARE NEEDED SO MANAGERS CAN BE MORE CONFIDENT ABOUT SPECIES AND SEED ZONE TYPES AS THEY PLAN RESTORATION EFFORTS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO ASSESS THE RESEARCH RESULTS, COLLECTING THE END OF THE 4TH, 5TH, AND 6TH GROWING SEASONS FOR THIS PROJECT, AND PROVIDE NOVEL, QUANTITATIVE INFORMATION WITH ACTIONABLE INFORMATION TO FLOODPLAIN AND WET FOREST MANAGERS ACROSS THE REGION. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE SKIDOO MILL, IN DEATH VALLEY NATIONAL PARK, IS A MASSIVE GOLD PROCESSING MILL THAT CASCADES, LEVEL BY LEVEL, DOWN THE SIDE OF A CANYON, DESIGNED TO USE GRAVITY TO MOVE ORE FROM ONE MILLING PROCESS TO THE NEXT. WHILE MUCH OF THE MILL REMAINS INTACT, THE STRUCTURE HAS LOST MOST OF ITS EXTERIOR SHEATHING, EXPOSING THE HEAVY TIMBER FRAMING OF THE MILL AND MUCH OF THE MACHINERY TO THE ELEMENTS. BASED ON AN ASSESSMENT COMPLETED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF CIVIL AND ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING AT THE UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT (UVM) IN AN EARLIER PHASE, THIS PROJECT IS FOCUSED ON A) DEVELOPMENT OF CONCEPTUAL-LEVEL RECOMMENDATIONS INTO A DETAILED TREATMENT PLAN, AND B) TREATMENT IMPLEMENTATION USING A FIELD SCHOOL FORMAT THAT WILL RESULT IN TRAINING OF STUDENTS AND OTHERS IN THE TREATMENT PROCEDURES TO BE IMPLEMENTED. THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A DETAILED STABILIZATION PLAN FOR THE MILL. USING A FIELD SCHOOL FORMAT, MULTIPLE WORKSHOP SESSIONS WILL FOCUS ON TRAINING STUDENTS AND MID-CAREER HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROFESSIONALS IN EARLY-20TH CENTURY TIMBER FRAMING TECHNIQUES THAT COMBINE TRADITIONAL PRE-INDUSTRIAL JOINERY WITH BOLTED CONNECTIONS, THE USE OF IRON ELEMENTS TO MANAGE TENSILE STRESSES, AND THE TREATMENT PROCEDURES TO BE IMPLEMENTED. NPS MAY ALSO CREATE A SERIES OF SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS AND OR NPS WEBSITE CONTENT THAT WILL DISSEMINATE TO THE PUBLIC BOTH THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION PHILOSOPHY THAT GUIDED THE PROJECT ALONG WITH PROJECT RESULTS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THIS PROJECT ENGAGES THE RECIPIENT IN PRONGHORN TELEMETRY ANALYSIS TO CHARACTERIZE THE SEASONAL USE (LOCATION AND TIME) OF WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENT GRASSLANDS BY PRONGHORN IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES TO PRONGHORN FEEDING, RESTING, AND CALVING HABITATS. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A FINE-SCALE PRONGHORN HABITAT EVALUATION USING GIS ANALYSIS OF ROBUST GPS COLLAR TELEMETRY DATA. RESEARCH WILL DELINEATE PRONGHORN HIGH-USE AREAS AND MODEL QUALITY HABITAT FOR BOTH WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENT AND SURROUNDING PRONGHORN POPULATION RANGE. THE RESULTS WILL SUPPORT CONFIDENT RECOMMENDATIONS ON WILDLIFE CLOSURES (SEASONS AND OR AREAS), WITH OTHER IMMEDIATE APPLICATIONS TO LANDSCAPE-SCALE HABITAT CONSERVATION. MAPS AND A WRITTEN REPORT OF PRONGHORN SEASONAL USE AREAS WILL BE CREATED WITH GIS APPLICATIONS.THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP ADEQUATE, COORDINATED, AND COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING ACTIVITIES CONCERNING THE RESOURCES OF THE NPS BY ENGAGING THE EXPERTISE AND UNIQUE QUALIFICATIONS OF THE RECIPIENT, WHO HAS SOLE JURISDICTION FOR WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT IN THE STATE OF ARIZONA. THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH THIS RESEARCH AND RELATED RESULTS. THE DISSEMINATION OF THIS NATURAL RESOURCE INFORMATION WILL ASSIST IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WILDERNESS PROTECTION.

TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT AN ARCHEOLOGICAL INVENTORY OF A MINIMUM OF 1,500 ACRES AT IDENTIFIED HIGH PRIORITY LOCATIONS, COMPLETE ALL NECESSARY FIELD RECORDING (INCLUDING FIELD SITE FORMS, CONDITION ASSESSMENTS, ARTIFACT ASSESSMENTS, SITE MAPS, AND PHOTOGRAPHIC RECORDS), COMPLETE DIGITAL SITE RECORDS FOLLOWING STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE REQUIREMENTS (INCLUDING SITE RECORDS AND GIS RECORDS), PRODUCE A CULTURAL RESOURCES REPORT DOCUMENTING ALL WORK AND FOLLOWING REQUIRED STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE FORMATS, PRODUCE MATERIALS AND PRESENTATIONS TO BE USED FOR PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS, AND HIGHLIGHT THE IMPORTANCE OF PROTECTING ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES.THIS PROJECT PROMOTES GREATER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES. THE INFORMATION, PRODUCTS AND OR SERVICES IDENTIFIED OR DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND SUPPORT FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF SIGNIFICANT RESOURCES THUS PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. INFORMATION RESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH PUBLIC TALKS, PUBLIC-ORIENTED PUBLICATIONS, AND CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS.ARCHEOLOGICAL RESEARCH IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS WILL RESULT IN INCREASED KNOWLEDGE OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND ASSIST IN BETTER MANAGING AND PROTECTING CULTURAL RESOURCES. RESULTS WILL BE USED IN RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, AS WELL AS FOR EDUCATIONAL AND INTERPRETIVE MEDIA. RESULTS OF THE SURVEY WILL BE USED TO HELP EVALUATE THE VARIOUS TYPES OF THREATS THAT ARE CURRENTLY IMPACTING CULTURAL RESOURCES.

MANAGERS OF NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION PARKS NEED TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACTS OF OVERABUNDANT NATIVE WHITE-TAILED DEER (ODOCOILEUS VIRGINIANUS) ON NATIVE PLANT COMMUNITIES BEFORE AND AFTER THE PARKS IMPLEMENTED DEER MANAGEMENT. ROCK CREEK PARK (ROCR), CATOCTIN MOUNTAIN PARK (CATO), AND OTHER PARKS ARE USING ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT QUANTIFY VEGETATION RESPONSE TO MORE THAN A DECADE OF DEER CULLING PROGRAMS.  DEER MANAGEMENT BEGAN IN 2010 FOR CATO AND IN 2012 FOR ROCR. ROCR WAS ONLY ABLE TO CULL DEER ONE NIGHT IN 2012, SO MANAGEMENT ACTIONS REALLY STARTED IN 2013. PARKS MONITOR VEGETATION AS AN INDICATOR OF FOREST RECOVERY AND OF THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE MANAGEMENT ACTION, I.E., DEER CULLING. DATA HAVE BEEN COLLECTED FROM PERMANENT PLOTS IN THE PARKS SINCE 1991. SOME PARKS HAVE ADDITIONAL PAIRED FENCED AND UNFENCED MODULES ADDED DURING THE EARLY 2000S. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM OF RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION THAT INVOLVES CULTURAL SCIENCES NEEDED TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES. THE RECIPIENT WILL UPDATE THE 1977 ARCHEOLOGICAL OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT (AOA) FOR AZTEC RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT AND PRODUCE AN ARCHEOLOGICAL OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT FOR CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS GOAL, THE RECIPIENT WILL UPDATE AND COMPLETE AOAS THAT PROVIDE A THOROUGH EXAMINATION OF EXISTING RECORDS, DOCUMENTS, AND REPORTS TO DESCRIBE AND EVALUATE THE KNOWN AND POTENTIAL ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES OF BOTH SITES AND IDENTIFY THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL FIELD SURVEYS TO LOCATE, EVALUATE, AND DOCUMENT RESOURCES. ALL WORK COMPLETED WITH FOLLOW THE NPS 28 - CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GUIDELINE.  AN AOA IS THE BASIC ELEMENT OF A PARK S ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. IT IS AN ARCHEOLOGICAL RESEARCH REPORT PRODUCED FOR A PARK AND THE FIRST STEP IN DETERMINING THE REQUIREMENTS FOR ADDITIONAL ARCHEOLOGICAL RESEARCH. BASED ON A THOROUGH EXAMINATION OF EXISTING RECORDS, DOCUMENTS, AND REPORTS, THE OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT DESCRIBE AND EVALUATE THE KNOWN AND POTENTIAL ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES IN AN AREA AND IDENTIFY THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL FIELD SURVEYS TO LOCATE, EVALUATE, AND DOCUMENT RESOURCES. BY WAY OF HAVING UP TO DATE AND COMPLETE AOAS FOR BOTH SITES HISTORIANS, INTERPRETERS, WRITERS, THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, AND MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC WILL BE PROVIDED NEW INFORMATION. THIS PROJECT PROMOTES GREATER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES. THE INFORMATION, PRODUCTS AND OR SERVICES IDENTIFIED OR DEVELOPED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATIONS CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL HERITAGE. RESEARCH COMPLETED ON CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK AND AZTEC RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT WILL ENHANCE THE PUBLICS UNDERSTANDING OF CHACOAN ARCHEOLOGY AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AT CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORIC PARK DATING TO THE EARLIER BASKET MAKER, ARCHAIC, PALEO-INDIAN OCCUPATIONS, AND THE LATER HISTORIC NAVAJO OCCUPATION.

TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS AS WILL PROVIDE FULL GEOGRAPHIC AND TOPICAL COVERAGE FOR RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE RESOURCES CONTAINED IN UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR LARGER REGIONS.A. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE COMPLETION OF AN ARCHITECTURAL VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OF THE MISSION CONCEPTION CONVENTO. THE CONVENTO EXEMPLIFIES INTANGIBLE CULTURAL HERITAGE IN ITS USE OF TRADITIONAL CRAFTSMANSHIP, SPECIFICALLY THE ENDURING WORK OF MASTER BUILDERS, STONEMASONS, CARPENTERS, AND SCULPTORS. THE CONVENTO STRUCTURE IS BUILT WITH LOAD-BEARING, RUBBLE MASONRY WALLS, DRESSED AND SET IN LIME MORTAR. INTERIOR WALLS ARE PRIMARILY COVERED WITH PLASTER AND PAINT. NUMEROUS FACTORS HAVE PLAYED A ROLE IN THE DETERIORATION OF BUILDING FABRIC, BOTH OF THE MASONRY MASS AND OF THE PAINTED SURFACES. ONE OF THE PRIMARY GOALS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BEGIN LINKING INDIVIDUAL PARK VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT EFFORTS TO FORM A NETWORK OF MULTIPLE PARKS ACROSS THE REGION IN ORDER TO DEVELOP A COMMON BASELINE METHODOLOGY FOR ASSESSING THE HEALTH OF RESOURCES AND IDENTIFY CONDITION TRENDS THAT TRANSCEND THE DIVERSITY OF STRUCTURAL SYSTEMS, MATERIAL TYPES, PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES, AND ENVIRONMENTS. PROJECT WORK WILL BE IN ACCORD WITH THE NPS VITAL SIGNS APPROACH TO INVENTORY AND MONITORING (I M).BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS

IT IS WELL ESTABLISHED THAT EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) IS THE MOST ECONOMICALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY EFFECTIVE WAY TO MANAGE THE INCURSIONS. SUCCESS OF EDRR FRAMEWORKS RELIES HEAVILY ON ESTABLISHING NETWORKS WITH STATE, FEDERAL, TRIBAL, AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES AND REQUIRE DEDICATED PROFESSIONAL STAFFING TO KEEP UP TO DATE ON EMERGING TECHNOLOGY AND THREATS. THIS PROJECT WOULD ESTABLISH A MIDWEST EDRR FRAMEWORK (BASED ON THE NATIONAL FRAMEWORK) THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF PARTNERSHIPS AND DEDICATED STAFFING TO IMPLEMENT A REGIONAL SCALE PREVENTION AND EDRR AQUATIC NUISANCE SPECIES (ANS) PROGRAM WITH EMPHASIS ON KEY AQUATIC THREATS, SPECIFICALLY THOSE ASSOCIATED WITH NEWLY RESTORED OR HIGH PRIORITY HABITAT AREAS. THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE COMPLETION OF AN ARCHITECTURAL VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OF THE 17TH CENTURY QUARAI SPANISH MISSION CHURCH, A STRUCTURE BUILT WITH LOCAL SANDSTONE USING TRADITIONAL TECHNIQUES IN 1626. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE FOUNDATIONAL DATA GATHERING REQUIRED TO IDENTIFY STRUCTURALLY VULNERABLE AREAS OF THE CHURCH IN ITS CURRENT CONDITION, AS WELL AS MATERIAL VULNERABILITIES ACROSS ITS WALLS. FOUNDATIONAL DATA GATHERING WILL INCLUDE A STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING ASSESSMENT, ANALYSIS OF CURRENT CLIMATE CONDITIONS FOCUSING ON ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES OVER THE PAST SEVERAL DECADES, AS WELL AS FIRST-ORDER CONDITION SURVEY OF THE CHURCH USING ELEVATION PHOTOGRAPHY FOR ANNOTATIONS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS AS WILL PROVIDE FULL GEOGRAPHIC AND TOPICAL COVERAGE FOR RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE RESOURCES CONTAINED IN UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR LARGER REGIONS.THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE A CULTURAL LANDSCAPE REPORT (CLR) FOR THE RATTLESNAKE SPRINGS, A CULTURAL LANDSCAPE THAT WAS DOCUMENTED THROUGH THE CULTURAL LANDSCAPE INVENTORY (CLI) IN 2023. THE PROPERTY IS LOCATED WITHIN THE CARLSBAD CAVERNS NATIONAL PARK (PARK) AND CONSISTS OF ROADS, WATER COURSES, BUILDINGS, FENCES, CCC-ERA RESOURCES AND VIEWSHEDS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE NATIONAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE SITE. THE SITE IS THE ONLY SOURCE OF FRESH WATER FOR THE PARK. THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE DATA IN THE CLI AS A BASIS FOR EXISTING CONDITIONS AND CONSIST OF DEVELOPING AN ANALYSIS OF THE CHANGES TO THE LANDSCAPE OVER TIME TO PREPARE TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO PRESERVE AND PROTECT THE SITE WHILE ALLOWING FOR INCREASED VISITATION. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS (PROJECT ABSTRACTS), OR CONTACT THE NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY OFFICE AT FINANCIAL ASSITANCE POLICY NPS.GOV.

TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF BAT SPECIES OCCURRENCE AND DISTRIBUTION IN MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK, UTILIZING THE NORTH AMERICAN BAT MONITORING PROGRAM (NABAT) PROTOCOLS AND WITHIN NABAT PRIORITY GRID SAMPLING CELLS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM WILL ANALYZE ACOUSTIC BAT DATA COLLECTED BY THE PARK AT N 12 SITES X 4 NIGHTS EACH (A TOTAL OF 48 TRAP NIGHTS).  THE SPECIES DETECTED FROM EACH SAMPLE NIGHT AND THE NUMBER OF DETECTIONS BY SPECIES PER NIGHT ANALYZED WILL BE REPORTED TO MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK BY MARCH 1, 2024 VIA A TECHNICAL REPORT SUBMISSION.   PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE SPECIES DETECTED FROM EACH SAMPLE NIGHT AND THE NUMBER OF DETECTIONS BY SPECIES PER NIGHT ANALYZED WILL BE REPORTED TO MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK BY MARCH 1, 2024 VIA A TECHNICAL REPORT SUBMISSION.  THE FIRST YEAR OF THE PROJECT (2022) DETECTED N 16 SPECIES ACROSS N 10 GENERA AT N 11 SITES AT MESA VERDE NP.  BENEFICIARIES:THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO THE NPS GAINS BY NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH RESEARCH AND RELATED RESULTS DISSEMINATION OF NATURAL, CULTURAL AND OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE INFORMATION. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE DATA THAT CAN BE ACCESSED BY RESEARCHERS ACROSS THE COUNTRY THROUGH THE NABAT ONLINE PLATFORM AND WILL FORGE A WORKING RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN WILDLIFE STAFF AT MESA VERDE AND RESEARCH STAFF AT THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM.  WE (MEVE NR) ALREADY HAVE A WORKING RELATIONSHIP WITH CNHP ON THE BOTANY VEGETATION ECOLOGY PROGRAM AND WE ARE EXPANDING IT TO INCLUDE THE WILDLIFE PROGRAM. MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK AND THE AMERICAN PUBLIC.

IN SUPPORT OF A PENDING FACILITY PROJECT, THE HISTORIC STRUCTURE REPORT (HSR) WILL PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE DOCUMENTATION REGARDING THE EVOLUTION OF THE INDIGENOUS QUARTERS STRUCTURES AT MISSION SAN JOS. THE REPORT WILL EVALUATE THEIR CURRENT CONDITION, CAUSES FOR STRUCTURAL DEFICIENCIES AND DETERIORATION, AND PROVIDE TREATMENT GUIDELINES. THE HSR IS THE PRIMARY GUIDE TO THE ORIGIN, MODIFICATION, TREATMENT AND USE OF THE CULTURAL RESOURCE. THIS HSR WILL SUPPORT FUTURE PRESERVATION EFFORTS AND REPAIR OF THE SAN JOS INDIGENOUS QUARTERS BY PROVIDING DOCUMENTATION ON CRITICAL AREAS OF DETERIORATION AND POTENTIAL RECOMMENDATIONS FOR STABILIZING THE STRUCTURE WITHIN THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIORS TREATMENT STANDARDS AND GUIDELINES.THIS HSR IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT TO THE SAN ANTONIO MISSIONS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK. MISSION SAN JOSE IS A PRIMARY VISITOR CONTACT AREA THAT HOUSES THE LARGEST VISITOR CENTER AND MUSEUM IN THE PARK. THE INDIGENOUS QUARTERS DEFINE THE WALLED COMPOUND OF THE SITE AND HELP THE VISITOR UNDERSTAND THE HISTORIC LAYOUT OF A MISSION. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THE BORDER WALL BETWEEN THE U.S.A. AND MEXICO REPRESENTS A NOVEL HUMAN-MADE FEATURE IN THE SONORAN DESERT WHOSE IMPACTS OF WILDLIFE REMAIN POORLY UNDERSTOOD. THESE IMPACTS COULD INCLUDE DISRUPTED MOVEMENT PATTERNS ACROSS MULTIPLE SPATIOTEMPORAL SCALES THROUGH THE PHYSICAL PRESENCE OF THE WALL AND OR BEHAVIORAL AVOIDANCE DUE TO HUMAN ACTIVITY, ROADS, OR LIGHTING. DISRUPTION OF MOVEMENT PATTERNS CAN NOT ONLY AFFECT LARGE-SCALE MIGRATORY MOVEMENTS BUT ALSO MOVEMENTS WITHIN AN INDIVIDUALS HOME RANGE WHICH MAY PREVENT INDIVIDUALS FROM ACCESSING IMPORTANT RESOURCES. MANY MAMMAL SPECIES, INCLUDING MAMMALIAN CARNIVORES, HAVE RELATIVELY LARGE HOME RANGES MAKING THEM INCREASINGLY SUSCEPTIBLE TO NEGATIVE BORDER WALL IMPACTS. FINALLY, THE BORDER WALL RUNS BETWEEN TWO LARGE NETWORKS OF PROTECTED LANDS KNOWN FOR THEIR RICH DESERT BIODIVERSITY AND DIVERSE MAMMAL COMMUNITIES. THESE NETWORKS ARE THE CABEZA PRIETA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND ORGAN PIPE NATIONAL MONUMENT IN THE U.S.A. AND THE EL PINACATE Y GRAN DESIERTO DE ALTAR BIOSPHERE RESERVE IN MEXICO. THE GOALS OF THIS STUDY ARE TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS OF THE BORDER WALL ON MAMMALIAN COMMUNITIES WITHIN THESE PROTECTED NETWORKS AND PROVIDE SUGGESTIONS FOR ACTIONS TO MITIGATE NEGATIVE BORDER WALL IMPACTS ON THESE WILDLIFE COMMUNITIES. WE WILL ACCOMPLISH THIS USING CAMERA TRAPS PLACED AT VARYING DISTANCES FROM THE BORDER AND IN DIFFERENT LANDSCAPE CONTEXTS. WE WILL USE DETECTION NON-DETECTION DATA OF DIFFERENT MAMMALS TO ESTIMATE SPECIES-SPECIFIC AND COMMUNITY-LEVEL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN OCCUPANCY AND BORDER WALL PROXIMITY. THIS STUDY WILL BE LED BY A GRADUATE STUDENT FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA IN COLLABORATION WITH THE PINACATE RESERVE AND NATIONAL PARK SERVICE.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS REGARDING THE MOVEMENT OF NUMEROUS ARCHITECTURAL COMPONENTS OF THE CLIFF PALACE ALCOVE COMPLEX IN MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK (MEVE).  INFORMATION RESULTING FROM RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS WILL YIELD RECOMMENDATIONS FOR STABILIZATION METHODS FOR THE ANCESTRAL PUEBLO CLIFF DWELLING COMPLEX AND HELP TO ENSURE ITS PRESERVATION AND CONTINUED SAFE ACCESS BY THE PUBLIC.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES AND CONCERNS, AND SHARE THE RESULTING NEW INFORMATION WITH THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC. THE RECIPIENT WILL APPLY STATE-OF-THE ART TECHNICAL EXPERTISE TO INVESTIGATE, DOCUMENT, ANALYZE, AND DIAGNOSE THE FULL RANGE OF ISSUES NEGATIVELY IMPACTING THE INTEGRITY OF CLIFF PALACE. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE THOROUGHLY RESEARCHED, LOGICAL, AND FEASIBLE OPTIONS FOR LONG-TERM CARE OF CLIFF PALACE IN FULL COMPLIANCE WITH THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIORS STANDARDS FOR THE TREATMENT OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES. THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP AND POTENTIAL STABILIZATION METHODS OF ANCESTRAL PUEBLO ALCOVE DWELLINGS OF THE AMERICAN SOUTHWEST.  IT WILL ALSO ASSESS AND PROVIDE STABILIZATION GUIDELINES AND METHODOLOGIES FOR THE SAFE ACCESS OF THE MANY VISITORS THAT COME TO TOUR CLIFF PALACE IN MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK.  THE RECIPIENTS STAFF, FACULTY, AND STUDENTS FROM THE CENTER FOR CULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY (CCS) WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE NPS IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES.  DUE TO THE UNIQUE NATURE OF OBSERVED AND DOCUMENTED PROBLEMS AT CLIFF PALACE, THE UTSA-CCS TEAM WILL CONSIST OF PH.D., MASTERS AND OR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, FACULTY, ON-STAFF RESEARCHERS, AND VISITING SCHOLARS. THESE INDIVIDUALS WILL DEVELOP AND GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH STATE-OF-THE-ART RESEARCH AND ANALYSIS. THE FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS DEVELOPED IN THE PROJECT WILL BE SHARED TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AND JOURNAL PUBLICATIONS, LEADING TO DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION ON PIONEERING METHODS OF CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, ANALYSIS, AND POSSIBLE INNOVATIVE AND NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT (NHPA) SECTION 106-COMPLIANT STABILIZATION METHODS. THE DISSEMINATION OF RESULTS WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND PROVIDE KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT FOR HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP AT MEVE.  LASTLY, STUDENTS WILL BE DIRECTLY ENGAGED IN MEANINGFUL FIELD WORK SUPPORTING SPECIALISTS AS THEY LEARN ABOUT CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS DEVELOP A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN DEVILS TOWER NATIONAL MONUMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND THE RECIPIENT OF THE AWARD.  UNDERNEATH THIS PARTNERSHIP, BOTH ENTITIES WOULD ACCOMPLISH A PROJECT TO COLLECT AND TEST ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES IN TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL CLIMBING TERRAIN AT DEVILS TOWER NATIONAL MONUMENT TO TEST FOR THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF THE PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTRANS FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME IN MULTIPLE BAT SPECIES.  THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL ALSO CONDUCT LAB EXPERIMENTS TO DETERMINE THE ABILITY OF THE FUNGUS TO TRANSFER FROM CLIMBING MATERIALS EQUIPMENT TO FROM THE ROCK TYPE PHONOLITE PORPHYRY THAT MAKES UP THE TOWER FORMATION AT THE PARK.  THIS PROJECT AND EXPERIMENT WILL FURTHER THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE BEHAVIOR OF THE FUNGUS IN VERTICAL TERRAIN UTILIZED BY BATS AND BY RECREATIONAL CLIMBERS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS (PROJECT ABSTRACTS), OR CONTACT THE NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY OFFICE AT FINANCIAL ASSITANCE POLICY NPS.GOV.

TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE GOAL OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS FOR PERSONNEL FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO, MUSEUM OF SOUTHWESTERN BIOLOGY, DIVISION OF ARTHROPODS (UNM) TO INVENTORY AND TO MONITOR POLLINATING INSECTS OF THE VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL MONUMENT, NEW MEXICO, AS THE PRELIMINARY STEP TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A LONG-TERM MONITORING PROGRAM FOR POLLINATORS ON THE PRESERVE. THE MONITORING PROGRAM MAY ALSO BE EXPANDED TO INCLUDE AREAS OF BANDELIER NATIONAL MONUMENT. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE STUDY WILL 1) DOCUMENT WHICH SPECIES OF INSECT POLLINATORS OCCUR ON THE PRESERVE AND POTENTIALLY BANDELIER NATIONAL MONUMENT, ALONG WITH DOCUMENTING INSECT POLLINATOR-FLOWERING PLANT SPECIES RELATIONSHIPS ACROSS DIFFERENT STUDY SITE ENVIRONMENTS, AND 2) DEVELOP A LONG-TERM MONITORING PROJECT OF THE POLLINATOR INSECTS ACROSS THOSE SAME STUDY SITES IN RELATION TO CHANGING CLIMATE AND VEGETATION. MONITORING PROTOCOLS WILL BE INITIATED AND TESTED FOR ACCURACY AND EFFICIENCY DURING THE FIRST 2 YEARS, AND ONE PRIMARY PROTOCOL WILL THEN BE CONTINUED BY PRESERVE STAFF AND OR COLLABORATING ENTOMOLOGISTS FOR MULTIPLE YEARS INTO THE FUTURE.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS (PROJECT ABSTRACTS), OR CONTACT THE NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY OFFICE AT FINANCIAL ASSITANCE POLICY NPS.GOV.

COOPERATIVE RESEARCH ECOSYSTEM STUDY UNIT SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO ESTABLISH AND MAINTAIN COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, TRIBES, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, TO FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.  THIS PROJECT, POPULATION ASSESSMENT OF BURBOT LOTA LOTA IN PTARMIGAN LAKE AND MORPHOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF ROCK AND PTARMIGAN LAKES, STUDIES BURBOT, ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT FISHERIES RESOURCES WITHIN WRANGELL-ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK   PRESERVE, FOR SUBSISTENCE AND RECREATIONAL HARVEST OPPORTUNITIES. WITH THE EXISTING, EXTREMELY LIMITED INFORMATION ON FISHING PRESSURE, USER TYPES (SPORT OR SUBSISTENCE), OR HARVESTS ON THE LAKES OF THIS INTENDED STUDY, ESTABLISHING BASELINE DATA FOR THE POPULATIONS IN THESE LAKES IS A VITAL INITIAL STEP FOR RESPONSIBLE FUTURE MANAGEMENT DESIGNED TO ENSURE THE LONG- TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF THIS RESOURCE. THE FINDINGS OF THIS STUDY WILL ALSO PROVIDE USEFUL INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC WITH INTEREST IN FISHING OR NAVIGATING IN BOTH PTARMIGAN AND ROCK LAKES.  TIMELINE: ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH   GAME WILL CONDUCT MARK AND RECAPTURE SAMPLING EVENTS OF BURBOT IN PTARMIGAN LAKE DURING JUNE AND AUGUST OF 2023. BATHYMETRIC DATA WILL BE RECORDED AT BOTH PTARMIGAN AND ROCK LAKE DURING 2023. PROJECT FINDINGS WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN A STATE OF ALASKA FISHERIES DATA SERIES PEER REVIEWED REPORT BY 30 JUNE 2024.  COPIES OF THE REPORT WILL BE AVAILABLE ELECTRONICALLY TO THE PUBLIC FROM THE SPORT FISH PUBLICATIONS LINK OF THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH   GAME WEB SITE. BENEFICIARIES: STATE OF ALASKA, SUBSISTENCE USERS, GENERAL PUBLIC.

TITLE: ASSESS FUELS TREATMENT IMPACTS AND DEVELOP RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR AN ENDANGERED TERRESTRIAL SALAMANDER.15.945: COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM CESU NETWORKPROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATECOOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE IMPACTS OF FUELS TREATMENTS ON THE FEDERALLY-ENDANGERED JEMEZ MOUNTAINS SALAMANDER (JMS), PLETHODON NEOMEXICANUS, AT VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE (VALL). FOR JMS, FUELS TREATMENTS CAN RESULT IN LOSS OF PRIMARY CONSTITUENT HABITAT ELEMENTS, INCLUDING CANOPY ELEMENTS, LARGE FALLEN TREES AND OTHER WOODY DEBRIS, AND STRUCTURAL FEATURES (E.G. ROCKS, BARK, AND MOSS MATS). THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE NPS, ALONG WITH SUBJECT-MATTER EXPERTS FROM THE NEW MEXICO ENDEMIC SALAMANDER TEAM (NMEST), REPRESENTING GOVERNMENT AND ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS, TO DEVELOP RECOVERY ACTIONS AND BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) FOR JMS IN THE CONTEXT OF CRITICAL, ONGOING FUELS TREATMENTS. EFFORTS WILL BUILD UPON ONGOING WORK TO RELATE SALAMANDER POPULATIONS AND ACTIVITY TO ABOVE- AND BELOW-GROUND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, THEREBY INFORMING CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND HELPING ENSURE PROJECT SUCCESS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE RECIPIENT TO STUDY, RESEARCH, AND DEVELOP INFORMATION REGARDING THE CUMULATIVE IMPACTS OF MANAGED ACCESS ON THE UNCONFINED WILDLAND RECREATION EXPERIENCE. INFORMATION RESULTING FROM THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO ASSIST IN DEVELOPING A STANDARD LEXICON FOR DISCUSSING MANAGED ACCESS ACROSS AGENCIES, AS SYSTEMS ARE BEING PILOTED AND IMPLEMENTED ACROSS PUBLIC LAND. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE A BRIEFING DOCUMENT AIMED AT PROVIDING MANAGERS WITH A CONCEPTUAL UNDERSTANDING OF MANAGED ACCESS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A CONCEPTUAL GRAPHIC MODEL FOR HOW MANAGED ACCESS IS APPLIED ACROSS THE RECREATION OPPORTUNITY SPECTRUM IN FEDERAL PUBLIC LANDS, INCLUDING AN ILLUSTRATIVE APPLICATION OF A CONCEPTUAL MODEL IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A STANDARDIZED GLOSSARY OF TERMS SURROUNDING MANAGED ACCESS. THE RECIPIENT WILL HOLD TWO WORKSHOPS WITH MANAGERS FROM GLACIER NATIONAL PARK (GLAC), GRAND TETONS NATIONAL PARK (GRTE), AND YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK (YELL) TO REFINE THE CONCEPTUAL MODEL, FOLLOWED BY A PRESENTATION OF THE FINAL MODEL.THE PUBLIC PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO DEVELOP INFORMATION REGARDING MANAGED ACCESS AND SHARE IT THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND SUPPORT FOR THE STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATIONS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY EXTERNAL TO THE NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH RESEARCH.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A COLLECTION-FOCUSED EDUCATIONAL WORK EXPERIENCE OPPORTUNITY FOR ARCHEOLOGY, ANTHROPOLOGY, AND MUSEUM STUDIES STUDENTS. THE PURPOSE IS TO COMPLEMENT CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION WITH HANDS-ON WORK ACTIVITIES IN A VARIETY OF AREAS THAT DESCRIBE, PRESERVE, AND MAKE CULTURAL ARTIFACTS AND CURATED NATURAL HISTORY SPECIMENS MORE AVAILABLE. THE SKILLS GAINED THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE STUDENT EMPLOYABILITY IN SEVERAL DIVERSE FIELDS. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT FUNDS THE RESEARCH, PRINTING AND FILING OF DOCUMENTATION TO PROVIDE ACCOUNTABILITY FOR INCOMING AND OUTGOING PARK AND CENTER TRANSACTIONS AND ASSIST NATIONAL PARK SERVICE CURATORIAL STAFF WITH PROVIDING ACCOUNTABILITY FOR COLLECTIONS HELD IN NON-FEDERAL REPOSITORIES. INCOMING COLLECTION ITEMS WILL BE IN PROCESSED TO PREPARE MATERIALS FOR CATALOGING AND STORAGE. OBJECTS WILL BE CATALOGEDS AND EXISTING CATALOG RECORDS UPDATED TO DESCRIBE THE ITEMS AND FACILITATE THEIR RETRIEVAL FOR RESEARCH. STORAGE WILL BE CONSOLIDATED AND IMPROVED TO PROMOTE PRESERVATION AND EFFICIENT USE OF REPOSITORY SPACE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:RESEARCH REPORTS WILL BE PRODUCED FOR INDIVIDUAL ITEMS, GROUPS OF ITEMS, OR PROJECTS BY JANUARY 31, 2027. INCOMING AND RETURNING COLLECTIONS WILL BE PROCESSED TO IDENTIFY MATERIALS VIA INVENTORY, PESTS ERADICATED, AND MATERIALS THAT MUST BE CLEANED IDENTIFIED AND PREPARED FOR CATALOGING AND STORAGE BY DECEMBER 31, 2026. EACH ITEM WILL BE CATALOGED, OR RECORDS UPDATED, PHOTOGRAPHS WILL BE ATTACHED OR RELOCATED TO THE ASSIGNED DIGITAL FOLDER, AND AN ELECTRONIC RECORD FOR EACH ITEM OR LOT ENTERED OR UPDATED IN ICMS WILL BE REVIEWED FOR ACCURACY AND SUBMITTED BY FEBRUARY 28, 2027. ITEMS WILL BE STORED, ORGANIZED, AND LABELLED IN APPROPRIATELY SIZED BOXES AND ENCLOSURES AND STORAGE LOCATIONS UPDATED BY MARCH 15, 2027. THE FINAL PROJECT REPORT, WITH A SEPARATE ABSTRACT, WILL SUMMARIZE ALL WORK COMPLETED INCLUDING FINAL COUNTS OF ACCOMPLISHED TASKS WITH THE DRAFT FINAL REPORT SUBMITTED BY MAY 15, 2027, AND THE FINAL REPORT BY JUNE 30, 2027.BENEFICIARIES:BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

IF THE NUTRIENTS ARE DERIVED FROM SOURCES INSIDE FLORIDA BAY, IS RESUSPENSION OF SEDIMENTS THE SOURCE.

PROJECT ABSTRACT: 15.945: COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM CESU NETWORK  PROGRAMMING SUPPORTS A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK OF COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS TO FACILITATE  COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, AND TRAINING TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF  THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THE STUDY UNITS FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION  PRODUCTS ACROSS MULTIPLE GEOGRAPHIC REGIONS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. IN PARTICULAR, IT WILL ANALYZE TREE-RING CORES TO MODEL TREE-RING FORMATION TO IDENTIFY ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN TREE GROWTH AND SUB-SEASONAL CLIMATE AND WEATHER. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL METHODS ON PLANT SPECIES AFFECTED BY GLEN CANYON DAM OPERATIONS. WE WILL USE FIELD-BASED AND REMOTE SENSING MEASUREMENTS TO QUANTIFY THE EFFICACY OF THE INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL METHODS. THIS STUDY WILL ENABLE NPS, USGS, AND NAU COLLABORATORS TO ADDRESS A SHARED GOAL OF PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS TO INCREASE THEIR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH SKILLSET AND CONTRIBUTE TO PUBLIC LANDS MANAGEMENT. THE FINAL GOAL INCLUDES EDUCATING THE PUBLIC ON HOW GLEN CANYON DAM OPERATIONS NEGATIVELY IMPACT RIPARIAN VEGETATION HEALTH ALONG THE COLORADO RIVER CORRIDOR, AND HOW NON-FLOW VEGETATION TREATMENT ACTIONS MAY MITIGATE GLEN CANYON DAM OPERATION IMPACTS ON RIPARIAN VEGETATION ALONG THE COLORADO RIVER.THIS PROJECT WILL QUANTIFY HOW EFFECTIVE THE INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL METHODS HAVE BEEN. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL: 1) DETERMINE WHICH VEGETATION TREATMENT METHODS (I.E., BROADCAST FOLIAR VS. SNIP-AND-DRIP VS. REFERENCE) ARE THE MOST EFFECTIVE FOR CONTROLLING INVASIVE NON-NATIVE PLANT SPECIES (E.G., CAMELTHORN  ALHAGI MAURORUM , RUSSIAN KNAPWEED  ACROPTILON REPENS ) AFFECTED BY DAM OPERATIONS  AND 2) DETERMINE WHICH VEGETATION TREATMENT METHODS (I.E., BROADCAST FOLIAR VS. SNIP-AND-DRIP VS. MECHANICAL VS. REFERENCE) ARE THE MOST EFFECTIVE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY FOR REMOVING VEGETATION (E.G., ARROWWEED  PLUCHEA SERICEA , COYOTE WILLOW  SALIX EXIGUA ) ENCROACHING ON CAMPABLE AREAS. IN THESE STEPS, WE WILL USE EXISTING FIELD-BASED MONITORING DATA AS WELL AS AIRBORNE AND SATELLITE IMAGES FROM BEFORE AND AFTER THE TREATMENTS. THIS PROJECT UNDER ASSISTANCE LISTING 15.945, COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDY UNITS PROVIDES FULL GEOGRAPHIC AND TOPICAL COVERAGE FOR RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE RESOURCES CONTAINED IN UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR LARGER REGIONS.  THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ANNUAL PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR K-12 TEACHERS TO INTEGRATE KNOWLEDGE OF LONG-TERM MONITORING, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND STEWARDSHIP PRINCIPLES INTO CURRICULUM FOR ALASKAN STUDENTS.  THROUGH THE WORKSHOP, TEACHERS EXPERIENCE FIRST-HAND THE COASTAL ECOSYSTEM AND CONNECT WITH RESEARCHERS WHO ARE IN THE FIELD PERFORMING LONG-TERM MONITORING SURVEYS. THROUGH THESE PROGRAMS, ALASKA GEOGRAPHIC HAS BUILT A HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL MODEL FOR INTRODUCING TEACHERS TO EXPERIENTIAL EDUCATION AND TRANSFERRING LESSONS BACK TO THE CLASSROOM. THE SUCCESS OF THIS WORKSHOP INVOLVES COLLABORATION OF SEVERAL PARTNERS, INCLUDING THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (WORKSHOP FACILITATOR AND FIELD RESEARCHERS), U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (FIELD RESEARCHERS), ALASKA GEOGRAPHIC (COURSE COORDINATION AND LOGISTICS, RISK MANAGEMENT CONSULTATION AND TEACHER RECRUITMENT), UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE (CONTINUING EDUCATION CREDITS), AND PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND REGIONAL CITIZENS ADVISORY COUNCIL (PWSRCAC) (WORKSHOP FACILITATION) AS WELL AS LOCAL ALASKA TEACHERS.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE: STUDENTS IN GRADES K-12, PUBLIC TEACHERS, STATE AND PUBLIC NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE DETERMINATIONS OF ELIGIBILITY (NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES) AND CURRENT CONDITION ASSESSMENTS FOR TWO HISTORIC PROPERTIES, THE SUGLIA RESIDENTIAL COMPLEX, AND THE PAULSELL RANCH HEADQUARTERS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THE PETRIFIED FOREST EXPANSION ACT OF 2004 PROVIDED AUTHORIZATION FOR THE PARK TO EXPAND ITS BOUNDARIES TO THE EAST AND WEST TO FURTHER PROTECT SIGNIFICANT PALEONTOLOGICAL AND ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES. THESE PARCELS INCLUDE(D) A MIX OF PRIVATE, STATE, AND FEDERAL LANDS (BLM). TWO OF THE ACQUIRED PRIVATE PARCELS INCLUDE STRUCTURES. THE SUGLIA FAMILY PROPERTY INCLUDES A HOUSE, GARAGE, AND ASSOCIATED OUTBUILDINGS. THE ARCHITECTURE AND MATERIALS SUGGESTS THIS COMPLEX WAS BUILT SOMETIME IN THE 1970S. THE PAULSELL RANCH HEADQUARTERS INCLUDES A HISTORIC BARN, CORRALS, AND OUTBUILDINGS. NONE OF THESE STRUCTURES ARE CURRENTLY IN USE AND SEVERAL OF THE BUILDINGS ARE FALLING INTO DISREPAIR. TO DETERMINE THE BEST MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR THESE BUILDINGS THE PARK REQUIRES CURRENT CONDITION ASSESSMENTS AND DETERMINATIONS OF ELIGIBILITY (DOE) TO ENSURE IF ELIGIBLE THE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE UTILIZED. PARK ARCHEOLOGISTS WORKING WITH THE COOPERATOR WITH CONDUCT CURRENT CONDITION ASSESSMENTS. THE COOPERATOR WILL CONDUCT THE DETERMINATION.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS WORK WILL START IN FY2023 AND CONTINUE INTO FY2024. FULL CONDITION ASSESSMENTS AND A FULL DOE WILL BE COMPLETED AND SUBMITTED TO THE AZ STATE HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICE (SHPO) BY THE END OF THE PERFORMANCE PERIOD. BENEFICIARIES:BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PROJECT TITLE  PROGRAMMATIC BIOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT FOR THE EVALUATION OF IMPACTS OF ROUTINE ACTIONS ON FEDERALLY LISTED BATSTHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR IMPACTS OF SPECIFIC STRESSORS PRODUCED BY APPROXIMATELY 50 BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY ACTIONS ON FOUR FEDERALLY LISTED BATS.PERFORMANCE GOALS  THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A PROGRAMMATIC STRATEGY WHICH FACILITATES AN APPROACH TO CONSERVATION THAT PRIORITIZES NEEDS AT A POPULATION AND REGIONAL LEVEL FOR BATS WHILE ALLOWING PARKWAY MANAGEMENT TO CONDUCT ESSENTIAL OPERATIONS TO ACCOMMODATE EXPANSION OF VISITOR SERVICES ESPECIALLY BUILDINGS, OR TO PREVENT INJURY OR DEATH FROM HAZARD TREES FAILURE, ESPECIALLY CAMPGROUNDS, PICNIC AREAS, ETC.

THE PROJECT WOULD HAVE FOUR MAIN OBJECTIVES: 1) DETERMINE MUSSEL DIVERSITY, 2) DETERMINE STATUS OF POPULATIONS WHERE POSSIBLE INCLUDING ESTIMATES OF NATIVE FRESHWATER MUSSEL DENSITIES, 3) DETERMINE CURRENT THREATS TO POPULATIONS INCLUDING ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSEL METRICS AND OTHER INVASIVE MOLLUSKS IF FOUND, AND 4) INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS RELATED TO RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. NATIVE FRESHWATER MUSSELS (UNIONIDS) ARE IMPORTANT INDICATORS OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH AND ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED FAUNAL GROUPS IN NORTH AMERICA. THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO PROVIDE POPULATION ESTIMATES AND DOCUMENT THE MOVEMENT AND BEHAVIOR OF COYOTES ON CAPE LOOKOUT AND CAPE HATTERAS NATIONAL SEASHORES USING A COMBINATION OF DNA FROM SCAT AND HIGH-RESOLUTION GPS TRACKING COLLARS.  BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THIS PROJECT WILL HELP SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK DETERMINE THE BEST WAY TO MAINTAIN THE BIG MEADOWS LANDSCAPE. THE PARK SEEKS TO PRESERVE THE MEADOWS HISTORIC CHARACTER AS AN OPEN LANDSCAPE WHILE ALSO PRESERVING THE RARE RESOURCES AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES THAT THE MEADOW PROVIDES. THE PROJECT WILL FUND A GRADUATE STUDENT AT VIRGINIA TECH TO ANALYZE 20 YEARS OF VEGETATION COVER DATA TO DETERMINE HOW THE MEADOW VEGETATION HAS CHANGED OVER TIME. ANALYSES WILL LOOK FOR LINKS BETWEEN THE PARKS USE OF MOWING AND PRESCRIBED BURNING TO MANAGE THE MEADOW VEGETATION SINCE 2000. A REPORT WILL BE WRITTEN THAT SUMMARIZES THE VEGETATION CHANGES AND CONNECTIONS, AND THAT PUTS FORTH A SUGGESTED MANAGEMENT REGIMEN FOR FUTURE MEADOW MAINTENANCE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO TRAIN PARK STAFF AND ENGAGE VOLUNTEERS IN DESIGNING AND INSTALLING A POLLINATOR GARDEN AND ENHANCING INTERPRETIVE EXPERIENCES ALONG AN ADA ACCESSIBLE PATHWAY NEAR THE RED HILLS VISITOR CENTER IN THE TUCSON MOUNTAIN DISTRICT OF SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE WHILE EDUCATING VISITORS ON THE IMPORTANCE OF POLLINATORS AND ACTIVITIES THEY CAN FOR POLLINATORS IN THEIR OWN YARDS.  THE POLLINATOR GARDEN WILL EMPLOY SMALL-SCALE, PASSIVE WATER HARVESTING TECHNIQUES AND INCLUDE NATIVE FLOWERS THAT WILL ATTRACT A WIDE ARRAY OF POLLINATORS. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE YOUTH, ESPECIALLY JR. RANGERS, NEXT GEN RANGER INTERNS AND OTHER DIVERSE LOCAL YOUTH, WHO WILL HELP BUILD THE GARDEN.  WE WILL DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE SUCH AS TRADITIONALLY SIGNIFICANT PLANTS FOR LOCAL INDIGENOUS TRIBES, AND  WATER SMART  PLANTING TECHNIQUES FOR CLIMATE RESILIENCE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:1)DESIGN A DEMONSTRATION POLLINATOR GARDEN NEXT TO THE TUCSON MOUNTAIN DISTRICT VISITOR CENTER THAT MEETS THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  2)INSTALL THE GARDEN USING YOUTH VOLUNTEERS FROM THE LOCAL AREA  3)DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE SIGNS FOR THE GARDEN BASED ON THEMES ESTABLISHED BY THE PARK  AND4)MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE THE GARDEN DURING THE FIRST YEAR WITH A GOAL OF 70  PLANT SURVIVAL. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1.INITIAL MEETING  POLLINATOR GARDEN DESIGN CHARETTE  PROVISION OF TRAINING MATERIALS  COMPLETION OF GARDEN DESIGN THAT INCLUDES PATHS AND PLANT LOCATIONS 2.REVIEW OF PLAN FOR INSTALLATION OF IRRIGATION SYSTEM, PLANTS, AND FENCES TO EXCLUDE WILDLIFE  ASSIST AND EDUCATE YOUTH DURING MINIMUM OF 3 VOLUNTEER EVENTS  3.REVIEW OF SUCCESS OF INITIAL PLANTINGS AND INSTALLATION OF INTERPRETIVE SIGNS   4.ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PLANTINGS PRIOR TO WINTER  AND5.REVIEW OF PARK STAFF PLANS AND MAINTENANCE SCHEDULE TO ENSURE SUCCESS OF PLANTS AND USE OF GARDEN BY POLLINATORS AND VISITORS BY SPRING 2024.BENEFICIARIES:  BENEFITS WILL BE TO PARK VISITORS, INCLUDING PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES, WHO WILL LEARN ABOUT THE VALUE OF POLLINATORS AND NATIVE PLANTS AND HOW TO ENHANCE THEM IN THEIR HOMES. OTHER BENEFITS WILL BE TO INTERNS AND VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL GAIN CAREER SKILLS IN CONSERVATION BIOLOGY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PROVIDE SCIENTIFICALLY-BASED INFORMATION ON THE NATURE AND STATUS OF SELECTED BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AT RAINBOW BRIDGE NATIONAL MONUMENT. THE RECIPIENT WILL ASSIST WITH TECHNICAL STUDIES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE LANDSCAPE HISTORY AND CURRENT CONDITIONS OF THIS SITE. THROUGH THIS PROJECT UNIVERSITY STUDENTS WILL COLLABORATE WITH NPS THROUGH PARTICIPATING IN NATURAL RESOURCES RESEARCH.THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN STUDIES OF RAINBOW BRIDGE TO UNDERSTAND CURRENT THREATS, COMPLETE PHOTOGRAMMETRY DOCUMENTATION OF RAINBOW BRIDGE AS BASELINE DATA AND TO BE AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE MODELLING AND FOR CREATION OF A 3D MODEL, AND COMPLETE DATING OF THE TERRACES AROUND RAINBOW BRIDGE TO UNDERSTAND THE FORMATION OF THE BRIDGE. BY PARTICIPATING IN THE PROJECT, UNIVERSITY STUDENTS WILL LEARN AND DEVELOP TECHNICAL SKILLS IN GEOPHYSICS, AND WILL LEARN ABOUT CURRENT THREATS TO NATURAL RESOURCES.  THE PROJECT FULFILLS THE PUBLIC PURPOSE OF ENGAGING UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND PARTNERS IN A TECHNICAL RESEARCH PROJECT THAT IS EXPECTED TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY. RESEARCHERS INVOLVED WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH PROJECT ACTIVITIES. RESULTS FROM RESEARCH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO OUR KNOWLEDGE OF THE HISTORY AND CURRENT CONDITIONS OF RAINBOW BRIDGE NATIONAL MONUMENT. INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE SHARED THROUGH A VARIETY OF STRATEGIES TO INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF RAINBOW BRIDGE NATIONAL MONUMENT.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO FINISH COLLECTING VISITOR DATA IN REMAINING KEY LOCATIONS WITHIN THE SOUTH RIM, INCLUDING DESERT VIEW BY 1) ESTABLISHING PATTERNS OF VEHICULAR AND PEDESTRIAN VISITOR FLOW, AND 2) INFORMING CURRENT AND DESIRED VISITOR EXPERIENCES. AT AREAS OF CONCERN INCLUDING: MATHER CAMPGROUND, SHOSHONE POINT, GRANDVIEW POINT AND TRAIL, LIPAN POINT AND TANNER TRAIL, DESERT VIEW WATCHTOWER, AND DESERT VIEW DRIVE. BOTH THE EVALUATIVE DATA AND DESCRIPTIVE DATA WILL BE PAIRED TO UNDERSTAND VISITOR PERCEPTIONS AS WELL AS ACTUAL BEHAVIORS WITHIN GRCA. BRYOPHYTES (MOSSES AND LIVERWORTS) ARE AN OFTEN OVERLOOKED ECOSYSTEM COMPONENT THAT PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN SOIL DEVELOPMENT, NUTRIENT CYCLING, MOISTURE REGULATION, MICROFAUNA HABITAT, AND ECOSYSTEM DIVERSITY. THIS IS ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT IN THE HIGH BIODIVERSITY AREAS OF THE APPALACHIAN BLUE RIDGE PROVINCES. THIS PROJECT WILL INVENTORY BRYOPHYTES IN SELECT ROCK OUTCROPS AND WATERFALLS STREAMS AND COMPARE HEAVILY VISITED SITES TO SITES WITH LOW VISITATION TO HELP THE PARK PROTECT THESE SENSITIVE RESOURCES. B.FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE (FOLA) IS KNOWN TO HAVE AN ACTIVE MATERNITY COLONY OF UP TO SEVERAL THOUSAND LITTLE BROWN BATS (MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS  MYLU) THAT ARE SUSCEPTIBLE TO WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME (WNS). THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WNS, PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS (PD) WAS DETECTED ON BATS AT FOLA IN 2018, AND IN 2022 WNS WAS CONFIRMED. CURRENTLY, THE ONLY PD-INFECTED MYLU POPULATION IN THE WEST THAT IS BEING MONITORED IS AT FOLA. THE MAJORITY OF MYLUS ROOST IN A MANMADE BAT CONDOMINIUM THAT WAS INSTALLED DURING PRIOR EFFORTS TO EXCLUDE BATS FROM THE MANY HISTORIC BUILDINGS IN THE FORT. FOLA PRESENTS THE IDEAL SETTING FOR MONITORING A WESTERN COLONY OF MYLU THROUGHOUT THE EPIDEMIC PHASES OF WNS (FROM FIRST DISCOVERY OF PD TO PROGRESSION OF ANTICIPATED DISEASE, ALTHOUGH THIS IS YET TO BE SEEN IN THIS COLONY). IT IS ALSO AN OPPORTUNITY TO ASSESS POPULATION CHANGE, AND THE IMPORTANCE OF MANMADE ROOST STRUCTURES FOR CONSERVING COLONIAL ROOSTING BAT POPULATIONSBENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).FOR MORE INFORMATION AND GUIDANCE, REFER TO NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY GUIDANCE DOCUMENT ON USASPENDING.GOV AWARD DESCRIPTIONS (PROJECT ABSTRACTS), OR CONTACT THE NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE

RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO UNDERSTANDING THE FUNCTIONING AND HABITAT PROVISIONING PROVIDED BY THE SNAKE RIVER FLOODPLAIN AND TRIBUTARY FLOODPLAINS (E.G., PACIFIC CREEK AND BUFFALO FORK) FOR PLANTS AND WILDLIFE. THE WORK WILL INCLUDE ASSESSING ECOGEOMORPHIC COMPLEXITY OVER TIME ON THE SNAKE RIVER FLOODPLAIN AND TRIBUTARIES. GEOMORPHIC COMPLEXITY (I.E., HETEROGENEITY) IS A CONCEPT THAT DESCRIBES THE VARIABILITY OF DIFFERENT GEOMORPHIC UNITS, WHICH ARE PATCHES ON THE LANDSCAPE THAT CAN BE CLASSIFIED BY PHYSICAL AND ECOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS, SUCH AS GRAIN SIZE, VEGETATION ASSEMBLAGE, OR ELEVATION ABOVE THE RIVER CHANNEL. GREATER GEOMORPHIC COMPLEXITY, FOR EXAMPLE WITHIN THE SNAKE RIVER FLOODPLAIN IN GRANT TETON NATIONAL PARK, PROVIDES A GREATER NUMBER OF DIFFERENT HABITAT TYPES FOR BOTH PLANTS AND WILDLIFE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES DETERMINE CHANGE IN THE EXTENT AND DIVERSITY OF FLOODPLAIN ECOGEOMORPHIC UNITS OVER TIME ON THE SNAKE RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES, USING HISTORICAL AERIAL IMAGERY, LIDAR DATASETS, AND RECENT SATELLITE IMAGERY COMPLETE FIELDWORK TO SURVEY FLOODPLAIN DOWNED WOOD LOADS IN THE SNAKE RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIESCOMPLETE FIELDWORK TO SAMPLE FLOODPLAIN SOIL TO DETERMINE SOIL CARBON CONTENT OF ECOGEOMORPHIC UNITS ON THE SNAKE RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIESCONTRIBUTE TO BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF RIVER CORRIDOR (CHANNEL AND FLOODPLAIN) DYNAMICS WITHIN GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK AND THE IMPACTS OF FLOW REGULATION ON THE SNAKE RIVER FLOODPLAINPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES SEE ABOVE DESCRIPTION OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED AND REVIEWED.THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS ON FUTURE HYDROLOGIC AND GEOMORPHIC MONITORING RELATED TO THE SNAKE RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES. ANTICIPATED INFORMAL DISCUSSIONS HELD ANNUALLY, WITH FINAL RECOMMENDATIONS PROVIDED IN THE FINAL REPORT.THE BULK OF THE WORK WILL LIKELY BE DONE OVER COURSE OF 2 3 YEARS, WITH MULTIPLE MANUSCRIPTS PUBLISHED AS A PART OF RESEARCH AND STUDY.BENEFICIARIES GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, BUREAU OF RECLAMATION, WYOMING GAME AND FISH, TETON CONSERVATION DISTRICT, US FOREST SERVICE, TROUT UNLIMITED, PUBLIC RECREATIONISTS, US GEOLOGIC SURVEY,

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT)  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE A LEVEL II SOILS MAP OF THE VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE (VALL). TO ADDRESS THE GOAL, NMSU AND NPS STAFF WILL CONDUCT EXTENSIVE SURVEYS OF UPLAND FORESTED VOLCANIC DOMES WITHIN VALL, IDENTIFY AND DESCRIBE SOIL PROFILES, AND CONDUCT SOIL CONSTITUENT ANALYSES (TEXTURE, ORGANIC MATTER, NUTRIENTS AS APPROPRIATE). NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY FACULTY AND STAFF, AND NPS STAFF, WILL THEN WORK CLOSELY WITH USDA NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS) STAFF TO INTEGRATE THIS FIELD WORK INTO A SOILS MAP, WHICH WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE NRCS PUBLIC ON LINE SOIL MAPPING WEBPAGE, THAT CAN BE USED BY LAND MANAGERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES  NMSU SOIL SCIENTISTS WILL EXPAND AND REFINE EXISTING VALL SOIL MAPS USING DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES IN THE UPLANDS OF VALL. THE DATA COLLECTED AND THE MAPS PRODUCED WILL BE DELIVERED TO COLLABORATING SCIENTISTS WITH THE NRCS WHO WILL THEN CREATE THE FINAL SOIL MAP FROM THE COLLECTED DATA AND PUBLISH THE MAP ON THE NRCS PUBLIC WEBSITE. NMSU SCIENTISTS WILL STRATIFY THE UPLAND AREAS INTO THREE SUB AREAS BASED ON GEOLOGICAL HISTORY  RHYOLITIC CERRO S, THE RESURGENT DOME, AND THE CALDERA RIM. WITHIN EACH SUB AREA, THEY WILL DEVELOP A STRATIFIED SAMPLING DESIGN USING THE EXISTING VALL MAPPING, CLIMATE DATA, EXISTING GEOLOGY MAPS, AND GEOSPATIAL ENVIRONMENTAL COVARIATES ASSUMED TO APPROXIMATE SOIL FORMING FACTORS. FIELD SAMPLING WILL BE CONDUCTED WITHIN EACH STRATUM TO CHARACTERIZE THE SOILS THAT OCCUR. FIELD SAMPLING AND LABORATORY ANALYSIS WILL BE USED TO CREATE MAPS OF SOIL CLASSES. VALIDATION SAMPLING WILL THEN BE PERFORMED TO ASSESS MAP ACCURACY. DATA ARE DELIVERED TO NRCS FOR MAP PROCESSING. LEVEL II SOILS MAP OF VALL WILL BE COMPLETED AND PUBLISHED ON THE NRCS PUBLIC WEBSITE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE FIELD WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED DURING SPRING SUMMER FALL OF 2023 AND 2024, AND THE VALL SOILS MAP WILL BE PUBLISHED ON THE NRCS SOILS WEB SITE, AND A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE END OF 2025. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) MAPS (INCLUDING ELECTRONIC GIS DATA ILLUSTRATING SOIL SAMPLING LOCATIONS) AND A DETAILED SUMMARY OF THE SURVEY RESULTS. COPIES OF FIELD NOTES (SCANS) AND DIGITAL PHOTOS TAKEN DURING THE SURVEYS ALSO WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE PRESERVE.BENEFICIARIES  THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES WILL BE NPS STAFF AT VALL, WHO WILL RECEIVE INFORMATION ON DIFFERENT SOIL TYPES TO ASSIST WITH PLANNING FOR TRAILS AND ROAD MAINTENANCE AND CONSTRUCTION, ALONG WITH POST FIRE REHABILITATION PLANNING.

TARGETS FOR FISHING EFFORT ARE INCLUDED IN THE NATIVE FISH CONSERVATION PLAN  HOWEVER, RESULTS FROM POPULATION MODELS THAT PROVIDE THESE TARGETS CHANGE AS NEW DATA ARE INCORPORATED. PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT)  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE A SURVEY OF WATERFOWL (DUCKS, GEESE, WADING BIRDS, SHOREBIRDS) ALONG ALL THE STREAMS, PONDS AND WETLANDS OF VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE. TO ADDRESS THE GOAL, HAWKS ALOFT STAFF WILL CONDUCT EXTENSIVE SURVEYS TO DEVELOP A LIST OF WATERFOWL SPECIES INHABITING THE PRESERVE, ADDING TO THE ALL TAXA BIOLOGICAL INVENTORY CURRENTLY UNDERWAY, IDENTIFYING THE PARTICULAR HABITATS FOR EACH SPECIES, AND DETERMINING WHETHER OR NOT THE SPECIES IS A BREEDING RESIDENT SPECIES ON THE PRESERVE (E.G., PRESENCE OF NESTS, NESTLINGS, FLEDGLINGS AND IMMATURES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES  HAWKS ALOFT STAFF WILL CONDUCT WATERFOWL SURVEYS DURING THE BREEDING SEASON (APRIL THROUGH JULY) VIA GROUND LEVEL OBSERVATIONS ACROSS THE PRESERVE IN LOCATIONS WHERE SUITABLE HABITAT EXISTS FOR WATERFOWL AND WHERE BREEDING COULD OCCUR. THE PRESERVE HAS NUMEROUS PONDS AND STREAMS THAT COULD SUPPORT WATERFOWL AND POTENTIALLY HOST BREEDING ACTIVITIES, DEPENDING ON ANNUAL WATER AVAILABILITY. ADDITIONALLY, RIPARIAN RESTORATION EFFORTS HAVE OCCURRED IN MULTIPLE LOCATIONS ON THE PRESERVE, AND WATERFOWL SURVEY EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON THOSE AREAS TO ASSESS THEIR IMPACT.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  THE FIELD WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED DURING SPRING SUMMER FALL OF 2023, AND A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE END OF THE YEAR. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE GIS MAPS (INCLUDING ELECTRONIC GIS DATA ILLUSTRATING MONITORING LOCATIONS AND A DETAILED SUMMARY OF THE SURVEY RESULTS. A COMPREHENSIVE LIST OF ALL BIRD AND WILDLIFE SPECIES OBSERVED ALSO WILL BE INCLUDED AS AN APPENDIX. COPIES OF FIELD NOTES (SCANS) AND DIGITAL PHOTOS TAKEN DURING THE SURVEYS ALSO WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE PRESERVE. NO SPECIMENS WILL BE COLLECTED.BENEFICIARIES  THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES WILL BE NPS STAFF AT VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE, WHO WILL RECEIVE INFORMATION ON WATERFOWL HABITATS AND BREEDING AREAS TO ENHANCE WETLAND MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. SECONDARY BENEFICIARIES WILL BE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, WHO ARE ALWAYS INTERESTED IN SPECIES DIVERSITY (ESPECIALLY PUBLIC BIRD ENTHUSIASTS).

CESUSSUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. THIS PROJECTAIMS TO LEVERAGE A UNIQUE, MULTI SEASON DATASET OF      FIELD MEASURED SNOW CHARACTERISTICS AND VEGETATION ATTRIBUTES DERIVED FROM      LONG TERM MONITORING PLOTS TO (1) EXAMINE HOW VEGETATION COMMUNITY      DEVELOPMENT INFLUENCES THE ACCUMULATION AND PERSISTENCE OF THE WINTER      SNOWPACK AT MULTIPLE SCALES, AND (2) EXPLORE HOW SNOWPACK CHARACTERISTICS      MAY AFFECT ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION IN THE SUBARCTIC. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDESTATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO FACILITATE MULTI DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. TO MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE NETWORK COOPERATIVE STUDY UNITS AS WILL PROVIDE FULL GEOGRAPHIC AND TOPICAL COVERAGE FOR RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE RESOURCES CONTAINED IN UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR LARGER REGIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES  WE WILL INVESTIGATE THE EFFICIENCY AND ACCURACY OF THREE NON INVASIVE, SURVEY METHODS TO ASSESS OCCUPANCY AND OR ABUNDANCE OF SPECIES OF CONCERN (SOC) ON STREAMS IN GNP. OUR PRIMARY FOCUS WILL BE ON HARLEQUIN DUCKS (HADU)  SECONDARILY, WE WILL LOOK AT OTHER WATERBIRDS CONSIDERED SOC LIKE BARROW S GOLDENEYES (BAGO) AND GREAT BLUE HERONS (GBHE). THE THREE METHODS INCLUDE CAMERA TRAPS, ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA), AND GROUND SURVEYS. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT A COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS OF EACH OF THESE SURVEY METHODS ALONE, AND OR USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH EACH OTHER. BASED ON DATA COLLECTED USING THE BEST METHOD(S), WE WILL BUILD OCCUPANCY MAPS FOR HADU THROUGHOUT GLACIER NATIONAL PARK (GNP).PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WE WILL COMPARE THREE NON INVASIVE SURVEY METHODS FOR THREE SPECIES OF WATERBIRDS ON STREAMS AT GLACIER NATIONAL PARK TO DETERMINE WHICH METHOD IS THE MOST COST EFFECTIVE WE WILL NOTE WHICH STREAMS ARE USED BY WHICH SPECIES AND THE ABUNDANCE OF EACH SPECIES ON THOSE STREAMS WE WILL BUILD OCCUPANCY MAPS FOR HADU.BENEFICIARIES  STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).
