THE PROJECT WILL ADD TO THE SUFFRAGIST STORIES STORY MAP AND GIS RESOURCE THE BIOGRAPHICAL, GEOGRAPHICAL, AND CORRESPONDENCE RECORDS OF SOME 600 AFRICAN AMERICAN SUFFRAGISTS THAT SUPPORTED THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE 19TH AMENDMENT TO THE US CONSTITUTION  THE SUFFRAGIST STORIES APP WAS DEVELOPED AND IS MAINTAINED BY TOWSON UNIVERSITY, OUR CESU PARTNER SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIESTHE PROJECT KNITS TOGETHER THE LETTERS AND WRITINGS, PLACES, AND PEOPLE THAT WERE FORMATIVE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE 19TH AMENDMENT  THE COOPERATOR WILL WORK WITH MORGAN STATE UNIVERSITY AND COMMUNITY HISTORIANS TO USE NETWORK AND GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS EXPERTISE AND CAPACITY OF ITS STUDENTS AND FACULTY TO RESEARCH AND ADD CONTENT FOR THE SOFTWARE APPLICATION  IN ADDITION, TOWSON S STUDENTS AND FACULTY WILL DEVELOP A COLLEGE LEVEL CURRICULUM THAT USES THE APP AND DATASET TO EXPLORE AFRICAN AMERICAN INTERSECTIONS WITH THE SUFFRAGE MOVEMENT PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES A RESOURCE THAT INCORPORATES DATA FROM OUR PARTNERS AT THE RADCLIFFE SCHLESINGER LIBRARY, THE ALEXANDER STREET PROJECT, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE TO REVEAL CONNECTIONS BETWEEN AFRICAN AMERICAN PROPONENTS OF THE SUFFRAGE MOVEMENT AND OTHER MOVEMENT SUPPORTERS, AND LINKS THEM TO THE SITES, PEOPLE, AND ARTIFACTS TO MORE FULLY REFLECT THE STORY OF THE SUFFRAGE MOVEMENT IN THE UNITED STATES INTEGRATION OF THIS WORK INTO THE TEACHING AND SOCIAL RESEARCH PROGRAMS AT TOWSON BY SUPPORTING STAFF AND STUDENTS FIRST HAND EXPERIENCE FOR STUDENTS WORKING WITH NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT CULTURAL RESOURCES ACROSS PARTNER INSTITUTIONS A LEGACY CURRICULUM PROJECT THAT SUPPORTS THE SURVIVAL OF THE PUBLIC HISTORY CONTENT INTO THE FUTURE BENEFICIARIES MORGAN STATE FACULTY AND STUDENTS, TOWSON UNIVERSITY FACULTY AND STUDENTS, VIRTUAL AND PHYSICAL VISITORS TO NATIONAL PARKS, NATIONAL HISTORIC LANDMARKS AND NATIONAL REGISTER SITES WITHIN THE SUFFRAGIST STORIES NETWORK

THE COORDINATING GROUP ON ALIEN PEST SPECIES  CGAPS  IS A COLLABORATIVE OF STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND NON GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS WORKING TO CLOSE GAPS IN KNOWLEDGE, POLICY, LAW, AND PUBLIC AWARENESS RELATED TO THE PREVENTION, DETECTION, RAPID RESPONSE, AND LONG TERM CONTROL OF TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES IN HAWAII  TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, CGAPS STAFF FACILITATES INFORMATION SHARING AND IMPLEMENTS COLLABORATIVE PROJECTS THAT ADVANCE THE 2025 JOINT STRATEGY FOR THE HAWAII INVASIVE SPECIES COUNCIL  HISC  AND CGAPS  CGAPS STAFF ALSO PROVIDES CAPACITY AND EXPERTISE TO ASSIST PARTNERS IN ADDRESSING SHARED PRIORITIES  ALTHOUGH PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON HAWAII, CGAPS ALSO WORKS ON INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUES AT NATIONAL AND REGIONAL LEVELS, INCLUDING BY CO FOUNDING OF THE PACIFIC REGIONAL INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE MANAGEMENT NETWORK, WHICH STRIVES TO BUILD A COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE TO RESEARCH AND COMMUNICATE THE SYNERGISTIC EFFECTS OF THESE TWO CHANGE DRIVERS  THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE HAS BEEN A CGAPS PARTNER FOR DECADES AND ENGAGES IN CGAPS MEETINGS AND PROJECTS, AND PROVIDES FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE CGAPS PROGRAM MANAGER TO CONTINUE THE CRITICAL ROLE OF CGAPS

THIS TASK AGREEMENT PROVIDES FUNDING TO SUPPORT 1 FULLTIME GIS SPECIALIST AND 1 LANDSCAPE ECOLOGY INTERNS FOR 12 WEEKS TO CREATE MAPS OF NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION PARKS THAT UNITE ECOLOGICAL AND GEODIVERSE FEATURES TO INFORM PARK MANAGEMENT CLIMATE CHANGE PRIORITIES  THIS WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT EVERY PARK IN THE REGION  IT IS KNOWN THAT PUBLIC LANDS OFFER IMPROVED RESILIENCY AND OVERALL WELLBEING TO HUMANS DURING NATURAL DISASTERS  BUT IT IS NOT KNOWN WHICH ECOLOGICAL FEATURES OF PUBLIC GREEN SPACE CONFER WELLBEING THIS PAID INTERNSHIP PROGRAM GIVES GIS EXPERIENCE AT THE LANDSCAPE LEVEL IN PARK RESOURCES  ALL THE REGIONAL PARKS WILL BE ORGANIZED INTO LANDSCAPE BLOCKS WITH THE ASSOCIATED CHARACTERISTICS THAT MAY ENHANCE VISITORS  WELLBEING AND RESILIENCY  EXAMPLES OF POTENTIAL WELLBEING CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDE VISUAL  E G , SCENIC VISTAS AND GREEN TREES , AURAL  E G , WATERFALLS AND BIRDSONG , AND PERSONAL SIGNIFICANCE  E G , CULTURALLY IMPORTANT LOCATIONS, COMMUNITY VALUES   THIS IS THE FIRST STEP TO IDENTIFY PARK LOCATIONS WITH ENHANCED AND UNIQUE VALUES AND PROVIDE INSIGHTS TO HELP PRIORITIZE PARK FEATURES FOR PROTECTION AGAINST CLIMATE CHANGE LOSS GIS AND LANDSCAPE ECOLOGY INTERNS WILL USE DIVERSE DATA LAYERS AND DATASETS  E G , TOPOGRAPHIC, LANDSCAPE USE, FOREST COVER, WATER FEATURES, VISTAS, BIRD WATCHING SITES  FOR PARKS  INTERNS WILL NETWORK WITH SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS AND EXPLORE THE PARKS, EXPERIENCING THEM AS A VISITOR WOULD WHILE BUILDING STEWARDSHIP VALUES INTERNS WILL PRESENT THEIR IDEAS, ACCEPT GUIDANCE AND FEEDBACK, DRAFT MATERIALS, SUBMIT DRAFTS FOR REVIEW BY SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS, REVISE PRODUCTS, PRESENT FINAL DRAFTS TO PARK UNITS, MAKE FINAL EDITS, AND SUBMIT MATERIALS TO PARK MANAGEMENT BENEFICIARIES  UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND

CUBAN RANCHOS OF THE FLORIDA CENTRAL GULF COAST   THIS PROJECT IS A HISTORIC AND PALEOGEOGRAPHIC STUDY THAT WILL PRODUCE A SCHOLARLY SYNTHESIS ABOUT THE CUBAN RANCHOS IN CENTRAL GULF COAST OF FLORIDA  THE STUDY WILL GIVE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING ABOUT THE PEOPLE THAT OCCUPIED THE RANCHOS AND THE INTERACTIONS THEY HAD WITH OTHER POPULATIONS  BECAUSE DE SOTO NATIONAL MONUMENT WAS A LIKELY LOCATION OF ONE OF THE RANCHOS, THE STUDY WILL HELP THE PARK DEVELOP INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS THAT WILL BETTER REFLECT THE HISTORY OF THE PLACE  THE NEW INFORMATION THAT WILL BE PUBLISHED WITH THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL BE INSTRUMENTAL IN EDUCATING THE LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND PARK VISITORS ABOUT THIS CRUCIAL COMMUNITY AND INDUSTRY ON FLORIDA S GULF COAST  IT WILL FURTHER PARK CONNECTIONS IN THE AFRO CUBAN COMMUNITIES AND INCREASE INCLUSION WITH THE PARK STORY AND MISSION  A DRAFT REPORT IS DUE BY MARCH 1, 2024, AND THE FINAL REPORT BY JUNE 30, 2024

PURPOSE OF AWARD THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT COMMUNITY EFFORTS TO DOCUMENT, PROTECT, PRESERVE, AND INTERPRET IMPORTANT RESOURCES WITH A VERIFIABLE CONNECTION TO THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD  THESE PROJECTS WILL LEVERAGE ADDITIONAL INVESTMENT IN UNDERGROUND RAILROAD RESOURCES AND WILL SUPPORT THE WORK OF COMMUNITY GROUPS, NON PROFITS, AND STATE OR LOCAL GOVERNMENTS IN PRESERVING AND INTERPRETING THEIR HISTORIC RESOURCES SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES THIS PROJECT WILL COMPETITIVELY FUND RESEARCH, INTERPRETATION, AND PRESERVATION PROJECTS BY SITES, INTERPRETIVE OR EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, OR RESEARCH FACILITIES THAT HAVE A VERIFIABLE CONNECTION TO THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD AS DEMONSTRATED BY REVIEW AND ACCEPTANCE AS MEMBERS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE  NPS  NETWORK TO FREEDOM  ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST COMMUNITIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO DEVELOP DOCUMENTATION ON NEW SITES PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES   SEPT  2002 SEPT  2024 1  THE RECIPIENT AND NPS WILL DEVELOP PARAMETERS FOR THE CALL FOR PROPOSALS AND REVIEW AND RANK PROPOSAL SUBMITTED  ENTER INTO AGREEMENTS WITH SELECTED ENTITIES 2  ADMINISTER PROJECTS WITH NPS 3  PUBLICIZE THE PROJECTS THROUGH VARIOUS SOURCES IN ORDER TO DISSEMINATE INFORMATION ON THE EFFORTS TO PRESERVE AND COMMEMORATE THE HISTORY OF THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD BENEFICIARIES THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL HAVE ACCESS TO NEW RESEARCH AND INTERPRETATION OF THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD  ADDITIONALLY, SITE STEWARDS, NON PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS AND COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT BY HAVING THEIR EFFORTS TO PRESERVE AND INTERPRET THEIR HISTORY SUPPORTED BY FUNDING AND RELATED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE AWARD WILL ASSIST THE NPS IN GARNERING COMMUNITY INPUT REGARDING ITS MANAGEMENT OF RESOURCES ASSOCIATED WITH ENSLAVEMENT AT THE BOWMAN HITE HOUSE, INCLUDING AN ARCHEOLOGICAL SITE INTERPRETED AS AN OUTBUILDING KITCHEN THAT MAY ALSO HAVE SERVED AS A DWELLING FOR AFRICAN AMERICANS ENSLAVED THERE  ULTIMATELY, THE GOAL IS THE IDENTIFICATION OF A FREE STANDING DESCENDANT BODY THAT WILL INFORM THE QUESTIONS PURSUED BY ARCHAEOLOGISTS AND INTERPRETATIONS OF THE SITE SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES COLLEGE OF WILLIAM AND MARY PERSONNEL AND STUDENTS WILL PERFORM A PROGRAM OF BACKGROUND RESEARCH ADEQUATE TO ENGAGE MEMBERS OF THE DESCENDANT COMMUNITY IN PUBLIC DISCOURSE AROUND TOPICS RELATED TO ARCHEOLOGY, HISTORY, ENSLAVEMENT, AND EMANCIPATION    A REPORT THAT FULLY DOCUMENTS THE OUTCOMES WILL BE COMPLETED AND SUBMITTED TO THE PARK PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE COOPERATOR WILL WORK WITH THE NPS TO PRODUCE A COMMUNICATION PLAN EARLY IN THE PROJECT S DURATION  THE COOPERATOR WILL ALSO PRODUCE AND FACILITATE, WITH PARK INPUT, A SERIES OF PUBLIC OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT EVENTS DESIGNED TO ELICIT COMMUNITY INPUT BENEFICIARIES THE PUBLIC PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE FULFILLED  BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR VOLUNTEERS, STUDENTS, PROFESSIONALS, AND  MEMBERS OF THE PUBLIC TO PARTICIPATE IN CRITICAL DIALOGUE AROUND CEBE S  ARCEHOLOGICAL RESOURCES  STUDENTS WILL BE DIRECTLY INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT,  GAINING EXPERIENCE WITH PARK BASED COMMUNITY CONSULTATION EFFORTS

PADRE ISLAND WIND TIDAL FLATS PILOT PROJECT   THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A PILOT STUDY AT PADRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE TO TEST RESTORATION TECHNIQUES FOR WIND TIDAL FLATS THAT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY VEHICLES TO IDENTIFY EFFECTIVE TECHNIQUES THAT CAN BE APPLIED BROADLY IN COASTAL AREAS OF TEXAS AND ADJACENT STATES  THE TEAM WILL TEST A RANGE OF TECHNIQUES TO GROW THE CYANOBACTERIA IN LARGE LABORATORY TANKS  MESOCOSMS  AND THEN USE THOSE CYANOBACTERIA TO TEST FIELD TECHNIQUES  BY TESTING VARIOUS TECHNIQUES, THE TEAM HOPES TO BE ABLE TO BOTH REMOVE THE TOPOGRAPHIC BLOCKAGES AND ESTABLISH THE CYANOBACTERIA  IF ACHIEVED THEN THE BASIS OF THE ECOSYSTEM WILL BE RE ESTABLISHED, AND THE SITE WILL ONCE AGAIN BE A CRITICAL SOURCE OF FOOD FOR MIGRATING BIRDS

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  UNDER THIS PROPOSED PROJECT, THE SAMUEL PROCTOR ORAL HISTORY PROGRAM  SPOHP  WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE  NPS  AND THE NATIONAL UNDERGROUND RAILROAD NETWORK TO FREEDOM  NTF  IN AN EFFORT TO GATHER, PRESERVE AND PROMOTE THE ORAL AND FAMILY TRADITIONS OF UNDERGROUND RAILROAD DESCENDANTS AND REPRESENTATIVES SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES SPOHP AND NTF WILL COORDINATE INTERVIEW SCHEDULING, TOPICS AND TRAVEL TO INTERVIEW LOCATIONS AND MODALITIES MOST CONVENIENT TO NARRATORS  INTERVIEWEES  SPOHP WILL CONDUCT, TRANSCRIBE AND EDIT THE ORAL HISTORIES IN A MANNER SUITABLE TO CREATING HIGH QUALITY DIGITAL VIDEO AND AUDIO RECORDINGS FOR POTENTIAL USE IN MUSEUM EXHIBITS, PODCASTS, RADIO DOCUMENTARIES, K 12 CURRICULUMS AND OTHER CONTEXTSPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES SPOHP WILL CONDUCT 40, ONE HOUR ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS WITH INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY THE NTF AND ITS MEMBERSSPOHP WILL PROVIDE COPIES OF THE TAPED AND TRANSCRIBED INTERVIEWS TO ALL INTERVIEWEES AND PROJECT CONTRIBUTORSSPOHP WILL UPLOAD ALL VIDEO ORAL HISTORY FOOTAGE TO YOUTUBE CHANNEL SPOHP111SPOHP WILL WORK WITH THE UF LIBRARIES TO DIGITIZE AND MAKE AVAILABLE ALL ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS AND TRANSCRIPTIONS FOR USE BY STUDENT AND FACULTY RESEARCHERS, DOCUMENTARIANS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WORLDWIDEBENEFICIARIES RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO NEW INFORMATION ABOUT THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD TO ENHANCE THEIR DOCUMENTATION, PRESERVATION, AND INTERPRETATION EFFORTS  DESCENDANT WILL HAVE PROFESSIONALLY CONDUCTED AND PRODUCED INTERVIEWS TO SHARE WITH THEIR UNIQUE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD HISTORY WITH THEIR FAMILIES AND FUTURE GENERATIONS

PROJECT TITLE   A MONITORING PROGRAM FOR THE AMERICAN CROCODILE IN EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARKAWARDPURPOSE   THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON INFORMATIONAL NEEDS ASSOCIATED WITH HYDROLOGICAL RESTORATION AND MODEL VERIFICATION  METRICS THAT RELATE CROCODILES TO HYDROLOGIC RESTORATION INCLUDE NESTING EFFORT AND SUCCESS, ESTIMATED ABUNDANCE, BODY CONDITION, AND GROWTH AND SURVIVAL  HATCHLING AND JUVENILE CROCODILE BODY CONDITION, ESTIMATED ABUNDANCE, GROWTH, AND SURVIVAL INCREASE WITH LOW TO MODERATE SALINITY LEVELS   20PPT   AND FEMALES GENERALLY SELECT NEST SITES AS CLOSE TO THESE HABITATS AS POSSIBLE  NEST DISTRIBUTION AND SITE SELECTION IN ENP HAS CHANGED WITH CHANGING SALINITY REGIMES  NESTING IN N E  FLORIDA BAY HAS SHIFTED TOWARD MAINLAND FRESHWATER SOURCES AND HAS NOT EXHIBITED THE UPWARD TREND OBSERVED IN THE CAPE SABLE REGION  ACTIVITIES TO BEPERFORMED  THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ASSESS NESTING EFFORT AND SUCCESS, GROWTH, SURVIVAL, DISTRIBUTION, ESTIMATED ABUNDANCE, AND BODY CONDITION OF AMERICAN CROCODILES IN NORTHEASTERN FLORIDA BAY FROM US1 TO AND INCLUDING MADEIRA BAY  IMPROVEMENTS TO WATER DELIVERY IN ENP, ESPECIALLY THOSE DESIGNED TO RESTORE FLOWS INTO TAYLOR SLOUGH  E G , C 111 CANAL PROJECTS  COULD IMPACT CROCODILES AND THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE CROCODILE RESPONSES TO THOSE HYDROLOGIC CHANGES

STATEMENT   THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE SOUTHEAST ARCHEOLOGICAL CENTER  SEAC  SERVES AS THE PRIMARY REPOSITORY FOR ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS FROM PARK UNITS IN THE NPS SOUTHEAST REGION  THE CENTER IS CHARGED WITH MANAGING OVER 9 MILLION ARTIFACTS AND OVER 700,000 ARCHIVAL DOCUMENTS FROM MORE THAN 60 PARK UNITS IN THE REGION  IT IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE CENTER MUSEUM STAFF TO MAINTAIN ACCOUNTABILITY, PROVIDE PRESERVATION AND PROTECTION, AND MANAGE RESEARCH ACCESS TO THESE COLLECTIONS FOR THE REGION S PARKS  THE PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THE REGION S COLLECTIONS PROVIDES CONTROL OF AND ACCESSIBILITY TO THE COLLECTIONS, PRESERVES THE COLLECTIONS, AND MAKES THEM AVAILABLE FOR RESEARCH AND FOR EXHIBITION  PARK CURATORIAL STAFF, PARK INTERPRETERS, PARK HISTORIANS, AS WELL AS PROFESSIONAL CURATORS AND HISTORIANS OUTSIDE OF THE SERVICE, EXTENSIVELY RESEARCH THE COLLECTIONS  THE PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THESE COLLECTIONS IS CENTRAL TO THE MISSION OF THE INDIVIDUAL PARK THE GOAL OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO WORK WITH ASALH TO CONDUCT A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY OF AFRICAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCES DURING THE CIVIL WAR AND RECONSTRUCTION AT MONOCACY JUNCTION AND MONOCACY NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD IN FREDERICK COUNTY, MARYLAND  THE HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY WILL EXPAND MONOCACY NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD S UNDERSTANDING OF HOW AFRICAN AMERICANS SHAPED THE MEANING OF FREEDOM ON AND AROUND THE BATTLEFIELD FROM THE CIVIL WAR INTO THE TWENTIETH CENTURY THE STUDY WILL DEVELOP ABASELINE DOCUMENTATION OF THE AFRICAN AMERICAN PEOPLE WHO LIVED, WORKED, AND ENLISTED ON AND NEAR MONOCACY NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD, AND DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE ON THE SOCIAL, CULTURAL, AND HISTORICAL CONNECTIONS BETWEEN DESCENDANT COMMUNITIES AND THE BATTLE OF MONOCACY  THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE NEW PRIMARY SOURCE RESEARCH ON AFRICAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCES AT MONOCACY THROUGH DOCUMENTARY RESEARCH AND PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES THE OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY, A CATALOG AND TRANSFER OF RESEARCH NOTES AND PRIMARY SOURCES, AND RECOMMENDATIONS AND CONTACTS FOR CONTINUED ENGAGEMENT WITH AFRICAN AMERICAN DESCENDANTS AND COMMUNITIES  MILESTONES WILL INCLUDE REVIEWS OF A PROJECT OUTLINE, PARTIAL AND FULL DRAFT REPORTS, AND PRESENTATIONS FOR KNOWLEDGE SHARING BENEFICIARIES  ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF AFRICAN AMERICAN LIFE AND HISTORY

THIS PROJECT WILL PRODUCE PROFESSIONALLY RESEARCHED AND PEER REVIEWED HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY  HRS  OF CONTEXT STUDY AND IN DEPTH CASE STUDIES RESULTING IN NEEDED BASELINE DOCUMENTATION ABOUT PEOPLE OF AFRICAN DESCENT DURING THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION  THE STUDY WILL PROVIDE A HISTORICAL OVERVIEW OF THE TOPIC THROUGH A REVIEW OF SECONDARY AND SOME PRIMARY SOURCES, AND IT WILL IDENTIFY CULTURAL RESOURCES THAT ARE RELEVANT TO HISTORIC CONTEXTS  THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE HRS IS ESSENTIAL FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE INTERPRETATION AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT  THIS HRS WILL BE A COMPREHENSIVE SYNTHESIS OF PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SOURCE MATERIAL

TO CONDUCT A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY OF AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORICAL EXPERIENCES ON AND NEAR THE LANDS THAT NOW MAKE UP GEORGETOWN WATERFRONT PARK IN WASHINGTON, DC  THIS STUDY WILL ASSIST THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE IN IDENTIFYING, PRESERVING, AND INTERPRETING PLACES AND STORIES ASSOCIATED WITH AFRICAN AMERICAN ENSLAVEMENT, LABOR, AND LIFE ON THE HISTORIC WATERFRONT THIS HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY WILL DEVELOP A NARRATIVE HISTORICAL REPORT AND ANALYSIS OF HISTORIC AND CONTEMPORARY MAPS  THE STUDY WILL INCORPORATE HISTORICAL RESEARCH ON ENSLAVEMENT AND SALE OF AFRICAN AMERICANS, THEIR LABOR AND CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE ECONOMY AND BUILT ENVIRONMENT OF GEORGETOWN, AND WAYS OF UNDERSTANDING CHANGES IN THE WATERFRONT LANDSCAPE AS WELL AS EXTANT HISTORIC RESOURCES THROUGH THE LENS OF AFRICAN AMERICAN EXPERIENCES THE MILESTONES AND OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE DRAFTS LEADING TO A COMPLETED HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY, MAPS SHOWING THE HISTORICAL EVOLUTION OF THE WATERFRONT IN PRINTABLE AND GEOSPATIAL FORMATS, AND AT LEAST ONE PRESENTATION WITH NPS STAFF, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND INTERESTED ORGANIZATIONS BENEFICIARIES  GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY

THIS PROJECT WILL USE AMINO ACID STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS OF EGGS TO ASSESS THE FOOD WEB OF A THE CAPTIVE AND WILD POPULATIONS OF ENDANGERED DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH WITHIN DEATH VALLEY NATIONAL PARK  PUPFISH EGGS ARE REGULARLY COLLECTED FROM BOTH DEVILS HOLE AND THE ASH MEADOWS FISH CONSERVATION FACILITY  AMFCF   THE EGGS ARE INCUBATED IN AQUARIA, BUT THOSE THAT DO NOT HATCH ARE RETAINED FOR FUTURE STUDY  A PROOF OF CONCEPT STUDY WILL DETERMINE WHETHER AMINO ACID STABLE ISOTOPES IN THE EGGS OF HYBRID PUPFISH MAINTAINED IN CAPTIVITY ARE REPRESENTATIVE OF THE POPULATION AS A WHOLE  PHASE I WILL DETERMINE WHETHER THIS METHOD IS VIABLE FOR USE WITH DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH AND HOW MANY EGGS ARE REQUIRED TO SUPPORT THE ANALYSES  IF PHASE I IS SUCCESSFUL, PHASE II WILL USE THE NOW PROVEN METHOD TO ASSESS THE FOOD WEBS OF THE TWO EXTANT POPULATIONS OF DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH  IN DEVILS HOLE AND IN THE AMFCF  CURRENT DATA FROM THE WILD POPULATION OF DEVILS HOLE PUPFISH WILL BE COMPARED TO DATA FROM PRESERVED SAMPLES TO IDENTIFY ANY CHANGES TO THE FOOD WEB OVER TIME

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THIS PROJECT WILL COLLECT AND IDENTIFY ETHNOHISTORICAL INFORMATION REGARDING NATIVE AMERICAN INVOLVEMENT IN THE SIEGE OF 1781  THIS PROJECT IS TIMELY AT THE 250TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTIONARY WAR  THE PARK HAS BEGUN EXPANDING THE STORIES IT TELLS VISITORS AND IS SEEKING OUT STORIES FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES WORK CONSISTS OF VISITING ARCHIVAL REPOSITORIES WITH KNOWN INFORMATION ON REVOLUTIONARY WAR SERVICE RECORDS AND LETTERS REGARDING NATIVE ENGAGEMENT IN THE WAR EFFORT AND FOLLOWING THROUGH WITH RECORDING THE PRESENCE AND ACTIVITIES OF THESE SOLDIERS AT YORKTOWN  ARCHIVES ARE IN PA, NY, MD, AND WASHINGTON D C PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS PROJECT WILL WORK WITH VIRGINIA TRIBES AND KNOWN HISTORIC ARCHIVAL REPOSITORIES IN NY, PA, MD, AND VA TO RECOVER THE STORIES OF VIRGINIA TRIBAL CITIZENS PARTICIPATING IN THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION AT YORKTOWN AND THEN WITH PERMISSION COLLECT THOSE STORIES FOR USE IN INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION FOR PARK STAFF BENEFICIARIES COLLEGE OF WILLIAM AND MARY, CHICKAHOMINY TRIBE, CHICKAHOMINY TRIBE EASTERN DIVISION, NANSEMOND NATION, NANTICOKE INDIANS, PAMUNKEY INDIAN TRIBE, RAPPAHANNOCK INDIAN TRIBE, CATAWBA NATION, UPPER MATTAPONI INDIANS, MATTAPONI INDIAN TRIBE  THE GENERAL PUBLIC

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO HAVE STUDENTS COLLABORATE WITH ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK STAFF TO COLLECT RELEVANT INFORMATION AND DATA TO ENSURE THE DEVELOPED INDICATORS AND THRESHOLDS ESTABLISHED FOR VISITOR USE MONITORING ARE RELIABLE AND ROBUST TO SUPPORT PARK MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  THIS WILL BE MET BY WORKING COLLABORATIVELY TO DEVELOP MONITORING PROTOCOLS FROM ESTABLISHED INDICATORS AND THRESHOLDS SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP VISITOR USE INDICATOR MONITORING PROTOCOLS, DEVELOP A SPATIALLY AND STATISTICALLY RELEVANT SAMPLING STRATEGY FOR EACH PROTOCOL, COLLECT BASELINE DATA TO TEST EACH INDIVIDUAL PROTOCOL, AND DEVELOP A DATABASE FOR LONG TERM DATA STORAGE AND MANAGEMENT PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES PROTOCOL AND DATABASE DEVELOPMENT WILL OCCUR IN FALL AND WINTER 2022 2023 WITH SUMMER 2023 BEING THE TIME TO COLLECT BASELINE AND TESTING DATA  THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT ARE INDIVIDUAL PROTOCOLS, SAMPLING STRATEGIES, AND DATABASES FOR EACH OF THE VISITOR USE INDICATORS BENEFICIARIES  BENEFICIARIES TO THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC, PARK VISITORS, AND STUDENTS INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT  THE PARK ALSO GAINS INFORMATION ABOUT VISITOR USE AND METHODS TO MONITOR THE EFFECT OF VISITOR USE ON A VARIETY OF PARK RESOURCES

CONDUCT A HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY OF SITES ASSOCIATED WITH PRE EMANCIPATION AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY ON LANDS THAT ARE NOW PART OF NATIONAL CAPITAL REGION PARKS  GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE SPECIALIZED RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION IN AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY AND GEOSPATIAL METHODS THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD ON THE SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING LITERATURE AND ASSESSMENT OF SITE DOCUMENTATION COMPLETED DURING PHASE I TO GENERATE IN DEPTH HISTORICAL RESEARCH AND MAPPING FOR SITES ASSOCIATED WITH ENSLAVEMENT  THIS PHASE II STUDY WILL FOCUS ON INDIVIDUAL CASE STUDIES OF PARK SITES WHERE HISTORIES OF ENSLAVEMENT ARE NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD OR NOT REFLECTED IN CURRENT BASELINE DOCUMENTATION  THE PROJECT WILL EXPAND HISTORICAL RESEARCH ON THESE SITES USING PRIMARY SOURCES TO RECOVER THE STORIES AND HUMANITY OF PEOPLE ENSLAVED THERE, AND TO LOCATE ASSOCIATED RESOURCES USING HISTORICAL AND MODERN MAPS  RESEARCH WILL BEGIN WITH PRIORITY SITES AND SEEK TO BUILD A MODEL FOR USE ACROSS THE REGION DRAFTS LEADING TO A COMPLETED HISTORIC RESOURCE STUDY, MAPS SHOWING THE HISTORICAL EVOLUTION OF SELECTED PARK LANDSCAPES IN PRINTABLE AND GEOSPATIAL FORMATS, AND A PRESENTATION OR WORKSHOP TO SHARE PROJECT FINDINGS BENEFICIARIES  GEORGE MASON UNIVERSITY, STUDENTS IN AFRICAN AMERICAN STUDIES AND DIGITAL HISTORY, THE SCHOLARLY RESEARCH COMMUNITY, NPS VISITORS

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE PURPOSE IS TO COLLABORATE ON PROCESSING AND ANALYZING WATER SAMPLES, AND INTERPRETING WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND SCIENCE IN THE REGION  CENTER FOR COASTAL STUDIES  CCS  STAFF WORK ALONGSIDE NPS RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS TO ANSWER ECOLOGICAL QUESTIONS, ADDRESS MANAGEMENT NEEDS AND PROVIDE INFORMATION TO PARK VISITORS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC  THIS STUDY WILL FURTHER THE UNDERSTANDING OF WATER RESOURCE HEALTH TO EASILY COMMUNICATE INFORMATION TO IMPROVE VISITOR EXPERIENCE AND SAFETY AND IMPROVE PARK STAFF S KNOWLEDGE SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES NPS IMPLEMENTS VARIOUS WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT IN LAKES AND COASTAL WATERS  CCS WILL ANALYZE WATER SAMPLES COLLECTED BY CAPE COD NATIONAL SEASHORE  CACO  NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT STAFF FOR WATER QUALITY CONSTITUENTS  THROUGH SCIENTIFIC COLLABORATION, THE WATER QUALITY ANALYSIS WILL BE PERFORMED TO ASSESS THE CONDITION AND INTEGRITY OF CACO WATER RESOURCES PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED THROUGH CLOSE COLLABORATION AMONG THE CCS INVESTIGATORS AND NPS SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS AT CACO  THIS COLLABORATIVE SCIENTIFIC ANALYSIS WILL LEAD TO A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF WATER QUALITY THROUGHOUT CACO AND PROVIDE UP TO DATE SCIENCE TO INFORM WATER RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE BENEFICIARIES BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE BOTH CACO AND THE CCS  BOTH ENTITIES BENEFIT FROM THE SYNERGY OF COLLABORATION TO PROCESS WATER QUALITY SAMPLES, ASSISTANCE PROVIDED TO EACH OTHER IN LABORATORY SUPPORT, AND PRODUCTIVE CONVERSATIONS THAT INFORM WATER QUALITY MANAGEMENT AND MITIGATION SOLUTIONS ACROSS THE REGION

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND CHANGES AND ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS IN FRAGILE ALPINE ENVIRONMENTS AND PROVIDE SCIENTIFICALLY CREDIBLE INFORMATION NEEDED TO MANAGE THESE AREAS IN PARK UNITS OF THE NORTHERN ROCKIES THIS PROJECT COOPERATIVELY MONITORS ALPINE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES IN ROCKY MOUNTAIN NETWORK NATIONAL PARKS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THEY MAY OR MAY NOT BE CHANGING OVER THE LONG TERM  IT IS PART OF A GLOBAL NETWORK OF ALPINE MONITORING SITES AND INCLUDES SITES IN ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK, GREAT SAND DUNES NATIONAL PRESERVE, AND YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK  WE MONITOR THE COMPOSITION OF ALPINE PLANT COMMUNITIES  AND THE SOILS THAT SUPPORT THEM  IN THESE PARKS IN COOPERATION WITH THE COLORADO NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AT COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY BENEFICIARIES  PARK STAFF AND VISITORS

PROJECT STATEMENT   THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE LONG TERM ECOLOGICAL STATUS AND TRENDS OF SEAGRASS COMMUNITIES AT DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARK, DISSEMINATES DATA THAT INFORMS NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATES THE PUBLIC, AND FACILITATE COLLABORATION AND RESEARCH CONDUCTED BY ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS ON FEDERAL LANDS PERFORMANCE GOALS   DEVELOP DRAFT CORAL RESTORATION AND SEA TURTLE MANAGEMENT PLANS  USING THESE DOCUMENTS, ASSIST THE NPS WITH THE COMPLETION OF THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ACT S  NEPA  ANALYSIS OF THE PROPOSED FEDERAL ACTIVITIES AND DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS FOR CONSIDERATION  DEVELOPMENT OF THESE DOCUMENTS WOULD BE BASED ON EXISTING DOCUMENTS, INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDER INPUT, AND MANAGEMENT REVIEW AND APPROVAL PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES   REVIEW PERTINENT LITERATURE, MATERIALS, AND CONSULT WITH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STAKEHOLDERS TO UNDERSTAND CURRENT AND PROPOSED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AT DRTO  SYNTHESIZE THIS INFORMATION INTO COMPREHENSIVE DRAFT MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR REVIEW BY NPS STAFF  ASSIST NPS STAFF WITH THE SUBMISSION, REVIEW, AND COMPLETION OF THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION ACT S  NEPA  ANALYSES OF THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES  ENGAGE WITH STAKEHOLDERS WHO PROVIDE REGULATORY CONSULTATION AND COMMENT DURING THE NEPA REVIEW PROCESS AND INCORPORATE AND OR ADDRESS INPUT RECEIVED  DEVELOP FINALIZED ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTS FOR CONSIDERATION  WORK WITH NPS STAFF TO ULTIMATELY ACHIEVE APPROVAL FOR THE DEVELOPED MANAGEMENT PLANS AND ASSOCIATED ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENTSMILESTONES  N AASSISTANCE LISTING   TITLE   BENEFICIARIES15 945   COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS   RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS  INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO QUANTIFY AND COMPARE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL TRENDS IN FOREST BIRD SPECIES WITHIN EASTERN US NATIONAL PARKS AND THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE  THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT ANALYSES TO UNDERSTAND HOW OCCURRENCES OF FOREST DEPENDENT BIRD SPECIES VARY ACROSS NATIONAL PARKS AS WELL AS ACROSS THE BROADER LANDSCAPE AND ADDRESS HOW SUCH VARIATION RELATES TO PARK SIZE, VARIATION IN CLIMATE, AND LANDSCAPE CONTEXT SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES THE PROJECT WILL CONDUCT ANALYSES OF LONG TERM FOR BIRD MONITORING COMMUNITY DATA TO EVALUATE CHANGES IN THE FOREST BIRD COMMUNITY OVER TIME AMONG 33 EASTERN PARK UNITS  THE ANALYSES WILL DETERMINE HOW CHANGES IN CLIMATE, FOREST HEALTH, AND LAND USE AFFECT FOREST BIRD OCCURRENCE IN PARKS TO INFORM MANAGEMENT PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES PERIODIC MEETINGS TO REVIEW LONG TERM DATA AND MODEL DEVELOPMENT, PUBLICATIONS DESCRIBING THE RESULTS OF THE MAIN PROJECT GOALS, AND SUMMARY TABLES AND FIGURES FROM THE ANALYSES BENEFICIARIES THE OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK WILL INCREASE THE PUBLIC AND SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY S KNOWLEDGE OF HOW OF HOW A VARIETY OF LOCAL AND REGIONAL STRESSORS AFFECT THE CONDITION OF EASTERN PARK S FOREST BIRD COMMUNITIES WHICH WILL ALSO RELATE TO THE OVERALL FOREST HEALTH IN THESE PARKS  THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP ETHICS IN ITS PARTICIPANTS INCLUDING THE GREATER PUBLIC AND YOUTH

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE PURPOSE OF THE AWARD IS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT STRATEGY THAT WILL INFORM COMPREHENSIVE EQUITY DECISION MAKING AND HELP ENHANCE SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGE EFFORTS FOR SAND CREEK REGIONAL GREENWAY  SCRG  AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES   CAPTURE DIVERSE PERSPECTIVES, CONCERNS, IMPACTS, AND EXPERIENCES AND THE DIFFERENT NEEDS OF COMMUNITIES FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION  DEVELOP STRATEGIES TO ENGAGE WITH DIVERSE COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, GROUPS, AND INDIVIDUALS  IDENTIFY STAKEHOLDER WHO MAY BE INTERESTED IN INCREASING COMMUNITY INTEREST AND USE OF OUTDOOR SPACES   PLAN, ORGANIZE AND FACILITATE A SERIES OR MULTIPLE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT MEETINGS OR LISTENING SESSIONS  REPORT FINDINGS TO SAND CREEK REGIONAL GREENWAY PARTNERSHIP  SCRGP  STAFF AND BOARD MEMBERS PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES RESULTS OF THE COMMUNITY INFORMED ENGAGEMENT EFFORT INCLUDE REDUCTION OF BARRIERS TO HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS TO INCREASE THE USE OF THE GREENWAY AND PARTICIPATION IN SCRGP PROGRAMS, REDRESS INEQUITIES IN EXISTING SCRGP POLICIES AND PROGRAMS, AND IMPROVEMENT OF EQUITABLE DELIVERY OF RESOURCES AND BENEFITS OF THE GREENWAY AND THE SCRGP  DENVER UNIVERSITY  CENTER FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT  WILL PREPARE A FINAL REPORT THAT SUMMARIZES THE COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT PROCESS AND FEEDBACK BENEFICIARIES   STUDENTS AT DENVER UNIVERSITY  CENTER FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT  COLORADO METRO AREA

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO INCREASE AND ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE OF HOW UTAH S NATIVE AMERICAN PEOPLES EXPERIENCE D  AND PERCEIVE D  THE NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAILS AND BUILD LONG TERM COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS THE AMERICAN WEST CENTER  AWC  WILL REACH OUT TO STAKEHOLDERS IN THE UTAH AMERICAN INDIAN COMMUNITY, STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, AND THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE TO FORM AN INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WHOSE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE INTEGRATION OF NATIVE PERSPECTIVES ON THE UTAH PORTIONS OF THE PONY EXPRESS, MORMON PIONEER, AND CALIFORNIA NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAILS  THE TEAM WILL ARTICULATE A SHARED VISION STATEMENT AND PROJECT GOALS, WHICH WILL THEN GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN THAT WILL IMPLEMENT THE ACTIONS NEEDED TO MEET THOSE GOALS AND ACHIEVE THAT VISION BY SEPTEMBER 15 2022, AWC WILL SUBMIT TO NATIONAL TRAILS THE LIST OF PROPOSED INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM MEMBERSBY OCTOBER 15, 2022 AWC AND NATIONAL TRAILS WILL MEET TO DISCUSS PROPOSED LISTBY MARCH 1, 2023, THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL PRODUCE DRAFT VISION STATEMENT AND PROJECT GOALSBY JUNE 1 2023 THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL PRODUCE DRAFT PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN, WHICH WILL INCLUDE THE FINAL VISION STATEMENT AND PROJECT GOALSBY JULY 15 2023 THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL PRODUCE FINAL PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLANBY AUGUST 15, 2023 THE INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL MEET TO DISCUSS NEXT STEPS FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN BETWEEN SEPT  15, 2023 AND MAY 15, 2024, HOLD MONTHLY VIRTUAL MEETINGS WITH INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM TO DISCUSS AND KEEP INFORMED OF IMPLEMENTATION PROGRESS BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE TRIBAL PARTNERS, UNIVERSITY OF UTAH GRADUATED STUDENTS  THROUGH THE AMERICAN WEST CENTER , AND NATIONAL TRAILS

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO ESTIMATE THE DENSITY OF COYOTES IN CAPE COD NATIONAL SEASHORE, AND TO GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE BROAD DISTRIBUTION AND OCCUPANCY PATTERNS OF THE SPECIES  THE ESTIMATED POPULATION SIZE AND DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION IS ESSENTIAL FOR DEVELOPING APPROACHES TO MANAGE COYOTES INCLUDING THE DEVELOPMENT OF A LETHAL PREDATOR CONTROL STRATEGY TO SUPPORT FEDERALLY PROTECTED SHOREBIRD SPECIES SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE  1  SURVEYING AND COLLECTION OF COYOTE SCATS TO DOCUMENT PATTERNS OF PRESENCE AND INDIVIDUAL SPACE USE  2  GENOTYPING SCATS TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS  3  DEVELOPING A SPATIAL CAPTURE RECAPTURE MODEL TO ESTIMATE DENSITY  4  DEVELOPING AN OCCUPANCY MODEL TO ESTIMATE DISTRIBUTION AND EFFECTS OF LANDSCAPE FACTORS ON OCCURRENCE PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES A FINAL REPORT THAT WILL DOCUMENT AND DISCUSS IMPLICATIONS OF COYOTE ABUNDANCE AND PRESENCE AT CAPE COD NATIONAL SEASHORE AND WHETHER PARK MANAGEMENT WILL NEED TO REMOVE COYOTES IN ORDER TO PROTECT NATIVE SHOREBIRD NESTING AREAS BENEFICIARIES THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE INVENTORY PROGRAM, INVENTORY AND MONITORING DIVISION, NRSS CAPE COD NATIONAL SEASHORE  NPS PARK UNIT

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  AS VISITATION PATTERNS SHIFT BEYOND TRADITIONAL SEASONAL PEAKS AND VISITOR NUMBERS BREAK NEW ANNUAL RECREATION VISITS, PARK MANAGERS MUST BE INFORMED REGARDING HOW INCREASED VISITOR PRESSURES IMPACT CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES  THIS PROPOSED RESEARCH FOCUSES ON YELL VISITOR IMPACTS TO WOLF BEHAVIORS AND VISITOR EXPERIENCES AS THEY PERTAIN TO WOLVES STUDY PURPOSE AND  OBJECTIVESTHE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO DEVELOP DIRECT MEASURES OF HUMAN IMPACTS UTILIZING MULTIPLE SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL INDICATORS   THE FOLLOWING RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE PROPOSED RESEARCHERS WILL ANALYZE HOW DATA INFORM FUTURE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF VISITORS, WILDLIFE VIEWING COMPANIES, EDUCATIONAL GROUPS, AND OTHER LOOSELY ORGANIZED WOLF ENTHUSIASTS  RESEARCHERS WILL BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL PATTERNS OF VISITOR USE AS IT PERTAINS TO WOLF VIEWING IN YELLOWSTONE SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES UTILIZATION OF PARK VISITOR USE AND ECOLOGICAL DATA FOR A SOCIO ECOLOGICAL MODELPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THIS RESEARCH HAS TWO MAJOR OUTCOMES  FIRST, SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL PATTERNS OF VISITOR USE PERTAINING TO WOLF WATCHING WILL BE IMPORTANT TO WILDLIFE ECOLOGISTS CONCERNED ABOUT THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF VISITOR BEHAVIOR ON WOLF POPULATIONS  SECOND, THE SOCIAL SCIENCE DATA COLLECTED FROM THIS EFFORT WILL INFORM HOW THOSE VISITORS COULD BE MANAGED IN ORDER TO ALIGN VISITOR BEHAVIORS WITH WOLF CONSERVATION GOALS BENEFICIARIES PARK MANAGERS, WOLVES, VISITORS, PUBLIC

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO GAIN BASIC INFORMATION ABOUT BAT SPECIES PRESENCE, DISTRIBUTION, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, AND WHETHER WHITE NOSE SYNDROME IS PRESENT IN ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES THIS PROJECT WILL ASSESS BAT SPECIES DIVERSITY, COMPOSITION, RELATIVE ABUNDANCE, OCCUPANCY, AND ACTIVITY AT ROOST SITES AND CONDUCT PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS  PD  SURVEILLANCE IN THESE AREAS  IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL ACOUSTICALLY SAMPLE LOCATIONS THAT REPRESENT THE RANGE OF HABITATS AND ELEVATIONS AVAILABLE IN ROMO WHILE OPERATING WITHIN THE CONTINENT WIDE FRAMEWORK ESTABLISHED BY NABAT PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES 1  CONFIRM THE PRESENCE ABSENCE OF ROOSTING BATS AT 40 STRUCTURES AND INCREASE THE NUMBER OF KNOWN ROOSTS IN ROMO FROM PRE PROJECT LEVELS 2  ESTABLISH BASELINE CONDITIONS FOR BAT SPECIES DIVERSITY AND DISTRIBUTION ACROSS HABITATS AND ELEVATION GRADIENTS  UPDATE THE PARK SPECIES LIST 3  ESTABLISH BASELINE CONDITIONS AT THREE OR MORE ROOSTS 4  SAMPLE BATS AT ROOSTS TO ESTABLISH WEATHER PD IS PRESENT ABSENT  DETERMINE SEX AND REPRODUCTIVE STATUS OF BATS CAPTURED BENEFICIARIES 1  THE PARK WILL BENEFIT BY GAINING BASELINE INFORMATION REGARDING BATS, INCLUDING THEIR USE OF PARK STRUCTURES 2  THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT THROUGH ADDITIONAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES REGARDING THE BATS AT ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK AND THEIR HABITATS 3  THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WILL BENEFIT FROM UNDERSTANDING THE UPPER ELEVATIONAL EXTENT OF SPECIES THAT HAVE BEEN NOT STUDIED AT THE TOP OF THEIR RANGES  IN ADDITION, RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS WILL BENEFIT FROM ADDITIONAL PD TESTING AND RESULTS FROM COLORADO WHERE WHITE NOSE SYNDROME HAS NOT BEEN DOCUMENTED

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A STUDENT INTERN TO JOIN THE AIR RESOURCES DIVISION IN DEVELOPING AND UPDATING EDUCATIONAL AIR AND VISUAL RESOURCES CONTENT FOR USE IN INTERNAL COMMUNICATIONS AND ON PUBLIC NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WEBPAGES. AIR RESOURCES STAFF WILL MENTOR THE INTERN IN LEARNING A VARIETY OF AIR QUALITY RELATED TOPICS AND IN DEVELOPING COMMUNICATION PRODUCTS. THE INTERN WILL DEVELOP WEBPAGES, FACTSHEETS, REPORTS, AND MAPS TO COMMUNICATE THE EFFECTS OF AIR POLLUTION UPON NATURAL RESOURCES AND VISITOR EXPERIENCES IN NATIONAL PARKS.

RAPID INCREASE OF URBAN DEVELOPMENTS ALONG THE BOUNDARIES OF TULE SPRINGS FOSSIL BEDS (TUSK) CONTRIBUTES TO AIR POLLUTION IN TUSK. THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY PLANTS SENSITIVE TO AIR POLLUTION AND SPATIAL PATTERNS OF AIR POLLUTION AT TUSK.PHASE I WILL LOCATE AIR POLLUTION-SENSITIVE PLANTS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL AREAS OF HIGH AIR POLLUTION IMPACT ON NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE PARK. IN PHASE II, SELECTED PLANT SPECIES WILL BE TARGETED FOR EVALUATION OF AIR POLLUTION DAMAGE ON PLANT HEALTH AND POLLINATION, AND AIR POLLUTION EFFECTS WILL BE VERIFIED BY FUMIGATING SELECTED PLANTS WITH OZONE.THE INVESTIGATORS WILL BUILD A DATABASE FOR USE BY THE PARK THAT INCLUDES GEOSPATIAL DATA, PLANT AND OBSERVATION DATA, AND PREPARE A TECHNICAL REPORT ON THEIR FINDINGS. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL ASSIST THE PARK IN FUTURE MANAGEMENT OF PLANT SPECIES AND WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS FOR FUTURE CITIZEN SCIENCE OUTREACH PROJECTS AT THE PARK.

PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT  IN SUPPORT OF A PENDING MAINTENANCE PROJECT, THE HISTORIC STRUCTURE REPORT  HSR  WILL PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE DOCUMENTATION REGARDING THE EVOLUTION OF THE GRANARY STRUCTURES AT MISSION SAN JOSE  THE REPORT WILL EVALUATE THEIR CURRENT CONDITION, POSSIBLE CAUSES FOR DETERIORATION, AND TREATMENT GUIDELINES  THE HSR IS THE PRIMARY GUIDE TO THE ORIGIN, MODIFICATION, TREATMENT AND USE OF THE CULTURAL RESOURCE THIS HSR WILL SUPPORT FUTURE PRESERVATION EFFORTS AND REPAIR OF THE SAN JOSE GRANARY BY PROVIDING DOCUMENTATION ON CRITICAL AREAS OF DETERIORATION, RECOMMENDATIONS FOR REPOINTING, INCLUDING MORTAR MIX FORMULAS BASED ON HISTORIC MORTAR ANALYSIS, AND PROVIDING DETAILED MEASUREMENTS FOR CONSTRUCTION DOCUMENTS THIS HSR IS EXTREMELY IMPORTANT TO THE SAN ANTONIO MISSIONS NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK  THE SPANISH COLONIAL GRANARY AT MISSION SAN JOSE IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT NOT ONLY FOR ITS HIGH CULTURAL AND HISTORIC VALUE, BUT ALSO FOR ITS STATUS AS ONE OF THE PRIMARY EVENT VENUES IN THE PARK, USED FOR FRIENDS GROUP DINNERS, TEMPORARY ART DISPLAYS, MUSIC VENUES, AND OTHER TYPES OF PROGRAMS THE GRANARY IS ONE OF THE STRUCTURES THAT IS INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIED AS NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT IN THE NATIONAL REGISTER LISTING AND IS PART OF THE ENABLING LEGISLATION FOR THE PARK  THE GRANARY IS AN INTERNATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT COMPONENT OF THE PARK AND WAS CALLED OUT AS ONE OF THE DEFINING CHARACTERISTICS FOR THE OUTSTANDING UNIVERSAL VALUE FOR THE 2015 WORLD HERITAGE DESIGNATION OF THE SAN ANTONIO MISSIONS  UNESCO 39COM 8B 34   IN ADDITION, THE GRANARY PLAYS AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CONSERVATION MOVEMENT IN SAN ANTONIO AND THE PRESERVATION OF ALL OF THE MISSIONS  IT WAS THE FIRST STRUCTURE AT THE MISSIONS PURCHASED BY THE SAN ANTONIO CONSERVATION SOCIETY TO PREVENT ITS DEMOLITION IN THE 1920S SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES THE HSR WILL FOLLOW THE FORMAT DESCRIBED IN DO 28 AND THE RECOMMENDED GUIDELINES OF NPS PRESERVATION BRIEF 43, THE PREPARATION AND USE OF HISTORIC STRUCTURE REPORTS  THE DOCUMENT WILL INCLUDE LARGE SCALE SURVEY MAPS AND DRAWINGS SHOWING CONDITION ASSESSMENT  THE SURVEY MAPS AND DRAWINGS WILL BE PRODUCED USING A COMBINATION OF THE FOLLOWING  PHOTOGRAMMETRY, AUTOCAD AND AGISOFT, AND LIDAR  THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE THOROUGHLY RESEARCHED, LOGICAL, AND FEASIBLE OPTIONS FOR LONG TERM CARE OF THE MISSION SAN JOSE GRANARY STRUCTURES IN FULL COMPLIANCE WITH THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR S STANDARDS FOR THE TREATMENT OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE HSR WILL FOLLOW THE OUTLINE PROVIDED IN PRESERVATION BRIEF 43  MILESTONES WILL FOLLOW THE GUIDELINES IN THE PRESERVATION BRIEF INCLUDING A DEVELOPMENTAL HISTORY, TREATMENT AND WORK RECOMMENDATIONS  THERE WILL BE A SERIES OF MEETINGS WITH CLIENT, THE PUBLIC, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AT THE BEGINNING AND AT THE DRAFT STAGE FOR COMMENTS  THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE A COMPLETED HSR FOR NPS, PUBLIC, AND STAKEHOLDER CONSUMPTION AVAILABLE IN A 508 COMPLIANT ELECTRONIC DOCUMENT ON THE PARK WEBSITE BENEFICIARIES PARK STAFF, VISITORS TO THE PARK WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION OF THE GRANARY, STUDENTS AND PRESERVATIONISTS WHO CAN USE THE DOCUMENT FOR OTHER RESEARCH AND DESCENDANTS OF THE MISSIONS WHO CAN SEE THE TANGIBLE ELEMENTS OF THEIR HISTORY PRESERVED CORRECTLY
GENOTYPING TO BUILD A PEDIGREE FOR BROOK TROUT FROM STANLEY BROOK, ACADIA NATIONAL PARK

NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROJECT ABSTRACTCOMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PROJECT PROPOSES AN EVALUATION OF THE EXISTING TRAIL CIRCULATION NETWORK IN THE CUMBERLAND ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE AS A FOUNDATIONAL ANALYSIS AND REVIEW OF EXISTING AND NEW DATA TO IDENTIFY EXISTING ISSUES AND POTENTIAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVING VISITOR EXPERIENCE, REDUCING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS, AND PROVIDING FOR MORE SUSTAINABLE MAINTENANCE WITHIN THE PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:PROJECT WILL ASSESS AND ANALYSIS THE TRAIL SYSTEM AND ITS IMPACT ON LOCAL ECOSYSTEMS AS WELL AS EVALUATE ITS USE AND IMPACT FROM VISITORS. THE PROJECT WILL COMBINE GIS AND TRADITIONAL FIELDWORK METHODOLOGIES TO MAP AND DEVISE A TRAIL SYSTEM THAT IS COMPATIBLE WITH THE DIFFERENT ECOSYSTEMS OF CUMBERLAND ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1. COMPILING AND REVIEWING RELEVANT EXISTING GIS AND OTHER AVAILABLE DATA FOR THE PARK INCLUDING EXISTING VEGETATION, NATURAL COMMUNITIES, FOCAL SPECIES HABITAT, TRAILS, PRIVATE PROPERTIES, ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES, AREAS IMPORTANT FOR FIRE MANAGEMENT, HYDROLOGY, SOILS AND OTHER READILY AVAILABLE DATA.2. COLLECTING ADDITIONAL DATA THROUGH ON-SITE VISITS AND COMMUNICATION WITH PARK STAFF TO DOCUMENT EXISTING ENVIRONMENTAL, USER, AND MAINTENANCE RELATED ISSUES, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ON IMPORTANT VISITOR EXPERIENCES, VIEWSHEDS, DESTINATION POINTS, AND SITES THAT SHOULD BE EXCLUDED FROM USE BY OUTSIDE VISITORS.3. EVALUATING THE EXTENT AND TIMING OF POTENTIAL SEA LEVEL RISE RISKS FOR THE PARK AND EXISTING CIRCULATION NETWORK.4. SYNTHESIZING NEW AND EXISTING DATA TO CONDUCT A SUITABILITY ANALYSIS THAT EVALUATES OPPORTUNITIES AND CONSTRAINTS FOR BOTH FUTURE PEDESTRIAN AND VEHICULAR CIRCULATION NETWORKS, INCLUDING IDENTIFYING AREAS OF HIGH ECOLOGICAL VALUE OR SENSITIVITY, AREAS IMPORTANT FOR USER EXPERIENCE, AREAS AT RISK FROM SEA LEVEL RISE, AND AREAS THAT PROVIDE CONSTRAINTS FOR LONG TERM SUSTAINABLE MAINTENANCE.5. COMPARING THE EXISTING CIRCULATION NETWORK TO AREAS OF HIGH AND LOW SUITABILITY TO HIGHLIGHT POTENTIAL ISSUES AND CONCERNS, AND DISCUSS OPPORTUNITIES AND RECOMMENDATIONS. THESE RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE COMPILED IN COORDINATION AND WITH INPUT FROM CUMBERLAND ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE STAFF AND MAY BE USED IN FUTURE PROJECT PHASES TO IDENTIFY PRIORITY LOCATIONS FOR REALIGNMENT OR REDESIGN OF THE EXISTING CIRCULATION NETWORK.ASSISTANCE LISTING - TITLE - BENEFICIARIES15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEPLOYING ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS TO SURVEY FOR BATS IN PETROGLYPH NATIONAL MONUMENT. RECORDERS WILL BE PLACED IN 10 LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT THE MONUMENT TO HELP THE PARK BETTER UNDERSTAND BAT PRESENCE AND RELATIVE ACTIVITY LEVELS IN KEY AREAS. THE ACOUSTIC DATA WILL BE ANALYZED USING SPECIALIZED SOFTWARE TO IDENTIFY BAT SPECIES WITH HIGH ACCURACY AND PRECISION. INFORMATION FROM THIS STUDY WILL HELP PETROGLYPH CONSIDER POTENTIAL IMPACTS ON BAT SPECIES FROM IMPLEMENTING PLANNED MANAGEMENT ACTIONS AND PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND ALLOW THEM TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS AND/OR MITIGATION MEASURES TO AVOID ADVERSE IMPACTS TO BATS BASED ON THE FINDINGS.EQUIPMENT WILL BE DEPLOYED IN FALL 2022 AND WILL RUN FOR ONE YEAR. IN FALL-WINTER OF 2023-2024, DATA WILL BE PROCESSED AND ANALYZED. FINAL RESULTS IN 2024 WILL INCLUDE A REPORT OUTLINING THE METHODS AND DISCUSSING THE IMPLICATIONS OF BAT PRESENCE AND ACTIVITIES IN KEY AREAS OF THE MONUMENT. THE MONUMENT STAFF CAN THEN USE THIS INFORMATION TO INFORM MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.

USE WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THESE SPECIFICATIONS WILL CONTINUE TO SERVE THE BROADER PARKS, RECREATION AND MUSEUM PROFESSIONS AND THE CRITICAL, COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS THAT SUPPORT THE PROJECT STATEMENT - THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE AN INVENTORY OF DEER POPULATION AT VICKSBURG NATIONAL MILITARY PARK. RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT FIELD WORK TO COLLECT PELLET SAMPLES AND VISUAL SURVEYS OF DEER. THE DNA ANALYSIS OF PELLETS USING LAB MICROSATELLITE TECHNIQUES TO IDENTIFY UNIQUE INDIVIDUALS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A CALIBRATION COEFFICIENT FOR VISUAL SURVEY CROSS-REFERENCING.PERFORMANCE GOAL - CONDUCT A DEER VISUAL SURVEY AND DEER PELLET SAMPLING TO ESTIMATE CURRENT DEER POPULATION AND DEVELOP A SPATIAL CALIBRATION COEFFICIENT TO SUPPORT INDIRECT ESTIMATION OF DEER POPULATION DENSITIES FROM THOSE FUTURE VISUAL SURVEYS.  PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES -DETERMINE AND DOCUMENT PRESENCE/ABSENCE, ABUNDANCE, AND DISTRIBUTION OF WHITE-TAILED DEERESTIMATE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE (PELLET COLLECTION AND/OR EDNA)ESTIMATE WHITE-TAILED DEER POPULATION SIZEDEVELOP A CALIBRATION COEFFICIENT FROM PELLET AND VISUAL SURVEYSSHARE RESULTS WITH PARK RESOURCE STAFF AND THE LARGER COMMUNITY VIA A REPORT MILESTONES  SEMESTER/YEAR?TASK?FALL 2022?PLAN FIELD WORK. HIRE FIELD TEAM?WINTER 2023?TRAIN THE FIELD TEAM IN THE RESEARCH PROTOCOL. PURCHASE   AND PREPARE FIELD SUPPLIESWINTER AND SPRING 2022/2023CONDUCT FIELD WORKSUMMER 2023?ENTER / QC DATA. CONDUCT DATA ANALYSIS. DRAFT   REPORT.FALL 2023?FINALIZE DATA PRODUCTS. COMPLETE AND SUBMIT   REPORT.BENEFICIARIES: MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY

NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROJECT ABSTRACTCOMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS MULTI-YEAR PROJECT WILL ALLOW FOR A PROGRAM OF HERITAGE DOCUMENTATION AND DIGITAL TWIN CREATION, THREE-DIMENSIONALLY RECORDING PRECISE STRUCTURAL AS-BUILTS AND CREATING LANDSCAPE GEOSPATIAL MAPPING APPLICATIONS TO PRODUCE HIGH-RESOLUTION RECORDS OF CURRENT CONDITIONS.THIS PROGRAM WILL ESTABLISH A HISTORIC BUILDING INFORMATION MANAGEMENT (HBIM) HERITAGE APPROACH TO MONITOR THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND TRANSFORMATION PROCESSES AT CUMBERLAND ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE, AND BE USED TO ASSIST IN PLANNING, MANAGEMENT, INTERPRETATION, AND RESTORATION. EXISTING GIS AND RELEVANT INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE SYNTHESIZED AND BROUGHT TOGETHER AS PART OF A GIS APPROACH TO DATA MANAGEMENT AND VISUALIZATION, ALLOWING FOR EFFICIENT TOOL AND APPLICATION DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, AND MAINTENANCE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:USE OF TERRESTRIAL LASER SCANNING AND STRUCTURED LIGHT SCANNING, ADVANCED IMAGING AND VIRTUALIZATION TECHNOLOGIES, AND GPS SURVEY WORK TO CAPTURE EXTANT REMAINS AT THE NPS CUIS. COMPLETE A SPATIAL AND 3D DOCUMENTATION INVENTORY, WITH GIS WEB APPLICATIONS, VIRTUAL COLLECTIONS AND TOURS, AND 3D MODELS AND VISUALIZATIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:KICK-OFF MEETING AND SITE SELECTION, ORDER OF OPERATIONAL DECISIONS- COLLABORATIVE WITH NPS CUISFIELD OPERATIONS SELECTED AS FIRST OPERATION ORDER WILL BEGIN DATA MINING, LITERATURE AND BACKGROUND REVIEW, AND GIS GEODATABASE DEVELOPMENT.YEAR 1 FIELD AND PROCESSING OPERATIONS YEAR 2: SELECTION OF SITES, FEATURES, ARTIFACTS.YEAR 3: FIELD OPERATIONS SELECTED AS FIRST OPERATION ORDER WILL BEGIN DATA MINING, LITERATURE AND BACKGROUND REVIEW, AND GIS GEODATABASE DEVELOPMENT. FINAL REPORT AND WORKSHOP: A COMPREHENSIVE DOCUMENT THAT REPORTS ON THE PROJECT OUTCOMES, WITH ALL AREAS OF DATA CAPTURE AND ANALYSES DISCUSSED. WORKSHOP WILL SHARE RESULTS AND ALLOW FOR IMPLEMENTATION AND USE PLANNING AND DISCUSSION AND DEMONSTRATIONS.BENEFICIARIES: ASSISTANCE LISTING -15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PROVIDE NATIVE AND LOCALLY SOURCED PLANTINGS NECESSARY TO RESTORE THE AREA AROUND THE LIND POINT PROJECT THAT WAS DAMAGED DURING HURRICANES IRMA/MARIA. THESE NATIVE PLANTS WILL PROVIDE EROSION CONTROL, HELP PREVENT INVASIVE PLANT INFESTATIONS, AND OFFER INTERPRETATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE PROJECT AREA.THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE PROPAGATION OF 1,202 CONTAINER PLANTS, DELIVERY OF PLANTS TO THE PROJECT SITE, WORKSHOPS/FIELD DAYS FOR EDUCATORS TO TEACH YOUTH ABOUT NATIVE PLANTS/PROPAGATION, DEVELOPMENT OF NATIVE PLANT INTERPRETIVE GUIDES, AND REPORT ON NATIVE PLANT PROPAGATION TECHNIQUES.THROUGH THE PROPAGATION OF THESE PLANTS, INTERNS AND STUDENTS SHALL LEARN ABOUT ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION, LOCAL PLANT SPECIES, AND HORTICULTURAL PRACTICES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO DETERMINE THE GENETIC PURITY AND OVERALL GENETIC DIVERSITY OF BONNEVILLE CUTTHROAT TROUT POPULATIONS IN THE WEST DESERT AND THE SURROUNDING AREA. THIS INFORMATION WILL AID STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES IN MAKING SOUND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.GREAT BASIN NATIONAL PARK WILL COLLECT AND SUPPLY FIN CLIPS. BRIGHAM YOUNG UNIVERSITY WILL ANALYZE THE FIN CLIPS TO DETERMINE PERCENT INTROGRESSION WITH RAINBOW TROUT AND OTHER CUTTHROAT SPECIES AND DETERMINE THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF EACH POPULATION. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE PRODUCED. BENEFICIARIES ARE BRIGHAM YOUNG UNIVERSITY.

THIS PROJECT ENGAGES SAMOAN YOUTH AT THE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL LEVEL WITH SWIMMING AND SNORKELING ACTIVITIES  OBJECTIVES INCLUDE 1  TEACHING ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS HOW TO SWIM AND SNORKEL, 2  INCORPORATING NPS STAFF, 3  PROVIDING MENTORSHIP OPPORTUNITIES, AND 4  APPRECIATING MARINE AREAS

THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE ON JOSHUA TREE WOODLAND COMMUNITIES, SPECIFICALLY THE SURVIVORSHIP OF EASTERN JOSHUA TREES AND BANANA YUCCAS. THE QUANTITIVE DATA RECORDED AT EACH SITE WILL BE POST-FIRE REGROWTH RESPONSES, COVER, HEIGHT AND DENSITY OF BOTH YUCCA SPECIES AT 18 SITES WITHIN THE DOME FIRE FOOTPRINT. THESE SITES ARE LOCATIONS PREVIOUSLY ESTABLISHED AND SURVEYED FOR HERBACEOUS VEGETATION DENSITY, AND THAT ARE REPRESENTED IN PRE- AND POST-FIRE PHOTOS. CENSUSES WILL BE CONDUCTED IN FALL 2022 AND SPRING 2023. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SYNTHESIZED AND A PUBLICLY-ACCESSIBLE ARCGIS STORYMAP WILL BE POSTED TO THE PRESERVE'S WEBSITE IN SUMMER 2023.

HISTORIC PRESERVATION SERVICES (HPS) WILL PARTNER WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA'S DEPARTMENT OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION TO DEVELOP PROFESSIONAL INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMERGING PROFESSIONALS INTERESTED IN ENHANCING THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE IN: CULTURAL LANDSCAPES AND HISTORIC STRUCTURES; TECHNICAL APPROACHES TO RESOURCE PRESERVATION (RELATED TO PRESERVATION ENGINEERING, HISTORICAL ARCHITECTURE, AND ARCHITECTURAL CONSERVATION); AND THE PEDAGOGY OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION THEORY AND PRACTICE, INCLUDING APPLICABLE LAWS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:EMERGING PROFESSIONALS/PROFESSIONAL INTERNS WILL ENGAGE IN A VARIETY OF SPECIAL PROJECTS FOCUSED ON THE PRESERVATION DOCUMENTATION OF DIVERSE CULTURAL LANDSCAPES AND HERITAGE ARCHITECTURE IN THE LEGACY INTERMOUNTAIN REGION (DOI REGIONS 6,7,8) THROUGH THE HPS PROGRAM. PROJECTS WILL BE DESIGNED TO BUILD TECHNICAL SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE IN PARTICIPATING EMERGING PROFESSIONALS. PROFESSIONAL INTERNS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO PROJECT SCOPING, HISTORICAL RESEARCH, COMPLETION OF CONDITION ASSESSMENTS, DETERMINATIONS OF CAUSALITY, DEVELOPMENT OF TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS, WRITING OF PROJECT REPORTS (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO CULTURAL LANDSCAPE INVENTORIES), AND, IN SOME CASES WHERE MAY BE FEASIBLE, ASSIST IN THE APPLICATION OF RECOMMENDED PRESERVATION TREATMENTS IN ORDER TO IMPROVE RESOURCE CONDITIONS AND BUILD TECHNICAL FIELD SKILLS. ALL WORK WILL BE DONE ALONGSIDE HPS AND NPS TECHNICAL EXPERTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE HISTORIC PRESERVATION SERVICES (HPS) PROGRAM PROPOSES TO CONTINUE AN EXISTING PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA'S DEPARTMENT OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION TO DEVELOP PROFESSIONAL INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR EMERGING PROFESSIONALS INTERESTED IN ENHANCING THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND PRACTICE.EMERGING PROFESSIONALS/PROFESSIONAL INTERNS WILL COMPLETE SPECIAL PROJECTS IN THE AREAS OF CULTURAL LANDSCAPES AND HISTORIC STRUCTURES DOCUMENTATION, DIRECT AND OVERSEE THE COMPLETION OF DOCUMENTS ASSOCIATED WITH HERITAGE RESOURCES, AND WILL RECEIVE PROFESSIONAL TRAINING IN PRESERVATION TECHNOLOGY AND PRESERVATION LAW THROUGH DISCUSSION AND FORMAL SEMINARS AS MAY BE RELEVANT.BENEFICIARIES:EMERGING PROFESSIONALS IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION
CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT - SECURITY OF PARK WATER SUPPLIES

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE WHAT ELEMENTS ARE MOST COMMONLY LINKED TO MORE POSITIVE OUTCOMES FOR VISITORS FROM LIVE AND AUDIENCE-CENTERED INTERPRETIVE EXPERIENCES IN THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE.PROJECT OBJECTIVES -DEVELOP MEASURES THAT REFLECT CONSENSUS-BASED OUTCOMES THAT APPLY BROADLY TO LIVE INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS AND OTHER AUDIENCE-CENTERED EXPERIENCES ACROSS THE NPS. CONDUCT FIELD RESEARCH TO DETERMINE WHICH APPROACHES TO LIVE INTERPRETATION ARE MOST POWERFULLY LINKED WITH DESIRED VISITOR OUTCOMES.CONDUCT FIELD RESEARCH TO DETERMINE WHICH APPROACHES TO AUDIENCE-CENTERED EXPERIENCES ARE MOST POWERFULLY LINKED WITH DESIRED VISITOR OUTCOMES.DETERMINE WHETHER CERTAIN APPROACHES ARE CONTEXT-SPECIFIC. IN OTHER WORDS, DO DIFFERENT APPROACHES RELATE TO OUTCOMES DIFFERENTLY IN DIFFERENT CONTEXTS (E.G., CULTURAL VS. NATURAL FOCUS; URBAN VS. REMOTE PARKS) OR DIFFERENT AUDIENCES (E.G., DIFFERENT SOCIODEMOGRAPHIC PROFILES)?SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:SPECIFIC RESEARCH PHASESPHASE 1 (AUGUST 2022 - MAY 2024): THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CONDUCT A PARTICIPATORY PROCESS, A PILOT STUDY AND STATISTICAL ANALYSIS TO DEVELOP MEASURES APPROPRIATE FOR EVALUATING THE OUTCOMES OF NPS INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS.PHASE 2 (AUGUST 2024 - SEPTEMBER 2026): THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DESIGN AND CONDUCT A RESEARCH STUDY OVER TWO FIELD SEASONS TO DETERMINE WHICH APPROACHES TEND TO LEAD TO MORE POSITIVE VISITOR OUTCOMES AND REPORT ON THE RESULTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROJECT DELIVERABLESINTERIM REPORTS: TWO INTERIM REPORTS WILL BE PRODUCED:  FIRST INTERIM REPORT: ONE ELECTRONIC VERSION OF AN INTERIM REPORT WILL HIGHLIGHT THE PROCESS, METHODS, AND RESULTS OF DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE MEASURES FOR ASSESSING OUTCOMES OF LIVE INTERPRETATION AND AUDIENCE CENTERED EXPERIENCES ACROSS THE NPS. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE READY-TO-USE SURVEY INSTRUMENTS.SECOND INTERIM REPORT: ONE ELECTRONIC VERSION OF AN INTERIM REPORT WILL SUMMARIZE THE FIRST FIELD SEASON, PROVIDE PRELIMINARY FINDINGS, AND SHARE SUGGESTED ADAPTATIONS FOR THE SECOND FIELD SEASON.DRAFT FINAL REPORT: ONE ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE DRAFT FINAL TECHNICAL REPORT WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE NPS FOR FEEDBACK.FINAL REPORT: THE FINAL REPORT WILL DETAIL ALL METHODS, ANALYSES, CONCLUSIONS, AND RECOMMENDATIONS. ONE ELECTRONIC VERSION WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE NPS AND ANOTHER TO THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNITS RESEARCH COORDINATOR.BENEFICIARIES: THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC, SPECIFICALLY ENSURING THAT THE OVER 300 MILLION ANNUAL VISITOR EXPERIENCES ARE ENJOYABLE, EDUCATIONAL, AND RELEVANT BY ASSISTING THE NPS IN EVALUATING AND IMPROVING CURRENT INTERPRETIVE EFFORTS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE ESTABLISHED RESEARCH METHODS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE NATIONAL INTERAGENCY VISITOR USE MONITORING FRAMEWORK TO ESTABLISH SPECIFIC INDICATORS AND THRESHOLDS FOR DESIRABLE RECREATION EXPERIENCES AT CARLSBAD CAVERNS NATIONAL PARK (CAVE) AND TIMPANOGOS CAVE NATIONAL MONUMENT (TICA).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:- THREE SPECIFIC PROJECT OBJECTIVES WILL GUIDE PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND LEAD TO THE ATTAINMENT OF THE PROJECT'S PERFORMANCE GOAL. THESE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE:IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE POTENTIAL INDICATORS THAT CHARACTERIZE VISITORS' EXPERIENCES.ESTABLISH QUANTITATIVE THRESHOLDS OF ACCEPTABILITY FOR PRIORITY INDICATORS OF VISITOR EXPERIENCES TO ASSESS EXPERIENCE QUALITY.QUANTIFY CURRENT CONDITIONS FOR PRIORITY INDICATORS AT EACH PARK UNIT TO DETERMINE HOW THEY ALIGN WITH VISITOR DEFINED THRESHOLDS OF ACCEPTABILITY.EVALUATE PERCEPTIONS OF CAVE AND KARST SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SEE ABOVEBENEFICIARIES: THE NPS IS AUTHORIZED TO ENTER INTO COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS WITH PUBLIC OR PRIVATE EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS, STATES, AND THEIR POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS, FOR THE PURPOSE OF DEVELOPING ADEQUATE, COORDINATED, COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING ACTIVITIES CONCERNING THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM (54 U.S.C. - 101702(B)).

POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE IS PROPOSING TO CONTINUE COLLABORATING WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA, A MEMBER OF THE DESERT SOUTHWEST COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNIT, ON MICROBIAL AND MYCORRHIZAL STUDIES RELATED TO COASTAL DUNES AT POINT REYES AND THE PARK'S EFFORTS TO EFFECTIVELY RESTORE THESE SYSTEMS AFTER BEING INVADED FOR DECADES. SOIL SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM PLOTS PREVIOUSLY INSTALLED AT ABBOTTS LAGOON AND AT&T, AND MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES BE ANALYZED FOR BOTH THE LITTER DECOMPOSITION AND EXPERIMENTAL INOCULUM PROJECTS. ROOTS FROM INVASIVE PLANTS (EUROPEAN BEACHGRASS) AND NATIVE DUNE PLANTS WILL BE COLLECTED FROM A NUMBER OF DUNE SYSTEMS AT POINT REYES, ALONG WITH SOILS FOR FUNGAL ANALYSES. DNA WILL BE EXTRACTED FROM SOIL SAMPLES COLLECTED AND PROCESSED TO CALCULATE THE ABUNDANCE AND PUTATIVE FUNCTIONAL COMPOSITION OF THE SOIL MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES AND EVALUATE DIFFERENCES ASSOCIATED WITH DUNE HABITATS AND INOCULUM TREATMENT. ROOTS OF NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE DUNE PLANTS AND DUNE SOILS WILL BE EVALUATED FOR MYCORRHIZAL COLONIZATION AND FUNGAL SPECIES PRESENCE.

CORES WILL BE ANALYZED TO UNDERSTAND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ISOTOPIC COMPOSITION OF PRECIPITATION AND DRIP WATER. ORGANICS ANALYZED TO PROVIDE A TIMELINE OF VEGETATION AND PRECIPITATION CHANGES, NITROGEN CYCLING IN SOIL, AS WELL AS NATURAL FIRES FOR HUNDREDS TO THOUSANDS OF YEARS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:OBJECTIVE 1: ESTABLISH A PRESENT-DAY CALIBRATION PROGRAM TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW THE CLIMATIC SIGNAL IS TRANSFERRED FROM SURFACE INTO THE CAVE.OBJECTIVE 2: RECOVER AN ICE CORE/S FROM AN ELMA CAVE FOR ANALYSIS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1) PROJECT START DATE - JULY 15, 20222) TECHNICAL PROGRESS REPORTS -ANNUALLY3) DATABASE, COLLECTIONS/SPECIMENS, ARCHIVES, AND MAPS PROVIDED TO THE NPS ATR OR TECHNICAL EXPERT- SEPTEMBER 1, 20224) DRAFT FINAL REPORT - NOVEMBER 1, 20235) FINAL REPORT -OCTOBER 31, 20236) PROJECT END DATE - DECEMBER 31, 2023 (PROJECT REPORTS/DELIVERABLES ARE DUE)7) FINAL SF424 FFR MUST BE SUBMITTED WITHIN 90 DAYS OF PROJECT AND DATE.BENEFICIARIES:NPS, THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH FLORIDA

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):SPRINGS ARE A UNIQUE AND IMPORTANT RESOURCE AT SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK (SHEN), PROVIDING IRREPLACEABLE HABITAT FOR MANY AQUATIC SPECIES AND CONTRIBUTING TO VISITOR EXPERIENCE. VISITORS ARE DRAWN TO SHEN'S SEEPS AND SPRINGS, SO MANY SEE HEAVY USE. ADDITIONALLY, SOME SEEPS AND SPRINGS IN SHEN HAVE BEEN USED HISTORICALLY AS DRINKING WATER SOURCES, AND IN SOME CASES HAVE SIGNIFICANT HUMAN MODIFICATION AND BUILT INFRASTRUCTURE, PARTICULARLY THOSE NEAR VISITOR USE HUTS. MANY OF THESE SPRINGS WITH BUILT INFRASTRUCTURE HAVE BEEN DEEMED UNSAFE AND DECOMMISSIONED AS THE PARK SWITCHED TO WELLS. PARK STAFF WOULD LIKE TO KNOW IF SPRINGS HARBOR RARE MACROINVERTEBRATE SPECIES THAT ARE KNOWN TO EXIST IN THE PARK TO DETERMINE WHETHER ANY SPRINGS NEED FURTHER PROTECTION FROM VISITOR USE AND WHETHER THE DECOMMISSIONED SPRINGS SHOULD BE RESTORED DUE TO THE PRESENCE OF RARE MACROINVERTEBRATES. PARK STAFF WOULD ALSO LIKE TO UNDERSTAND THE COMPOSITION OF SPECIES IN BOTH HIGHLY VISITED SPRINGS AND MORE PRISTINE SPRINGS. THIS PROJECT WILL DETERMINE THE PRESENCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF RARE MACROINVERTEBRATE SPECIES AND ASSOCIATED HABITAT IN SHEN SEEPS AND SPRINGS, BOTH UNDEVELOPED AND DEVELOPED, ALONG VISITOR USE, GEOLOGICAL, AND ELEVATIONAL GRADIENTS. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP THE PARK DETERMINE WHETHER TO RESTORE SPRINGS THAT HAVE DECOMMISSIONED INFRASTRUCTURE AND WHETHER FURTHER PROTECTION FROM VISITOR USE IS WARRANTED ON UNDEVELOPED SPRINGS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE SAMPLING FOR BENTHIC MACROINVERTEBRATES IN EACH HABITAT TYPE IN EACH SPRING AND NOTE THE PHYSICAL HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS LIKE TEMPERATURE AND SUBSTRATE. THE RESEARCHERS WILL NOTE IF ANY RARE SPECIES OR SPECIES OF CONSERVATION INTEREST ARE PRESENT IN SAMPLED SPRINGS. THEY WILL ALSO COMPARE SPECIES PRESENCE/ABSENCE AND RICHNESS ACROSS VISITOR USE, ELEVATIONAL, AND GEOLOGICAL GRADIENTS. THE PARK CAN USE THIS INFORMATION TO DETERMINE WHAT SPECIES MAY BE EXPECTED IN DEGRADED SITES (OF SIMILAR HABITAT, GEOLOGY, AND ELEVATION) WERE THEY IN PRISTINE CONDITION AND WHETHER TO CONSIDER ACTION TO PROTECT OR RESTORE SPRINGS WITH RARE SPECIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SAMPLING SITES WILL BE SCOUTED IN FALL 2022, DURING WHICH THE RESEARCHERS WILL COLLECT INITIAL DATA ABOUT SPRING HABITAT. SAMPLING FOR MACROINVERTEBRATES WILL OCCUR IN SPRING/SUMMER 2023, AFTER WHICH ALL SPECIES WILL BE IDENTIFIED. FINAL RESULTS WILL INCLUDE A REPORT OUTLINING THE METHODS AND DISCUSSING THE PRESENCE OF RARE SPECIES AND THE COMPOSITION OF SPECIES IN DIFFERENT SPRINGS. THE PARK CAN THEN USE THIS INFORMATION TO INFORM THEIR MANAGEMENT OF THESE SPRINGS.BENEFICIARIES: VIRGINIA TECH

FENS ARE PEAT-ACCUMULATING GROUNDWATER-FED WETLANDS THAT FORM A UNIQUE HABITAT WITHIN GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK AND JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR. MEMORIAL HIGHWAY. THIS HABITAT SUPPORTS PLANT SPECIES THAT GROW NOWHERE ELSE, AND PEAT SOILS MAY TAKE THOUSANDS OF YEARS TO DEVELOP, MAKING FENS AN IRREPLACEABLE RESOURCE. AS VISITATION INCREASES AND VISITATION PATTERNS CHANGE, FENS AND SPECIFICALLY RICH FENS MAY NEED ADDED PROTECTION TO AVOID TRAMPLING AND OTHER DISTURBANCES.THIS PROJECT WILL USE EXISTING IMAGERY DATA TO MAP POTENTIAL FEN AND RICH FEN HABITAT. PROJECT PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS WILL THEN DEVELOP A PRIORITIZED LIST OF 20 TO 50 POTENTIAL FEN LOCATIONS TO VERIFY THEIR STATUS AS FENS AND CONDUCT FOLLOW-UP FIELD SURVEYS FOR RARE PLANT SPECIES PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE.FEN MAPPING WILL OCCUR IN FALL-WINTER 2022-2023. FIELD WORK WILL OCCUR IN 2023. THE FINAL REPORT AND PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE GIS DATA, ACCURACY OF POTENTIAL FEN CLASSIFICATION, RARE PLANT PRESENCE AND ABUNDANCE, AND DATA SYNTHESIS AND INTERPRETATION.
