NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROJECT ABSTRACTCOMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE 1) UPGRADING MUSEUM STORAGE FOR NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGED AT SEAC; 2) IMPROVE ACCOUNTABILITY BY CATALOGING ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGED AT SEAC, AND 3) ENGAGING STUDENTS AND PROVIDING HANDS-ON MUSEUM COLLECTIONS EXPERIENCE TO GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS. OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THAT MUSEUM STORAGE IS UPGRADED FOR NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGED AT SEAC AND THAT GRADUATE STUDENTS ARE AFFORDED AN OPPORTUNITY TO GAIN HANDS ON EXPERIENCE WITH A VARIETY OF COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT DUTIES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: MUSEUM OBJECTS WILL BE EVALUATED TO DETERMINE WHICH NEED TO HAVE HOUSING IMPROVED, COLLECTIONS WILL BE REORGANIZED, AND MUSEUM OBJECTS WILL BE CATALOGED (IDENTIFIED, COUNTED, WEIGHED) INTO THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR'S INTERIOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:MEETINGS WILL BE HELD TWICE A YEAR TO ENSURE GOALS ARE BEING MET. MUSEUM STORAGE WILL BE UPGRADED FOR NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS MANAGED AT SEAC. OBJECTS FROM CANE RIVER CREOLE NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE (CARI) WILL BE ONE FOCUS OF THE PROJECT, WITH OTHER SEAC COLLECTIONS BEING INCLUDED. THREE ACCESSIONS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS REQUIRING ADDITIONAL ATTENTION INCLUDING: SEAC-01224, SEAC-01300 AND SEAC-01304. THESE THREE ACCESSIONS ARE COMPOSED OF APPROXIMATELY 150 COLLECTIONS STORAGE BOXES AND 40 DRAWERS OF METAL ARTIFACTS. IT IS EXPECTED THAT ROUGHLY ONE-THIRD OF THE COLLECTIONS TARGETED FOR REHOUSING AND REORGANIZATION WILL BE ADDRESSED EACH YEAR OF THE PROGRAM.15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE QUALITY OF WATER RESOURCES IN NEW RIVER GORGE NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE WITH A FOCUS ON ANALYZING WATER CHEMISTRY IN SPRINGS, SEEPS, VERNAL POOLS, TRIBUTARY STREAMS, AND WATER COMING FROM LEGACY UNDERGROUND MINES. RESULTS WILL HELP PARK MANAGERS PRIORITIZE WATERSHEDS AND AQUATIC RESOURCES THAT CAN BE IMPROVED TO SUPPORT AQUATIC ORGANISMS, PROVIDE DATA TO INFORM RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WITHIN THE PARK, AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO COLLABORATE WITH UPSTREAM PARTNERS WHEN SOURCES OF IONS OR METALS ARE OUTSIDE OF THE PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:SPECIFIC PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:FIELD SAMPLING AND LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF WATER CHEMISTRY FOR SPRINGS OR SEEPS, ESPECIALLY SURFACE WATERS THAT MAY ORIGINATE IN HISTORIC UNDERGROUND MINES.FIELD SAMPLING AND SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL ANALYSIS OF STREAM CHEMISTRY FOR TRIBUTARIES OF THE NEW RIVER WITH A FOCUS ON WATERSHEDS WITH SIGNIFICANT HISTORIC MINING ACTIVITIES.FIELD SAMPLING AND LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF WATER CHEMISTRY IN VERNAL POOLS. BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING OF AQUATIC INSECTS TO EVALUATE THEIR POTENTIAL TO BETTER PREDICT WATER QUALITY IN STREAMS (COMPARED TO RESULTS OF WATER SAMPLE MEASUREMENTS) AND IDENTIFY AN INSECT SPECIES THAT CAN BE USED AS A BIOINDICATOR OF TRACE METAL POLLUTION. PROVIDE DATA AND REPORTS TO HELP PARK MANAGERS PRIORITIZE WATERSHEDS AND AQUATIC RESOURCES THAT CAN BE IMPROVED TO SUPPORT AQUATIC ORGANISMS, INFORM RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, AND IDENTIFY OPPORTUNITIES TO COLLABORATE WITH UPSTREAM PARTNERS WHEN SOURCES OF IONS OR METALS ORIGINATE OUTSIDE OF THE PARK.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:YEAR 1: WORK WITH NPS TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE STREAMS AND OTHER AQUATIC RESOURCES AND BEGIN SAMPLING TO ADDRESS DATA GAPS ON TRACE METAL AND MAJOR ION CONCENTRATIONS. EXPECTED OUTCOME: SAMPLE AND ANALYZE 350 WATER SAMPLES FOR 12 METALS AND MAJOR IONS AS WELL AS NUTRIENT AND ANION MEASUREMENTS AT SELECTED HIGH CONDUCTIVITY SITES.YEAR 2: EXPAND WATER CHEMISTRY ANALYSIS AND ASSESS TRACE METAL CONTENT OF AQUATIC MACROINVERTEBRATES TO FIND A SPECIES THAT CAN BE USED AS AN ONGOING BIOMONITOR OF TRACE METAL POLLUTION. EXPECTED OUTCOME: ANALYZE 250 WATER SAMPLES FOR METALS AND MAJOR IONS AND 50 BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES.YEAR 3: ASSESS WATER CHEMISTRY AND ASSOCIATED METALS IN BIOTA IN SEEPS AND ASSOCIATED VERNAL POOLS. COMPLETE DATA ANALYSIS AND REPORTING. EXPECTED OUTCOME: ANALYZE 250 WATER SAMPLES FOR METALS AND MAJOR IONS AND 150 BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES AND DELIVER ONE FINAL REPORT.BENEFICIARIES:WATER QUALITY DIRECTLY INFLUENCES THE HEALTH OF BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING FISH AND AQUATIC INSECTS, WITHIN THE PARK. HISTORIC MINING AND RAILROAD INFRASTRUCTURE AND MORE RECENT INDUSTRIAL AND MUNICIPAL ACTIVITIES MAY CONTRIBUTE POLLUTANTS THAT DEGRADE THESE RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WILL IMPROVE UNDERSTANDING OF WATER QUALITY AND POTENTIAL STRESSORS AFFECTING THE PARK'S AQUATIC RESOURCES, HELPING PARK MANAGERS TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE WATERSHEDS THAT ARE IN MOST NEED OF RESTORATION. FURTHERMORE, THE BROADER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH THIS RESEARCH AND THE PUBLIC WILL HAVE BETTER APPRECIATION OF THE PARK'S AQUATIC RESOURCES AND RELATED MANAGEMENT ISSUES.

CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS HAVE DECLINED IN ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION IN RECENT YEARS. THEY ARE LISTED AS A SPECIES OF SPECIAL CONCERN BY THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THREATS TO THESE OWLS INCLUDE LOSS OF HABITAT, COMPETITION WITH INVASIVE BARRED OWLS, AND SEVERE WILDFIRE. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO RESURVEY EXISTING SITES AFTER THE KNP COMPLEX FIRE BURNED THROUGH SEQUOIA KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARK TO DETERMINE IF THE FIRE IMPACTED CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO TARGET POTENTIAL RESTORATION AREAS AND ADJUST THE IMPORTANCE OF PRE-FIRE FUELS TREATMENTS AND POST-FIRE RESPONSE DEPENDING ON WHAT IS FOUND IN TERMS OF IMPACTS OF HIGH, MODERATE, AND LOW SEVERITY FIRE ON OWL OCCUPANCY.THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE DEPLOYING ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS TO SURVEY FOR CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWL AND BARRED OWLS IN SEKI AT THE SAME 78 LOCATIONS USED TO SURVEY IN 2021 PRIOR TO THE KNP COMPLEX FIRE. THESE LOCATIONS COVER A VARIETY OF FIRE INTENSITY, INCLUDING UNBURNED, LOW SEVERITY, MODERATE SEVERITY, AND HIGH SEVERITY BURNS. THE ACOUSTIC DATA WILL BE SCANNED USING SPECIALIZED MACHINE-LEARNING ALGORITHMS THAT IDENTIFY THESE TARGET SPECIES WITH HIGH ACCURACY AND PRECISION.

THIS AWARD AIMS TO OFFER UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS WITH THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP HANDS ON SKILLS IN THE MANAGEMENT OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND MUSEUM COLLECTIONS IN THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AREA. INCLUDING ACCESSIONING, PROCESSING, AND CATALOGING MUSEUM COLLECTIONS.PROJECT TASKS INCLUDED BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO CREATING REPORTS AND BASELINE DOCUMENTS, CARRYING OUT ROUTINE CURATORIAL TASKS THROUGHOUT THE NATIONAL CAPITAL AREA, ENTERING CATALOG RECORDS INTO THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR'S INTERIOR COLLECTION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, DEVELOPING ONLINE EXHIBITS AND CONTENT ABOUT COLLECTIONS AND CULTURAL RESOURCES.THE APPLICATION OF PREVENTIVE CONSERVATION METHODS IN PARK SITES AND THE MUSEUM RESOURCE CENTER, THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF APPROPRIATE AND UPDATED STORAGE MOUNTS FOR COLLECTIONS AT THE MUSEUM RESOURCE CENTER, THE CREATION OF CATALOG RECORDS AND OTHER BASELINE DOCUMENTATION.JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY/NATIONAL PARK SERVICE
STIMULATE IMPERILED ORCHID RECOVERY IN PRWI WITH FOREST THINNING AND WOOD CHIPS

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO DEVELOP DESCRIPTIVE INFORMATION ABOUT VISITOR USE TYPES, AMOUNTS, AND PATTERNS AS WELL AS PERCEPTIONS OF VISITOR EXPERIENCE ON BLUE MESA RESERVOIR AND THE ADJACENT GUNNISON RIVER AT CURECANTI NATIONAL RECREATION AREA (CURE). UNDERSTANDING CURRENT CONDITIONS, EXPERIENCES, AND ASSOCIATED RELATIONSHIPS REGARDING VISITOR USE ON BLUE MESA RESERVOIR AND THE ADJACENT GUNNISON RIVER IS ESSENTIAL FOR PARK PLANNING.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THROUGH THIS WORK, CURE INTENDS TO ACHIEVE: 1) A BASELINE UNDERSTANDING OF VISITOR USE PATTERNS, TYPES, AND AMOUNTS; 2) SEASONAL DIFFERENCES, IF ANY, IN VISITOR USE PATTERNS, TYPES, AND AMOUNTS; 3) INFORMATION ABOUT VISITOR EXPERIENCE, EXPERIENCE QUALITY, AND OTHER VISITOR USE ASPECTS - INCLUDING INFORMATION TO INFORM DEVELOPMENT OF EXPERIENCE QUALITY THRESHOLDS - FROM ON-SITE VISITORS; AND 4) A VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT TOOL THAT MERGES THE DESCRIPTIVE AND EVALUATIVE COMPONENTS OF THE RESEARCH TOGETHER FOR FUTURE SCENARIO PLANNING.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:ON-SITE VISITOR USE STUDY IN SUMMER 2023TECHNICAL REPORT DETAILING THE COMPLETE FINDINGS OF THE DATA COLLECTIONSA SCENARIO PLANNING TOOLKIT ALL FINAL DATASETSBENEFICIARIES:THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND/OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE ON APPLICATIONS AND METHODOLOGIES FOR ANALYZING RECREATIONAL VISITOR USE AND ASSOCIATED RESOURCE
CRITICAL INVASIVE PLANT INVENTORY AT FLORISSANT FOSSIL BEDS NM

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE: TRAINING SESSION FOR NPS MANAGERS ON BMPS FOR WEED WASH STATIONS TO PREVENT INVASIVE PLANT SPREAD DURING FIRE SUPPRESSION; TRAINING SESSION ON ECOLOGICALLY SENSITIVE VEGETATION MANAGEMENT AT THE CAL-IPC SYMPOSIUM; AND AN INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT STRATEGY FOR JOHN MUIR NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE ORIGINAL LIME PLASTER AND GYPSUM FINISHES IN THE SACRISTY AND BAPTISTERY OF MISSION SAN JOSE DE TUMACACORI. THE CHURCH IS THE PRIMARY RESOURCE FOR WHICH THE PARK WAS ESTABLISHED, AS IDENTIFIED IN THE ENABLING LEGISLATION. THE LAST COMPREHENSIVE WORK ON THE INTERIOR WAS COMPLETED IN 1984. SINCE THEN, THE PLASTER HAS DETERIORATED, AND PRESERVATION IS NEEDED.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:DEVELOP TREATMENT PLAN FOR THE SACRISTY AND BAPTISTERY OF THE MISSION CHURCH AT TUMA.COMPLETE THE COMPREHENSIVE CONDITION ASSESSMENT OF THE IDENTIFIED INTERIOR SPACES OF THE CHURCH, USING A VARIETY OF APPROACHES (INCLUDING VISUAL EVALUATION, ANNOTATED ORTHO-RECTIFIED PHOTOMONTAGE, NON-DESTRUCTIVE TESTING AND ANALYSIS OF SURFACES AND SUB-SURFACE ISSUES) DEVELOP PROGRAM FOR INVESTIGATION AND SAMPLINGDOCUMENT ALL PAST REPAIRS AS PART OF THE BASELINE DATA, WITH PARTICULAR FOCUS ON INCOMPATIBLE REPAIRSPRIORITIZATION OF TREATMENT AREAS BASED ON MATERIAL/DESIGN INTEGRITY, SIGNIFICANCE OF FEATURES, LEVEL AND RATE OF DETERIORATION, AND PUBLIC VISIBILITY/ACCESSDEVELOP OF TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO ADDRESS CAUSES OF FAILURE FOR THE FOLLOWING: PLASTER LOSS, DETACHMENT OF PLASTERS, VOIDS AND INTER-LAYER SEPARATION OF PLASTERS, FRIABILITY OF SURFACE MATERIALS, ADOBE DISINTEGRATION AND LOSS, BASAL EROSION, STRUCTURAL AND MICRO-CRACKING, AND FAILURE OF PREVIOUS TREATMENTS; DEVELOPMENT OF A TREATMENT AND MONITORING APPROACH AND TIME-FRAMEIMPLEMENT IN-SITU TREATMENTREMOVAL/REPLACEMENT OF INCOMPATIBLE REPAIRSCLEANING SURFACESREMOVAL OF SALTSCONSOLIDATING DISINTEGRATING LIME RENDER/PLASTERSTABILIZING/REPLACING FAILING PLASTER EDGESREATTACHING DETACHED PLASTERGROUTING OF CRACKS AND VOIDS IN LIME RENDER/MORTAR -ENGINEER NEEDS TO CONDUCT STRUCTURAL ASSESSMENT (NOT IN CONTRACT)CONSOLIDATION AND REATTACHMENT OF THE PAINTED FINISH COATSPROVIDE ORIGINALS (OR COPIES) OF ALL DIGITAL AND HARD COPY INFORMATION PRODUCED AS PART OF THE PROJECTPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DEVELOP TREATMENT PLAN, COMPLETE TREATMENTS, AND FINALIZE A REPORT FOR THE NPS.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE UPENN STUDENTS, FACULTY, THE PUBLIC

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROVIDES HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE THE CLASSROOM FOR ANTHROPOLOGY, ARCHEOLOGY, AND/OR MUSEUM STUDIES STUDENTSSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COOPERATORS WILL ASSIST WITH SECURING INVENTORY INFORMATION AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS TO RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC; CONDUCT RESEARCH TO PROCESS AND CATALOG OBJECTS; ANALYZE ARCHEOLOGICAL FAUNAL REMAINS; FACILITATE ACCESS EVENTS; STORE AND CONSOLIDATE COLLECTIONS; COMPLETE CYCLIC MAINTENANCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TO ADDRESS LONG TERM PRESERVATION NEEDS TO PREPARE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS FOR PUBLIC EXHIBIT AND ACCESS FOR RESEARCH, WHILE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL WORK OPPORTUNITIES.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:CATALOG, HOUSE, AND STORE CIRCA 6,600 OBJECTS FROM 4 PARKS; INPROCESS 75 LF OF GENERAL PARK COLLECTIONS; IMPROVE 500 LEGACY BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK RECORDS TO MEET CURRENT STANDARDS.PHOTOGRAPH CIRCA 40 DIAGNOSTIC FAUNAL ELEMENTS; ATTACH IMAGES TO ICMS.ENTER SURVEY DATA FOR CIRCA 35 PLASTIC TREATMENTS INTO ICMS; CHECK OUT AND IN OBJECTS ON LOAN TO CONSERVATIONATTACH METTAG LABELS TO 10 INCOMING BOXES OF OBJECTS ACCORDING TO THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLAN; COMPLETE CYCLIC MAINTENANCE FOR 25 MICROCLIMATE CONTAINERS FOR FOUR PARKSBENEFICIARIES:NPS PARKS WITH MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND COOPERATORS.

PROJECT TITLE - ACOUSTIC SURVEYS AND PUBLIC OUTREACH FOR BATS AFFECTED BY WHITE NOSE SYNDROMEPROJECT STATEMENT - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE PRESENCE/ABSENCE OF RARE BAT SPECIES AND OTHER BAT SPECIES THAT INHABIT THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY AND CARL SANDBURG HOME. THIS INFORMATION WILL PROVIDE MANAGEMENT AT BOTH PARKS A DEFINITIVE LIST OF RARE SPECIES AND THEIR KNOWN LOCATIONS THAT WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE IMPACTS OF ESSENTIAL OPERATIONS ON DECLINING BAT POPULATIONS, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING TREND DATA ON SPECIES OCCURRENCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY AND PROTECT BATS WHERE THEY OCCUR IN THE PARK WITH EMPHASIS ON RARE SPECIES (NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT, LITTLE BROWN BAT, INDIANA BAT, EASTERN SMALL FOOTED BAT, TRI-COLORED BAT, GRAY BAT, AND VIRGINIA BIG-EARED BAT) WHILE PROVIDING SAFE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR VISITORS.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES - THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT ARE 1) TO DEVELOP A LIST OF BAT SPECIES AND THEIR KNOWN LOCATIONS IN EACH PARK; 2) TO PROVIDE BACKGROUND INFORMATION TO EACH PARK SO THAT ISSUES AFFECTING THEIR HEALTH AND VIGOR CAN BE SHARED WITH STAFF, THE PUBLIC, AND LOCAL SCHOOLS; AND 3) TO GATHER SPECIES DATA THAT WILL BE USED TO ANALYZE TRENDS IN BAT SPECIES/POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT BOTH PARKS (E.G., WHETHER SPECIES ARE IN DECLINE, STABLE, OR INCREASING IN ABUNDANCE).PROJECT MILESTONESKICK OFF   MEETINGJULY 11-15, 2022EQUIP/SUPPLIES   DELIVERED TO PARTNER UNIVERSITYJULY 15ACOUSTIC SURVEYSJULY 11 - JULY 31, 2022ACCOMPLISHMENT   REPORT PROVIDED TO PARK15-NOV-22ALL RAW DATA   RUN THROUGH SOFTWARE15-DEC-22ANNUAL   INVESTIGATOR REPORT (RESEARCH PERMIT)15-DEC-22DRAFT REPORT   PROVIDED TO PARK1-APR-23COMMENTS FROM   PARK TO PARTNER UNIVERSITY15-APR-23FINAL REPORT   COMPLETED30-APR-23SD CARDS, DATA   SHEETS/METADATA, EXCEL/DATABASE SUBMITTED TO PARK30-APR-23

NPS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROJECT ABSTRACTCOMPETITIVE AWARD AGREEMENT REQUIREMENTSFUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: N/AFUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT: N/AREQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO ENHANCE THE NATURAL RESOURCES ON THE SHORELINES OF FORT GEORGE ISLAND (FL) AND CUMBERLAND ISLAND (GA) TO PROVIDE PROTECTION TO ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES AT EACH LOCATION. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO DIRECTLY RESTORE, ENHANCE, CREATE, OR MANAGE 100 METERS OF SHORELINE AT FORT GEORGE ISLAND (FL) AND AT CUMBERLAND ISLAND.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE PLANNED LIVING SHORELINE RESTORATION LOCATION AT KINGSLEY PLANTATION LOCATED ON FORT GEORGE ISLAND WITHIN THE TIMUCUAN ECOLOGICAL AND HISTORIC PRESERVE IN JACKSONVILLE, FL IS EXPERIENCING RAPID EROSION DUE TO WAKE AND STORM WAVE ENERGY. THIS SITE IS IDENTIFIED AS HIGH PRIORITY AREA DUE TO INCREASED EROSION TO A NEARBY ARCHEOLOGICAL SITE THAT IS SIGNIFICANT TO THE PROPERTY'S HISTORY. THE PROJECT WILL DEPLOY STRUCTURES THAT ARE RESILIENT TO HIGH WAKE ENERGY AND SHOULD PROVIDE A ROBUST FOUNDATION FOR CONTINUED OYSTER GROWTH OVER TIME. VIGOROUS OYSTER BEDS IN NEARBY REGIONS INDICATE OYSTERS WILL BE HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL ONCE PROVIDED A FOUNDATION AND MAY BE ABLE TO KEEP UP WITH SEA LEVEL RISE. OYSTER REEFS WILL PROTECT GROWTH OF SPARTINA ALTERNIFLORA ONCE WAKE ENERGY IS REDUCED. BOTH HABITATS WILL ENHANCE RESOURCES FOR TARGET SPECIES. THE RESULTING OYSTER HABITAT IS EXPECTED TO HAVE A POSITIVE EFFECT ON FORAGING RESOURCES OF 3 SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. SPECIES EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM THE ESTUARINE ENHANCEMENT INCLUDE JUVENILE SCALLOPED HAMMERHEAD SHARKS AND SANDBAR SHARKS, ALONG WITH THE AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER. A TOTAL OF 100 LINEAR METERS OF SHORELINE WILL BE ENHANCED LEADING TO AN ESTIMATED 4 ACRES OF ESTUARINE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT. DUVAL COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOL STUDENTS WILL BE UTILIZED TO HELP CREATE THE OYSTER STRUCTURES AND HARVEST AND PLANT SPARTINA GRASS.THE PROJECT ON CUMBERLAND ISLAND WILL TAKE PLACE ON THE WESTERN SIDE OF CUMBERLAND ISLAND ON THE BRICKHILL RIVER ADJACENT TO THE BRICKHILL CAMPGROUND.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SURVEY AND DEVELOP WAVE MODELS TO DETERMINE BEST WHERE ERECT THE      STRUCTURES.BUILD AND INSTALL 10 OYSTER "RESTORATION UNITS." EACH UNIT WILL      CONSIST OF APPROXIMATELY 5 PERVIOUS OYSTER SHELL HABITATS (POSHS) OR      CONCRETE STRUCTURES FOR A TOTAL OF 50 OYSTER STRUCTURES. THE PLANNED      STRUCTURES WILL BE APPROXIMATELY 30CM HIGH AND APPROXIMATELY 45 CM AT THE      BASE.SOURCE, GROW, HARVEST, AND INSTALL SPARTINA      BEHIND 50% OF THE "OYSTER RESTORATION UNITS." PLANTS WILL BE PLACED IN A      GRID PATTERN FOR UP TO 2M BEHIND THE UNITS WITH A SPACING OF APPROXIMATELY      30CM BETWEEN PLANTS TO PREVENT CROWDING. BENEFICIARIES:15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):TO ANALYZE AND, IF NEEDED, DEVELOP STABILIZATION METHODS FOR CLIFF PALACE A UNIQUE ANCESTRAL PUEBLO CLIFF DWELLING COMPLEX TO ENSURE ITS PRESERVATION AND CONTINUED SAFE ACCESS BY THE PUBLIC.THE PROJECT WILL APPLY STATE-OF-THE ART TECHNICAL EXPERTISE TO INVESTIGATE, DOCUMENT, ANALYZE, AND DIAGNOSE THE FULL RANGE OF ISSUES NEGATIVELY IMPACTING THE INTEGRITY OF CLIFF PALACE. THE FINAL PRODUCT WILL BE THOROUGHLY RESEARCHED, LOGICAL, AND WILL CONTAIN FEASIBLE OPTIONS FOR LONG-TERM CARE OF CLIFF PALACE IN FULL COMPLIANCE WITH THE SECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR'S STANDARDS FOR THE TREATMENT OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ROBUST AND DETAILED DOCUMENTATION, IN THE FORM OF MARKED DRAWINGS AND PHOTOGRAPHS, AND THREE-DIMENSIONAL (3D) NUMERICAL ANALYSES OF THE COMPLETE CLIFF PALACE COMPLEX. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE AND OVERSIGHT OF THE RESEARCH EFFORT TO THE HIGHLY QUALIFIED AND EXPERIENCED RESEARCH FACULTY OF THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS, AT SAN ANTONIO (UTSA) CENTER FOR CULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY PLUS GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM THE UTSA HISTORIC PRESERVATION, ARCHITECTURE, AND CIVIL ENGINEERING PROGRAMS.INTEGRATION AND EVALUATION OF LIDAR SCANS OBTAINED BY NPS IN 2017 AND OTHER IN SITU DATA WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH A SOPHISTICATED AND ROBUST 3D FINITE DIFFERENCE ANALYSES, SIMILAR TO FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSES. LIDAR DATA WILL BE MUCH SIMPLIFIED AND THEN MODELS WILL BE MADE TO HAVE THE GEOMETRY NEEDED FOR THE ANALYSIS. METHODS NOW IN DEVELOPMENT AS PART OF YEAR ONE RESEARCH WILL INCORPORATE SMEARED PROPERTIES, CONSIDERING THE STRUCTURAL BEHAVIOR OF THE MASONRY AS A WHOLE (AS A CONTINUUM ELEMENT).PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:COMPLETION OF RESEARCH BEGUN IN YEAR ONE ON THE HISTORY OF 20TH CENTURY ALTERATIONS AT CLIFF PALACE, FOCUSED ON STRUCTURAL INTERVENTIONS AND STABILIZATION PROJECTS. ONGOING TRAINING OF PH.D. STUDENT AND/OR UTSA RESEARCH STAFF IN OPERATION OF COMPUTER ANALYSIS PROGRAM. DEVELOP A TECHNICAL REPORT ON 13TH CENTURY STONE ASSEMBLIES BASED ON LITERATURE REVIEW, FIELD OBSERVATIONS, AND NON-DESTRUCTIVE EVALUATIONS. THESE ASSEMBLIES ARE RELEVANT TO UNDERSTANDING STRUCTURAL PERFORMANCE OF PRESENT-DAY WALL CONFIGURATIONS.PHYSICAL TESTING OF SANDSTONE AND MORTARS FROM CLIFF PALACE WILL BE PURSUED IN YEAR TWO. INCORPORATE DATA FROM PHYSICAL TESTING OF SANDSTONE AND MORTARS INTO DEVELOPMENT OF MATERIAL MODELS IN 3D ANALYSIS. CLASSIFY WALL ASSEMBLIES AND DOCUMENT CONDITIONS RELEVANT TO STRUCTURAL PERFORMANCE FOCUSING ON THREE OR FOUR CLIFF PALACE "COURTYARD" AREAS. CONDUCT GROUND PENETRATING RADAR (GPR) SURVEYS USING HANDHELD DEVICE TO GATHER DATA FROM A SMALL NUMBER OF SPECIFIC LOCATIONS WHICH CAN THEN BE GENERALIZED AND EXTRAPOLATED TO INFORM KNOWLEDGE ON STRUCTURAL CONFIGURATIONS ACROSS CLIFF PALACE.BENEFICIARIES:THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND MESA VERDE NATIONAL PARK WILL BENEFIT WITH A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE STRUCTURAL CHARACTERISTICS AND EXISTING STABILITY OF CLIFF PALACE. GRADUATE LEVEL STUDENTS WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE IN ASSESSING THE CONDITION OF A PREHISTORIC STRUCTURE AND IN ADVANCED ANALYSIS METHODS. VISITORS WILL BENEFIT IN THAT STABILIZATION METHODS TO ENSURE CLIFF PALACE IS STRUCTURALLY STABLE WILL BE DEVELOPED AND THE CLIFF DWELLING REMAINS OPEN TO THE PUB

COMPLETE CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS THAT DESCRIBE ASSET-SPECIFIC VULNERABILITIES FROM CLIMATE CHANGE FOR INFRASTRUCTURE IN HIGH PRIORITY COASTAL OR SHORELINE PARK UNITS IN THE GREAT LAKES, PACIFIC COAST, PACIFIC ISLANDS, ALASKA, AND ELSEWHERE. INFORM ADAPTATION ACTIONS FOR SELECT PROJECTS SERVICE WIDE.COMPLETION OF CLIMATE CHANGE VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS FOR PARKS AS IDENTIFIED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):- THE WACO MAMMOTH NATIONAL MONUMENT FELLOWSHIP, IN COLLABORATION WITH BAYLOR UNIVERSITY, WILL HELP TO FURTHER RESEARCH FOCUSED ON THE PLEISTOCENE FOSSIL RESOURCE AT THE MONUMENT. THIS COLLABORATION WILL ASSIST BOTH ORGANIZATIONS IN THEIR OWN GOALS WHILE STRENGTHENING THE EXISTING PARTNERSHIP. SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS FELLOWSHIP WILL FURTHER RESEARCH AT THE MONUMENT AND GIVE THE BASIS FOR CONTENT FOR EDUCATION, INTERPRETATION, AND DISTANCE LEARNING. THE FELLOW WILL WORK WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND BAYLOR UNIVERSITY FACULTY AND STAFF TO DEVELOP SPECIFIC INDIVIDUAL PLANS FOR THE ACADEMIC YEAR THAT WILL USE THEIR STRENGTHS TO CONDUCT ORIGINAL RESEARCH. POSSIBLE RESEARCH TOPICS INCLUDE PALEOENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES, AGING OF MAMMOTH, BONE PATHOLOGIES, COLLECTION METHODOLOGY, IMPROVED SPECIMEN PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES. SPECIFIC TOPICS AND STEPS WILL BE BASED ON THE STRENGTHS OF THE FELLOW, BUT THE END RESULT WILL BE CONTENT THAT CAN BE USED BY INTERPRETATION TO DEVELOP NEW ON-SITE PROGRAMMING FOR VISITORS AND A NEW DISTANCE LEARNING PROGRAM FOR K-12 STUDENTS. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SEE SUMMARYBENEFICIARIES: THE RESULTS OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT WILL HELP VISITORS UNDERSTAND HOW THE RESOURCE FITS WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THE RESEARCH COMMUNITY, AND THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY AT LARGE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PIPE SPRING NATIONAL MONUMENT WILL PARTNER WITH SOUTHERN UTAH UNIVERSITY INTERGOVERNMENTAL INTERNSHIP COOPERATIVE (IIC) TO RECRUIT SEVERAL INTERNS AND YOUTH CREWS TO SERVE ALL FUNCTIONAL AREAS OF THE PARK.THE IIC PROMOTES PROFESSIONALISM IN LAND STEWARDSHIP AND CREATES OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO PARTICIPATE IN PAID INTERNSHIPS AS PART OF THEIR FORMAL EDUCATION TO CONSERVE OR PRESERVE CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE EFFECTIVELY SERVING COMMUNITIES AND PARK VISITORS. THE IIC MISSION IS TO PROVIDE WORK AND PROJECT-BASED EDUCATIONAL INTERNSHIPS AND SERVICE-LEARNING PROGRAMS TO SERVE THE SOUTHERN UTAH, NORTHERN ARIZONA, AND EASTERN NEVADA REGION. IT MATCHES THE NEEDS OF LAND MANAGEMENT GOVERNMENT AGENCIES WITH THE GOALS OF HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENTS WHO ARE SEEKING MEANINGFUL EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. THE IIC AND FEDERAL AGENCIES WORK TOGETHER TO PROMOTE PROFESSIONALISM IN LAND STEWARDSHIP AND CREATE OPPORTUNITIES TO CONSERVE OR PRESERVE CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE EFFECTIVELY SERVING COMMUNITIES AND VISITORS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS TASK AGREEMENT WILL ENGAGE AT MINIMUM 25+ YOUTH IN STEWARDSHIP INTERNSHIPS OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS, TOTALING MORE THAN 10,500 HOURS OF EXPERIENCE. THESE INTERNS WILL GAIN SKILLS IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION, INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION, AND LIVESTOCK AND FARMING MANAGEMENT. OTHER OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE THE ABILITY TO RECRUIT AND COLLABORATE WITH TRIBAL YOUTH FROM THE SURROUNDING KAIBAB PAIUTE RESERVATION, WITH THE PLACEMENT OF AT MINIMUM 5 TRIBAL YOUTH OVER THE NEXT FIVE YEARS. ADDITIONALLY, THE TASK AGREEMENT WILL ENABLE THE MONUMENT TO ENGAGE AND INTERACT WITH THE YOUTH FROM THE YOUTH FROM THE REMOTE AND RURAL ARIZONA STRIP COMMUNITIES THAT ARE AN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY AS WELL AND INTRODUCE THEM TO WORK BEING PERFORMED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND PIPE SPRING NATIONAL MONUMENT. THE MONUMENT WILL ENGAGE AT LEAST MINIMUM 5+ YOUTH FROM THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES. THE INTERNS ENGAGED IN THESE INTERNSHIPS WILL PRODUCE INTERPRETATIVE DEMONSTRATIONS, ACTIVELY LEARN NATIVE AND PIONEER GARDENING METHODS, DEVELOP CUSTOMER SERVICE, LEARN ABOUT HISTORIC PRESERVATION AND MORE. THE INTERNS WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE MONUMENTS PROFESSIONAL SUMMER STAFF AND BE MENTORED AND COACHED BY SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS. THE INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCE WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE EXPERIENCE FOR YOUTH TO ENTER THE PUBLIC LANDS WORKFORCE WITH TANGIBLE SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND ASSIST THEM IN PURSUING FEDERAL AGENCY SEASONAL AND PERMANENT POSITIONS TO ENSURE THE NEXT GENERATIONS OF STEWARDSHIP ON OUR PUBLIC LANDS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RECRUIT FULL-TIME SUMMER INTERNS WORKING DURING      THEIR SUMMER BREAK FROM COLLEGE AND PART-TIME INTERNS IN THE FALL AND      SPRING SEMESTERS.THIS PROJECT WILL RECRUIT YOUTH CREWS TO ADDRESS BACKLOGGED      MAINTENANCE ALONG PARK TRAILS, BOUNDARY FENCES, AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION      PROJECTS FOR VISITOR ENJOYMENT.INTERNS WORKING IN THE VISITOR SERVICES DIVISION WILL ENGAGE      APPROXIMATELY 2000 VISITORS EACH THROUGH FORMAL AND INFORMATION      INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING, AS WELL AS, ROVING AND INFORMATION BOOTH      CONTACTS.BENEFICIARIES: SOUTHERN UTAH UNIVERSITY- INTERGOVERNMENTAL INTERNSHIP COOPERATIVE

THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH COLLABORATIVE INVESTIGATION OF WILDLIFE MORTALITY EVENTS AND EMERGING WILDLIFE DISEASES, IMPLEMENTATION OF DISEASE SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS AND CONDUCTING RESEARCH TO INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF WILDLIFE AND ZOONOTIC DISEASES IN PARKS. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WILL BE PROVIDED BY COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY AND PARTNERS AS NEEDED FOR RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS IN PARKS, INCLUDING WILDLIFE CAPTURE, FIELD ANESTHESIA, BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING, POPULATION MONITORING, EPIDEMIOLOGIC INVESTIGATIONS, POSTMORTEM EXAMINATION, COLLECTION AND HANDLING OF BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES AND DIAGNOSTIC AND TOXICOLOGICAL TESTING AND DEVELOPMENT.THE MAJORITY OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR ON AN ON-GOING BASIS AS NEEDED TO RESPOND TO EMERGING WILDLIFE HEALTH ISSUES OR MANAGEMENT NEEDS IN PARKS. TASKS RELATED TO SPECIFIC DISEASE SURVEILLANCE PROGRAMS WILL CONTINUE TO OCCUR ON AN ANNUAL BASIS IN ALIGNMENT WITH PARK AND DISEASE SURVEILLANCE PRIORITIES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROVIDES HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE THE CLASSROOM FOR ANTHROPOLOGY, ARCHEOLOGY, AND/OR MUSEUM STUDIES STUDENTSSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COOPERATORS WILL ASSIST WITH SECURING INVENTORY INFORMATION AND PROVIDING ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS TO RESEARCHERS AND THE PUBLIC; CONDUCT RESEARCH INTO PROVENANCE TO PROCESS AND CATALOG OBJECTS; ANALYZE ARCHEOLOGICAL FAUNAL REMAINS FOR IDENTIFICATION; FACILITATE ACCESS EVENTS; STORE AND CONSOLIDATE COLLECTIONS; COMPLETE CYCLIC MAINTENANCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TO ADDRESS LONG TERM PRESERVATION NEEDS TO PREPARE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS FOR PUBLIC EXHIBIT AND ACCESS FOR RESEARCH, WHILE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL WORK OPPORTUNITIES.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:CATALOG, REHOUSE, AND STORE AN ESTIMATED 500 FAUNAL ELEMENTS FROM FORT DAVIS NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE AND UPDATE OTHER FODA CATALOG RECORDS AS NECESSARY. PHOTOGRAPH AN ESTIMATED60 DIAGNOSTIC FAUNAL ELEMENTS AND ATTACH IMAGES TO CATALOG RECORDS.INPROCESS, REHOUSE, AND STORE APPROXIMATELY 75 LINEAR FEET OF PARK COLLECTIONS AND UPDATE EXISTING CATALOG RECORDS AS NECESSARY; COMPLETE NEW CATALOGING FOR UNCATALOGED ITEMS.PHOTOGRAPH 25 UNIQUE ITEMS FROM CASA GRANDE NATIONAL MONUMENT (CAGR), EDIT, AND ATTACH TO ICMS.ENTER SURVEY DATA FOR CIRCA 100 PLASTIC OBJECTS INTO ICMS AND CHECK OUT AND CHECK IN OBJECTS ON LOAN TO CONSERVATIONREBOX CIRCA 150 LF OF BULK STORAGE CERAMICS AND 75 BOXES OF VEGETAL MATERIAL, UPDATING STORAGE LOCATIONS AS NECESSARY.ATTACH METTAG LABELS TO 10 INCOMING BOXES OF OBJECTS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLANHOUSE, STORE AND UPDATE LOCATIONS FOR 100 PROCESSED TUMA SOIL SAMPLESCOMPLETE CYCLIC MAINTENANCE FOR 25 MICROCLIMATE CONTAINERS FOR FOUR PARKSALERT STAFF OF ANY EVIDENCE OF PEST OR PEST ACTIVITY ENCOUNTEREDBENEFICIARIES:NPS PARKS WITH MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND COOPERATORS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):(1) CONDUCT PD FUNGUS AND WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME PRESENCE TESTING AT SIX WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENT EARTHCRACKS;(2) CONDUCT NIGHTTIME BAT EMERGENCE COUNTS AT SIX WUPATKI EARTHCRACKS UTILIZING INFRARED VIDEO RECORDERS;(3) CONDUCT ACOUSTIC BAT MONITORING SURVEYS AT SIX WUPATKI EARTHCRACKS UTILIZING BAT ECHOLOCATION RECORDERS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:SUMMER BAT POPULATIONS WILL BE DETERMINED BY UTILIZING NIGHTTIME EMERGENCE SURVEYS AND INFRARED VIDEO MONITORING. BIOACOUSTIC RECORDERS WILL BE UTILIZED TO AID IN BAT SPECIES IDENTIFICATIONS. WINTER BAT POPULATIONS AND POTENTIAL PRESENCE OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME WILL BE DETERMINED THROUGH IN-CAVE HIBERNACULA SURVEYS. THE POTENTIAL PRESENCE OF PD FUNGUS WILL BE DETERMINED THROUGH THE SAMPLE TESTING OF IN-CAVE SEDIMENT, SUBSTRATE SWABBING, AND BAT GUANO.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:IT IS EXPECTED THAT DURING THE 3 YEARS OF BAT EARTHCRACK SURVEYS, APPROXIMATELY 500 PD FUNGUS SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED AND TESTED. SIX IN-CAVE BAT POPULATION SURVEYS WILL BE PERFORMED. APPROXIMATELY 1000 NIGHTS OF ACOUSTIC BAT SPECIES DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED. APPROXIMATELY 50 NIGHTTIME VIDEO RECORDING SESSIONS WILL BE COLLECTED TO ANALYZE BAT POPULATION NUMBERS.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY BENEFITS PARK VISITORS THROUGH THE CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF WILDLIFE SPECIES AND WILDLIFE VIEWING OPPORTUNITIES. BATS PLAY AN INTEGRAL ROLE IN THE RANGER-LED, PUBLIC "STAR PARTIES" IN WUPATKI. SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS WILL BE PUBLISHED TO POPULAR PARK MEDIA/INFORMATION FORMATS FOR PARK VISITOR EDUCATION.

JOSHUA TREE NATIONAL PARK (JOTR) AND RECIPIENT STAFF WILL COLLABORATE TO CONDUCT A DEMOGRAPHIC AND SPATIAL ANALYSIS OF EXISTING JOSHUA TREE DATA TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CONDITION OF JOSHUA TREES PARKWIDE. THE ANALYSIS IS BASED ON WELL-ESTABLISHED TECHNIQUES TO ASSESS SEEDLING RECRUITMENT, VEGETATIVE REPRODUCTION (SPROUTING), AND MORTALITY. THE ANALYSIS WILL LOOK AT ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS INFLUENCING THESE INDICATORS OF SPECIES' HEALTH AND DENSITY ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE USING STANDARD MIXED-EFFECTS MODELING AND OTHER MULTIVARIATE METHODS. THIS ANALYSIS WILL PROVIDE A BASIS FOR ASSESSING OTHER CLIMATE-VULNERABLE, THREATENED, OR RARE SPECIES IN THE PARK. DATA ALSO WILL BE USED TO FURTHER VALIDATE AND REFINE THE MAPPED PREDICTED AREAS OF JOSHUA TREE SURVIVAL (REFUGIA) USING SPATIAL HABITAT MODELING TOOLS. JOTR AND THE RECIPIENT PROPOSE TO USE A METHODOLOGY FOR ANALYZING PATTERNS OF AGE STRUCTURE AMONG POPULATIONS. THESE DATA MAY ALSO ADDRESS OTHER IMPORTANT KNOWLEDGE GAPS INCLUDING FLOWER/FRUIT SET AND REPRODUCTION OVER ELEVATION, AND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN FIRE AND JOSHUA TREE SURVIVAL AND RECRUITMENT.TO CONDUCT THIS DEMOGRAPHIC AND SPATIAL ANALYSIS, THE RECIPIENT WILL ANALYZE RE-SURVEY DATA FROM THE 50 PLOTS ESTABLISHED BY USGS IN 2008 WHICH WILL HAVE BEEN RESAMPLED IN 2021 BY JOTR STAFF UNDER SEPARATE FUNDING. ADDITIONALLY, THE RECIPIENT WILL ALSO ANALYZE 100 RANDOMLY LOCATED PLOTS ESTABLISHED BY JOTR STAFF FROM 2018-2020. SPECIFICALLY, THE DATA WILL BE ANALYZED TO LOOK AT JOSHUA TREE CONDITION, INCLUDING PLANT SIZE, PLANT HEALTH, NUMBER OF JUVENILES (RECRUITMENT METRIC), NUMBER OF SPROUTS, AND LIVE VERSUS DEAD RATIOS (MORTALITY METRIC). THE 50 RE-SAMPLED PLOTS WILL ALLOW FOR AN ANALYSIS THAT INCLUDES AN ACTUAL RECRUITMENT RATE AND MORTALITY RATE OVER A TWELVE-YEAR PERIOD. ADDITIONAL PROJECT INFORMATION IS INCLUDED IN THE DETAILED IMPLEMENTATION PLAN (DIP) ATTACHED. METHODOLOGY WILL BE DOCUMENTED SO AS TO BE ADAPTABLE TO ANALYZING OTHER SPECIES IN SIMILAR WAYS TO INFORM MANAGEMENT.
ASSESSING LANDSCAPE VULNERABILITY TO DROUGHT AND MEGAFIRES USING LINKED FOREST CONDITION-WATER MODELS TO GUIDE RESILIENCE PLANNING

THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE BASELINE DOCUMENTATION OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES WITHIN SELECTED STUDY AREAS AT SUMMIT LAKE AND THE THIRSTY CREEK WATERSHED, WEST DISTRICT, YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CONDUCT A WYOMING CLASS III CULTURAL RESOURCES INVENTORY, COMPLETE SITE CONDITION ASSESSMENTS, AND EVALUATE ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES FOR THEIR ELIGIBILITY FOR INCLUSION ON THE NATIONAL REGISTER OF HISTORIC PLACES (NRHP).PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:COMPLETE INVENTORY AND CREATE BASELINE DOCUMENTATION, EVALUATE CULTURAL RESOURCES ENCOUNTERED DURING INVENTORY FOR ELIGIBILITY FOR LISTING ON THE NRHP, TREAT IMPACTS FOUND AT SITES THROUGH HANDS-ON ACTIONS, DEVELOP A PRIORITIZED LIST OF NHRP-ELIGIBLE RESOURCES AND PLAN FOR MONITORING, AND DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR CULTURAL RESOURCE PROTECTION.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND LONG TERM HUMAN USE PATTERNS WITHIN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK. THE NPS RECEIVES THE INDIRECT BENEFIT OF COMPLETING CULTURAL RESOURCE INVENTORY AS REQUIRED UNDER THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT. NEWLY ACQUIRED DATA WILL AID PARK PLANNING EFFORTS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION CRITICAL TO MAKING INFORMED TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE AN INTERNSHIP SERVICE OPPORTUNITY FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO MUSEUM STUDIES PROGRAM TO GAIN VALUABLE EXPERIENCE AND FURTHER THEIR EDUCATIONAL AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT THROUGH WORK WITH THE CHACO CULTURE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (CHCU) MUSEUM PROGRAM. THE INTERNS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE MANAGEMENT, PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF CHCU ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF THE NPS CHCU CURATORIAL STAFF AND IN COORDINATION WITH THE DIRECTOR OF THE UNM MUSEUM STUDIES PROGRAM, THE STUDENT PARTICIPANTS (ONE LEAD AND TWO TEAM MEMBERS) WILL WORK TO ASSIST THE CHACO MUSEUM PROGRAM TO DIGITIZE, DESCRIBE AND PRESERVE PHOTOGRAPH COLLECTIONS IN THE CHACO ARCHIVE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE INTERNSHIP, THE LEAD STUDENT WILL 1) WRITE A BRIEF SUMMARY REPORT, INCLUDING PHOTOGRAPHS, DESCRIBING THE PROJECTS AND TASKS ACCOMPLISHED DURING THEIR EXPERIENCE WITH THE CHACO MUSEUM PROGRAM, AND 2) INTERNS WILL PREPARE NO FEWER THAN 12 SOCIAL MEDIA OUTREACH PRODUCTS ABOUT AN ASPECT OF THE DIGITIZATION PROJECT, ARCHIVAL CONTENT OF THE CHACO MUSEUM PROGRAM, OR THE INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCE. APPROXIMATELY 6000 IMAGES AND DESCRIPTIVE INFORMATION WILL BE UPLOADED TO THE NPS NPGALLERY DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT PLATFORM FOR VIEWING BY THE PUBLIC.BENEFICIARIES:UNM MUSEUM STUDIES STUDENTS; VISITORS TO CHACO CULTURE NHP; VIRTUAL VISITORS FROM AROUND THE WORLD.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE COMPLETION OF AN ETHNOGRAPHIC STUDY (ES) OF THE TA-18 AREA OF MANHATTAN PROJECT NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK BY A RESEARCH TEAM FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA (UOFA). THE STUDY WILL DOCUMENT CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL INFORMATION RELATED TO NUMEROUS AMERICAN INDIAN TRIBES WITH TIES TO THIS AREA. THE RESULTS OF THE ETHNOGRAPHIC STUDY WILL THEN BE INTEGRATED INTO A 100% DRAFT CULTURAL LANDSCAPE REPORT (CLR) OF TA-18, TO PROVIDE A GREATER AMERICAN INDIAN INTERPRETATION OF THE LANDSCAPE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES WILL INCLUDE THE UOFA RESEARCH TEAM GETTING INSTITUTIONAL REVIEW BOARD (IRB) APPROVAL TO CONDUCT THE RESEARCH STUDY. THE UOFA RESEARCH TEAM WILL INCLUDE ANTHROPOLOGISTS, LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTS, AND GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCHERS WHO WILL WORK IN COLLABORATION TO DEVELOP A RESEARCH DESIGN THAT CAN FIT THE NEEDS OF THE ETHNOGRAPHIC STUDY AND SUPPORT THE INTEGRATION OF THE ETHNOGRAPHIC INFORMATION INTO THE 100% DRAFT CLR OF TA-18. THE UOFA WILL COMPLETE BACKGROUND RESEARCH THAT DOCUMENTS THE AMERICAN INDIAN CONNECTIONS TO THE TA-18 AREA AND THE BROADER CENTRAL PAJARITO PLATEAU. BASED ON THE BACKGROUND RESEARCH, THE UOFA WILL DETERMINE ASSOCIATED TRIBES WITH THE STUDY AREA, WHICH MAY OR MAY NOT MATCH THE ASSOCIATED TRIBES LIST THE PARK CURRENTLY USES. THE UOFA WILL THEN REACH OUT TO ASSOCIATED TRIBES IN ORDER TO CONDUCT ORIGINAL ETHNOGRAPHIC FIELDWORK AT THE MANHATTAN PROJECT NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK WITH 12 AMERICAN INDIAN TRIBES. ADDITIONAL MONEY MAY BE ADDED TO THE PROJECT IF MORE THAN 12 TRIBES WISH TO PARTICIPATE. THE INFORMATION GAINED FROM THE BACKGROUND RESEARCH AND THE ETHNOGRAPHIC FIELDWORK WILL BE USED TO COMPLETE AN ES OF THE TA-18 AREA OF THE MANHATTAN PROJECT NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK, WHICH WILL BE A STAND-ALONE DOCUMENT. AFTER THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE DRAFT ES, THE UOFA RESEARCH TEAM WILL CONDUCT REVIEW MEETINGS WITH EACH OF THE PARTICIPATING AMERICAN INDIAN TRIBES, TO ENSURE THE ACCURACY OF INFORMATION AND THAT NO SENSITIVE CONTENT IS BEING PUBLISHED. AFTER REVISIONS TO THE REPORT BASED ON THE TRIBAL REVIEW SESSIONS, THE UOFA WILL PROVIDE THE NPS WITH A DRAFT REPORT TO REVIEW FOR A COMMENT PERIOD OF NO LESS THAN 30 DAYS. FOLLOWING THIS REVIEW, THE UOFA WILL ADDRESS/INCORPORATE COMMENTS AND FINALIZE THE DOCUMENT. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO RESULT IN THE UOFA INCORPORATING INFORMATION FROM THE ES INTO THE CLR.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DEVELOPMENT OF A RESEARCH DESIGN AND COMPLETION OF UOFA IRB PROCESS.A COMPREHENSIVE LITERATURE REVIEW TO IDENTIFY HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL INFORMATION ABOUT AMERICAN INDIAN TRIBES ASSOCIATED WITH THE STUDY AREA. ETHNOGRAPHIC INTERVIEWS WITH KNOWLEDGEABLE TRIBAL MEMBERS TO ELICIT INFORMATION ABOUT THE STUDY AREA. TWELVE 3-TO-4 DAY ETHNOGRAPHIC FIELD RESEARCH VISITS TO THE STUDY AREA WITH ASSOCIATED AMERICAN INDIAN TRIBES. A SUMMARY OF INFORMATION OBTAINED DURING RESEARCH ACTIVITIES COMPILED INTO AN ETHNOGRAPHIC STUDY REPORT.REVIEW SESSIONS WITH TRIBAL CONSULTANTS TO ENSURE ACCURACY OF CONTENT.DELIVERY OF TRIBALLY APPROVED ETHNOGRAPHIC REPORT TO FUNDING AGENCY.INTEGRATE THE RESULTS OF THE ETHNOGRAPHIC REPORT INTO THE DRAFT CLR PREPARED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF OREGON.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA STUDENTS, FACULTY, THE PUBLIC, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROVIDES HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE FOR POSTGRADUATES OF THE SCHOOL OF INFORMATION. POST GRADUATES WILL PERFORM BEST PRACTICES FOR PROCESSING, CATALOGING, STORAGE UPGRADE AND SCANNING OF ARCHIVESSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: WORK WITH NPS ARCHIVISTS ON BEST PRACTICES FOR CATALOGING AND SCANNING ARCHIVES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TO MAKE NPS ARCHIVES MORE ACCESSIBLE TO PUBLIC, ENHANCE PRESERVATION, TRAIN FUTURE ARCHIVISTS.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:INITIAL PROCESSING OF AN ESTIMATED 24      LINEAR FEET FINAL PROCESSING OF AN ESTIMATED 149      LINEAR FEET.CATALOGING OF AN ESTIMATED 152 LINEAR      FEET.SCANNING AND PRINTING OF AN ESTIMATED      10,000 BAG LABEL .REHOUSING OF AN ESTIMATED 143 LINEAR      FEET OF RECORDS IN APPROPRIATELY LABELED ACID-FREE FOLDERS AND BOXES.BENEFICIARIES:NPS PARKS WITH MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND UNIVERSITY POST GRADUATESTUDENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO ENGAGE STUDENTS AND RESEARCH ASSOCIATES IN PROJECTS RELATED TO GEOSPATIAL, DATA, DEVELOPMENT/APPLICATION, CLOUD, AND OTHER INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FIELDS AS THE NEXT GENERATION OF STEWARDS WHO WILL CARE FOR OUR NATIONS PARK RESOURCES AND PRESERVE THE NPS LEGACY.PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WORK WITH THE NATIONAL GEOSPATIAL PROGRAM THAT USES SPATIAL DATA, STANDARDS, AND TECHNICAL TOOLS TO PROVIDE A WAY FOR STAFF TO UNDERSTAND, PROTECT AND HELP VISITORS ENJOY OUR NATIONAL PARKS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):CONTINUE SCIENTIFIC COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA AND ORGAN PIPE CACTUS NATIONAL MONUMENT'S ECOLOGICAL MONITORING PROGRAM. PROVIDE TRAINING TO THE PARK ECOLOGIST IN ECOLOGICAL MODELLING TECHNIQUES THAT WILL ALLOW FOR MORE ACCURATE EVALUATION OF TRENDS IN NATURAL RESOURCES, BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF ECOSYSTEM DYNAMICS, AND BETTER SCIENCE COMMUNICATION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:ORGAN PIPE WILL PROVIDE DATA SETS AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTS. THE UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA WILL PROVIDE TRAINING IN ECOLOGICAL MONITORING. THE PARTNERS WILL WORK TOGETHER TO DEVELOP STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES FOR DATA MANIPULATION AND ECOLOGICAL MODELLING.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:WE WILL FIRST DEVELOP PROCEDURES FOR INTERPOLATING WEATHER DATA AND FILLING IN GAPS. WE WILL CLEAN UP LONG-TERM MONITORING DATA SETS FOR VERTEBRATE COMMUNITIES INCLUDING REPTILES, BIRDS, AND MAMMALS. WE WILL UPDATE THE ANALYSIS OF LIZARD DATA FIRST ACCOMPLISHED IN 2017 AND THEN MODIFY THE TECHNIQUES TO ANALYZE THE DATA SETS FOR BIRDS AND MAMMALS. THIS SET OF PROCEDURES WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE PROTOCOLS FOR THE MONITORING PROGRAM.BENEFICIARIES:ORGAN PIPE CACTUS NATIONAL MONUMENT'S ECOLOGICAL MONITORING PROGRAM, RESOURCE MANAGERS, THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY, AND THE PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A TRADITIONAL USE STUDY FOR SUMMIT LAKE AND THE THIRSTY CREEK WATERSHED, WEST DISTRICT, YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK (YNP).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:1) COMPLETE A TRADITIONAL USE STUDY FOR SUMMIT LAKE AND THE THIRSTY CREEK WATERSHED, MADISON PLATEAU, WEST DISTRICT, YELLOWSTONE NP; AND 2) DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR PROTECTION OF RESOURCES IDENTIFIED IN THE TRADITIONAL USE STUDY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE TRADITIONAL RESOURCE USE STUDY WILL RESULT IN ORAL HISTORIES AND A SUMMARY WRITTEN REPORT WHICH WILL COMPILE, DESCRIBE, AND EVALUATE THOSE HISTORIES REGARDING TRADITIONAL USE AND MANAGEMENT OF RESOURCES AT SUMMIT LAKE AND WITHIN THE THIRSTY CREEK WATERSHED. RECIPIENT WILL COMPLETE TRADITIONAL USE STUDY WITH WRITTEN FINAL REPORT, PROVIDE ASSOCIATED GIS DATA, AND COMPLETE AND TRANSCRIBE ALL ORAL INTERVIEWS. BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND LONG TERM HUMAN USE PATTERNS WITHIN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK. THE NPS RECEIVES THE INDIRECT BENEFIT OF COMPLETING CULTURAL RESOURCE INVENTORY AS REQUIRED UNDER THE NATIONAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION ACT. NEWLY ACQUIRED DATA WILL AID PARK PLANNING EFFORTS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION CRITICAL TO MAKING INFORMED TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE: ZION NATIONAL PARK WILL PARTNER WITH SOUTHERN UTAH UNIVERSITY'S IIC TO RECRUIT INTERNS AND YOUTH CREWS TO SERVE ALL AREAS OF THE PARK. THE IIC PROMOTES PROFESSIONALISM IN LAND STEWARDSHIP, CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO PARTICIPATE IN PAID INTERNSHIPS AS PART OF THEIR FORMAL EDUCATION TO CONSERVE & PRESERVE CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES WHILE EFFECTIVELY SERVING COMMUNITIES AND PARK VISITORS.ACTIVITIES: ZION'S INTERNS WILL GAIN SKILLS IN ALL FUNCTIONAL AREAS OF THE PARK: INTERPRETATION, EDUCATION, AND VISITOR SERVICES, NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, FEE COLLECTION, RESEARCH, VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT, INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES (IT), SUSTAINABILITY, WILDERNESS, FACILITIES/MAINTENANCE, TRAIL CREW, RANGE MANAGEMENT, ADMINISTRATION, AND OTHER SPECIALTIES. INTERNS RECEIVE ACADEMIC CREDIT AND ARE ASSESSED UTILIZING SUU'S ESSENTIAL LEARNING OUTCOMES. INTERNS WILL PARTICIPATE IN ZION'S FORMAL MENTORSHIP PROGRAM WITH WORKSHOPS AROUND ESTABLISHING GOALS, NETWORKING, AND RESUME BUILDING. PROJECT TITLE - ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT OF CHARLES PINCKNEY NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE AND FORT SUMTER AND FORT MOULTRIE NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARKPROJECT STATEMENT - THE ETHNOGRAPHIC OVERVIEW AND ASSESSMENT WILL BE CONDUCTED TO PROVIDE BASELINE DATA ON TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED GROUPS, THE PARK RESOURCES WITH WHICH THEY ARE ASSOCIATED, AND DESCRIPTION OF THE TRADITIONAL USES OF AND ASSOCIATIONS WITH THESE RESOURCES, HISTORICALLY AND CURRENTLY.PERFORMANCE GOAL - CHPI AND FOSU WILL GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED GROUPS AND THE ETHNOGRAPHIC RESOURCES THEY VALUE. THIS STUDY WILL INFORM THE STEWARDSHIP OF ETHNOGRAPHIC RESOURCES, THE INTERPRETATION OF ETHNOGRAPHIC RESOURCES AND TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED GROUPS, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PERCEPTIONS OF THE PARK AREAS AND THE EFFECTS OF PARK MANAGEMENT ON THE TRADITIONAL PRACTICES AND USES OF THESE COMMUNITIES AND GROUPS.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES --THIS PROJECT WILL BRIEFLY DESCRIBE THE BROAD HISTORY OF COMMUNITY FORMATION, GROWTH, AND CHANGE IN THE REGION AND SPECIFICALLY THOSE COMMUNITIES LYING WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO CHPI AND FOSU.-THIS PROJECT WILL RESEARCH POTENTIAL TRIBAL ASSOCIATIONS TO RESOURCES NOW MANAGED BY CHPI AND FOSU, OR DOCUMENT THE LACK OF CONTEMPORARY ASSOCIATIONS BY STATE OR FEDERALLY-RECOGNIZED TRIBES.-THE COOPERATOR WILL DOCUMENT THE DEMOGRAPHIC, CULTURAL, AND HISTORICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE COMMUNITIES AND NEIGHBORHOODS.MILESTONES - PHASE I: SEPTEMBER 2022 - APRIL 2023REVIEW AND SYNTHESIS OF EXISTING HISTORIC AND ETHNOGRAPHIC INFORMATION RELATED TO ASSOCIATIONS TO CHPI AND FOSU.PHASE II: APRIL 2023 - JULY 2023FIELDWORK, INTERVIEWS, CONSULTATION AND REPORT PREPARATION.PHASE III: JULY 2023 - FEBRUARY 2024SYNTHESIS OF PHASE I AND II AND PREPARATION OF REPORT.ASSISTANCE LISTING -15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

DELIVER INITIAL DYNAMIC SOIL SURVEYS FOR ACADIA, CUYAHOGA VALLEY, AND MINUTE MAN NATIONAL PARKS TO SUPPORT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT NEEDS.AT THE END OF THE TERM OF THIS AGREEMENT, THE RECIPIENT WILL HAVE RECRUITED A POSTDOCTORAL FELLOW TO CONDUCT DATA COLLECTION TO SUPPORT THE MONITORING, MODELING, AND MAPPING TASKS REQUIRED TO DEVELOP INITIAL DYNAMIC SOIL SURVEYS THAT WILL IMPROVE UPON THE AVAILABLE SOIL AND ECOLOGICAL INVENTORIES FOR THE SELECTED NATIONAL PARK SERVICE UNITS. FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: P-P-CESU-22-006PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):FORESTS IN DEVILS POSTPILE NATIONAL MONUMENT AND THE SURROUNDING MUCH LARGER INYO NATIONAL FOREST WERE IMPACTED BY SEVERAL LARGE FIRES OVER THE PAST FEW DECADES AND A LARGE WINDSTORM EVENT 10 YEARS AGO.THEY ARE MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT SALVAGE LOGGING, THINNING REMNANT STANDS, AND OTHER FUEL AND VEGETATION MANAGEMENT, WITH SEVERAL YEARS OF LARGE-SCALE WORK STARTING IN SUMMER 2023.BEFORE TARGETING THINNING AND/OR PRESCRIBED BURNING OF REMNANT PATCHES OF DENSE INTACT FOREST, MODERATELY DAMAGED FORESTS, OR SALVAGE LOGGING OF SUBSTANTIALLY BLOWN-DOWN AREAS, THEY NEED TO KNOW IF 3 BAT SPECIES OF CONSERVATION CONCERN (TOWNSEND'S BIG-EARED BAT, PALLID BAT, FRINGED MYOTIS), BATS IN GENERAL, OR CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS ARE USING THESE FOREST TYPES. THEY WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO DETERMINE HOW TO BEST PROTECT HABITAT USED BY THESE SPECIES.THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO IDENTIFY AS CLOSE AS POSSIBLE TO THE FULL COMPLEMENT OF SPECIES OF BATS USING DEVILS POSTPILE NATIONAL MONUMENT, OPPORTUNISTICALLY FIND EVIDENCE OF CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS, AND USE THIS INFORMATION TO INFORM FUELS TREATMENT ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT ANY OF THESE SPECIES DETECTED AT DEVILS POSTPILE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:USE ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS TO IDENTIFY THE SPECIES OF BATS USING THE DEVILS POSTPILE LANDSCAPE. USE ACTIVE CALL SURVEYS TO ASSESS WHETHER CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS ARE LIKELY TO BE USING THE DEVILS POSTPILE LANDSCAPE.INFORM NPS OF THE MAGNITUDE OF DIFFERENCE (IF ANY) IN BAT USE OF AREAS OF DIFFERENT DISTURBANCE LEVEL WITHIN THE LANDSCAPE. IF DETECTED, COMMUNICATE THE PRESENCE OF CALIFORNIA SPOTTED OWLS AND/OR THE THREE BAT SPECIES IDENTIFIED AS BEING OF CONSERVATION CONCERN TO ALLOW THEM TO TAKE ANY REQUIRED FURTHER ACTION. PROVIDE INFORMATION NEEDED TO MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT WHICH AREAS TO CONDUCT FUELS TREATMENTS IN THE SUMMER OF 2023, IN ORDER TO MINIMIZE DISTURBANCE TO FOCAL SPECIES AND TO AVOID REMOVAL OR ALTERATION OF IMPORTANT HABITAT.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TEN ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS WILL BE DEPLOYED THROUGHOUT THE MONUMENT IN SUMMER OF 2022. FIELD STAFF WILL SEARCH FOR POTENTIAL BAT ROOST AND FORAGING SITES AND WILL CONDUCT ACTIVE CALL SURVEYS FOR OWLS. DATA ANALYSIS AND CHECKING WILL OCCUR IN THE FALL OF 2022. THE FINAL DATA AND REPORT WILL BE COMPLETE BY SPRING 2023.BENEFICIARIES:THE INSTITUTE FOR BIRD POPULATIONSLA KRETZ CENTER FOR CALIFORNIA CONSERVATION SCIENCE

TO COLLECT PRESENCE/ABSENCE DISTRIBUTION DATA FOR DIAMONDBACK TERRAPINS AT THREE NATIONAL PARK UNITS - FIRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE, SAGAMORE HILL NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE AND SANDY HOOK NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. UNDERSTANDING THE DISTRIBUTION AND OCCURRENCE OF NESTING DIAMONDBACK TERRAPINS IS CRITICAL FOR STUDYING AND MONITORING RECRUITMENT TO POPULATIONS, CONSIDERING MANAGEMENT ALTERNATIVES OF NESTING AREAS OR PROTECTING LIVE NESTS. ADDITIONALLY, KNOWING THE SPATIAL ARRANGEMENT OF NESTS ALLOWS FOR STUDYING THE INFLUENCE OF IMPENDING ANTHROPOGENIC THREATS, SUCH AS CLIMATE CHANGE, ON VULNERABLE NESTING AREAS.THE PERFORMANCE GOALS ARE TO GATHER QUALITY ASSURED BIOLOGICAL DATA UTILIZING A STUDY DESIGN PLAN THAT WILL BE APPROVED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE INVENTORY PROGRAM IN A MANNER WHICH WILL PERMIT ANALYSIS WITHIN AND ACROSS MANAGEMENT BOUNDARIES AND PROVIDE CORRELATIONS BETWEEN FLORISTIC AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS.THE OBJECTIVE FOR THIS WORK WILL BE THE COMPLETION OF FULL DATA REPORT ON THE STATUS OF NESTING ON THE AFOREMENTIONED NPS AREAS, INCLUDING A PROJECT NARRATIVE, METHODS USED, INFORMATION FROM POINT COUNT ESTIMATES AND NESTING INFORMATION FOR EACH AREA SURVEYED SPATIAL INFORMATION FROM GIS, NESTING FEMALE MORPHOLOGY, NESTING METADATA AND NEST FATES WHEN AVAILABLE. THE REPORT WILL INCLUDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PARK MANAGEMENT ON HOW TO MANAGE AND PROTECT DIAMONDBACK TERRAPINS AT THESE THREE PARK UNITS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):ALLOW THE PARK TO WORK WITH SCIENCE STAFF FROM THE ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION INSTITUTE AT NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY TO DEVELOP RESTORATION OBJECTIVES FOR RESTORING PONDEROSA PINE FOREST HABITAT IN USING MECHANICAL TREATMENTS PRIOR TO PRESCRIBED BURNING.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:IN ORDER TO GUIDE TREATMENT ACTIONS, THE NAU ERI WILL INVESTIGATE HISTORIC CONDITIONS OF PARK PONDEROSA FORESTS PRIOR TO HUMAN DISRUPTION OF NATURAL FIRE CYCLES USING AVAILABLE AND NEWLY COLLECTED DATA, USING THAT INFORMATION RECOMMEND SPECIFICATIONS FOR RESTORATION ACTIONS, AND DEVELOP MONITORING PROTOCOLS FOR EVALUATING TREATMENT EFFICACY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES (IF APPLICABLE) AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF HABITAT QUALITY FOR SEVERAL PARK WILDLIFE SPECIES. FOREST COMMUNITIES WILL BE MORE RESILIENT TO DISTURBANCES, SUCH AS WILDFIRE, WHICH WILL IMPROVE THE SAFETY OF THE VISITING PUBLIC AND PARK INFRASTRUCTURE.BENEFICIARIES: NAU STUDENTS

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):IN PARTNERSHIP WITH PETRIFIED FOREST NATIONAL PARK (PEFO), THE MUSEUM OF NORTHERN ARIZONA (MNA) WILL DOCUMENT AND ADVISE ON WAYS TO MITIGATE FUTURE EROSION OF ARCHEOLOGICAL SITE PEFO 01003 (PEFO 2013A-262) AND REDUCE EROSIONAL IMPACTS TO BURIALS AND OTHER FEATURES AT THE SITE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:IN CONSULTATION WITH TRIBES, PEFO AND MNA WILL COLLABORATE TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING: BACKGROUND RESEARCH AND RESEARCH DESIGN; BASELINE ARCHEOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT; CONDITION ASSESSMENTS AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL STUDY; EXCAVATION, RECORDATION, AND REPOSITIONING OF BURIALS; EXCAVATION AND DOCUMENTATION OF STRUCTURES THREATENED BY EROSION; ANALYSIS OF DATA; DRAFT AND FINAL REPORT; PUBLIC PRESENTATIONS; AND DEVELOP AN EROSIONAL CONTROL PLAN. PHASE TWO WITH INSTALL THESE CONTROLS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:FOLLOWING THE RESEARCH DESIGN THAT WILL BE PREPARED BY PEFO AND MNA, THE COOPERATORS WILL COMPLETE AN ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL SURVEY OF PEFO 01003 IN CONSULTATION WITH TRIBES THAT INCLUDES DOCUMENTATION AND EXCAVATION OF BURIAL SITES AND STRUCTURES THREATENED BY EROSION IN ADDITION TO THE REPOSITIONING OF BURIALS. A DRAFT AND FINAL REPORT WILL BE PREPARED SHARING PROJECT FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR EROSION CONTROL MEASURES THAT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED IN PHASE 2 SHOULD ADDITIONAL FUNDING BE AWARDED. PROJECT FINDINGS WILL ALSO BE SHARED AT PUBLIC AND PROFESSIONAL PRESENTATION EVENTS. EROSIONAL CONTROLS WILL BE INSTALLED ON-SITE AS NEEDED.BENEFICIARIES:TRIBES, SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND RESEARCHERS INCLUDING ARCHAEOLOGISTS, AND GENERAL PUBLIC.

: COPPER RIVER (CR) SOCKEYE SALMON POPULATIONS (STOCKS) ARE AMONG THE MOST SIGNIFICANT NATURAL RESOURCES OF WRANGELL-ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE (WRST). ECOLOGICALLY, THEY REPRESENT A VITAL SOURCE OF ENERGY AND MARINE-DERIVED NUTRIENTS TO PARK ECOSYSTEMS. CULTURALLY, THEY ARE CENTRAL TO THE TRADITIONS AND SUBSISTENCE PRACTICES OF INDIGENOUS AHTNA AND OTHER RURAL RESIDENTS AFFILIATED WITH THE CR DRAINAGE (FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE USERS) AND ARE VALUED BY MANY ALASKA RESIDENTS WHO PARTICIPATE IN SEVERAL STATE-MANAGED (ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME, ADF&G) FISHERIES THAT HARVEST CR SOCKEYE. SOCKEYE SALMON OF THE CR ALSO REPRESENT A CRUCIAL ECONOMIC RESOURCE TO THOSE WHO PARTICIPATE IN CR FISHERIES AND TO THE REGION, WITH SOCKEYE SALMON HARVESTED IN THE COMMERCIAL GILLNET DRIFT FISHERY (WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR APPROXIMATELY 84% OF THE ANNUAL CR SOCKEYE SALMON HARVEST) VALUED UP TO $40M ANNUALLY. BY FAR, SOCKEYE SALMON IS THE SINGLE MOST IMPORTANT SUBSISTENCE RESOURCE FOR MANY OF THE RURAL ALASKA COMMUNITIES AFFILIATED WITH WRST, AS MEASURED BY MEAN ANNUAL HARVEST WEIGHT PER HOUSEHOLD.FISHERIES THAT HARVEST CR SOCKEYE SALMON ARE MANAGED TO ACHIEVE SPECIFIED GOALS FOR DRAINAGE-WIDE ESCAPEMENT (DEFINED AS THE ANNUAL ESTIMATED AMOUNT OF SPAWNING SOCKEYE SALMON), WITH ESCAPEMENT GOALS SPECIFIED WITHIN RANGES NECESSARY FOR CONSERVING AND SUSTAINING LONG-TERM SALMON PRODUCTION AND MAINTAINING NORMAL ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONING. IN ADDITION TO ESCAPEMENT AMOUNT, ESCAPEMENT IS TO BE MANAGED IN A MANNER THAT MAINTAINS GENETIC AND PHENOTYPIC CHARACTERISTICS OF CR SOCKEYE SALMON STOCKS BY ASSURING APPROPRIATE GEOGRAPHIC AND TEMPORAL DISTRIBUTION OF SPAWNERS THROUGHOUT THE CR DRAINAGE, INCLUDING THE SIGNIFICANT PROPORTION OF SOCKEYE SALMON DESTINED FOR SPAWNING GROUNDS IN WRST. THESE STOCK CHARACTERISTICS, AS WELL AS SIZE RANGE, SEX RATIO, AND OTHER POPULATION ATTRIBUTES ARE ENCOMPASSED BY THE CONCEPT OF ESCAPEMENT QUALITY.IN 2018 AND AGAIN IN 2020, UNEXPECTEDLY LOW NUMBERS OF SOCKEYE SALMON RETURNED TO THE CR DRAINAGE SYSTEM FROM THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT, WITH DRAMATIC CONSEQUENCES FOR CR FISHERIES AND STAKEHOLDERS. THESE INCLUDED THE UNPRECEDENTED CLOSURE OF THE COMMERCIAL FISHERY FOR 41 CONSECUTIVE DAYS IN 2018 AND ONLY FISHING SEVEN PERIODS IN 2020; THE FIRST-EVER CLOSURE OF THE STATE SUBSISTENCE FISHERY IN 2018; AND EXPANDED CLOSURES OF THE PERSONAL USE FISHERY IN 2018 AND 2020. IN 2018, CONCERN AMONG FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE USERS ABOUT THE LOW SOCKEYE SALMON RETURN AND IMPACTS OF STATE-MANAGED FISHERIES ON SOCKEYE SALMON STOCKS RESULTED IN UNPRECEDENTED WRITTEN REQUESTS THAT THE WRST SUPERINTENDENT ISSUE EMERGENCY SPECIAL ACTIONS CLOSING ONE OR MORE STATE FISHERIES PURSUANT TO HIS DELEGATED AUTHORITY FROM THE FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE BOARD.IN ADDITION TO RECENT RELATIVELY LOW NUMBERS OF RETURNING CR SOCKEYE SALMON, THERE HAS BEEN A LONG-TERM DECLINE IN BODY SIZE OF RETURNING CR SOCKEYE SALMON, WHICH MAY BE AN IMPORTANT BIOLOGICAL FACTOR CONTRIBUTING TO RECENT LOW ESCAPEMENT. SMALLER FISH MAY BE MORE LIKELY TO SUFFER EN-ROUTE (PRE-SPAWNING) MORTALITY, POTENTIALLY DRIVEN BY IMPACTS OF CHANGING MARINE CONDITIONS (WARMING AND COMPETITION) ON HEALTH PARAMETERS AND THE CAPACITY OF SOCKEYE SALMON TO RESPOND TO CHANGING RIVERINE CONDITIONS (FLOW AND TEMPERATURE REGIMES).IN THIS CONTEXT, THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES IN THE GULF OF ALASKA AND THE CR WATERSHED MAY IMPACT SPAWNING MIGRATION SUCCESS BY SOCKEYE SALMON UNDER FUTURE ECOLOGICAL SCENARIOS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO INTEGRATE PRIOR AND ONGOING RADIO-TELEMETRY DATA ON CR SOCKEYE SPAWNING MIGRATION WITH SEVERAL LONG-TERM ADF&G DATA SETS TO DEVELOP FORECASTING MODELS FOR SOCKEYE THAT WOULD INCORPORATE NEW INFORMATION FROM A RECENTLY AVAILABLE HYDROLOGICAL MODEL DEVELOPED BY USGS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE THE CONDITION OF CR SOCKEYE STOCKS AS INDICATED BY MIGRATORY SUCCESS AND INCIDENCE OF EN ROUTE OR PRE-SPAWN MORTALITY.
