THE EXPECTED RESULT OF THIS REPORT IS TO ESTABLISH COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WITH NEW USER GROUP AND DEVELOP CONSISTENT NPS COMMUNITY GARDEN MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES FOR THE THIRTEEN NPS COMMUNITY GARDENS. THIS REPORT IS ESSENTIAL TO THE PRESERVATION, PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT OF THIS UNIQUE PARK ETHNOGRAPHIC RESOURCES, FOSTERING BETTER COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS AND ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES THAT ARE CULTURALLY COMPETENT.

REQUIREMENTS FOR ALL AGREEMENTSPURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE OVERALL GOAL AND OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AND CONDUCT A VISITOR STUDY TO GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT TOURISTS' SERVICE AND EXPERIENCE PREFERENCES AT BENT'S OLD FORT NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE IN COLORADO IN ORDER TO INFORM THE NPS TOURISM TOOLKIT. THE NPS REQUIRES VALID AND RELIABLE DATA FROM VISITORS TO THE FORT THAT IS USEFUL FOR PLANNING AND PROMOTION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:TO ADDRESS THE INFORMATION NEEDS OF NPS PARK MANAGERS, ASU RESEARCHERS WITH THE CENTER FOR SUSTAINABLE TOURISM IN THE SCHOOL OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES AND DEVELOPMENT, IN COOPERATION WITH NPS, WILL IMPLEMENT A VISITOR STUDY AT BENT'S OLD FORT NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE (BEOL). ASU WILL DEVELOP AND CONDUCT A VISITOR STUDY TO DEVELOP A DETAILED PROFILE OF CURRENT PARK VISITORS. SPECIFIC QUESTIONS WILL BE DEVELOPED IN COOPERATION WITH BEOL STAFF, THE INTERMOUNTAIN REGION VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM COORDINATOR, THE INTERMOUNTAIN REGION PROGRAM MANAGER FOR NATIONAL HERITAGE AREAS, THE WASO TOURISM PROGRAM STAFF, AND NPS SOCIAL SCIENCE PROGRAM'S STAFF. THESE INCLUDE: VISITORS' INTEREST IN, AND SATISFACTION WITH, EXISTING SERVICES, FACILITIES AND EXPERIENCES (I.E., ACCESS FOR THE DISABLED, THE GUIDED TOUR, SELF-GUIDED TOUR, INTERPRETIVE TRAIL, PARKING LOT SHUTTLE, VISITOR CENTER AND EXHIBITS, EVENTS, AND BOOK STORE); VISITORS' PREFERENCES FOR ADDITIONAL FACILITIES AND EXPERIENCES (I.E., NIGHT SKY PROGRAMS, LIVING HISTORY PROGRAMS, EVENTS, AND PHOTOGRAPHY WORKSHOPS); VISITOR'S TRIP PLANNING AND DECISION-MAKING BEHAVIOR (I.E., HOW LONG IN ADVANCE DECISIONS WERE MADE, WHAT INFORMATION WAS USED, PERCEPTION OF COST VS. VALUE OF THE VISIT); TRAVEL PROFILE OF VISITORS (MOTIVES, ACTIVITIES, TRIP LENGTH, ACCOMMODATIONS USED, TRAVEL PARTY COMPOSITION, OTHER ATTRACTIONS VISITED, SPENDING PATTERNS); AND BASIC DEMOGRAPHICS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:DEVELOP AND ADMINISTER A VISITOR STUDY AT BENT'S OLD FORT NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE WITH THE OBJECTIVE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND VISITOR INTERESTS, SATISFACTION, PREFERENCES, MOTIVES, TRIP CHARACTERISTICS, AND DEMOGRAPHICS.SPECIFICALLY, ASU WILL:1) CONDUCT PRE-STUDY LOGISTICS (I.E. COORDINATE MEETINGS WITH BEOL AND NPS REGIONAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE STAFF TO DISCUSS PROJECT GOALS, SURVEY DEVELOPMENT, AND ADMINISTRATION).2) DEVELOP VISITOR SURVEY AND OBTAIN OMB APPROVAL WITH NPS ASSISTANCE.3) ADMINISTER SURVEY TO PARK VISITORS.4) CONDUCT SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT ANALYSIS.5) ANALYZE SURVEY DATA.6) PROVIDE RESULTS REPORT IN THE NPS NRSS FORMAT THAT IS 508 COMPLIANTBENEFICIARIES: BENT'S OLD FORT NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE, ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY (FACULTY AND STUDENTS), AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC

THIS AWARD WILL FUND THE ANALYSIS OF DNA EXTRACTION AND SPECIES IDENTIFICATION AND PRESERVATION BY ARCHIVING OF ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SAMPLES COLLECTED AT SPRINGS ACROSS 9 NATIONAL PARK UNITS. APPROXIMATELY 550 SAMPLES WILL BE ANALYZED.GOALS INCLUDE COLLECTING 550 ENVIRONMENTAL DNA SAMPLES AND COMPANION WATER SAMPLES. EXTRACT EDNA FROM THE FILTERS AND COMPARE TO KNOWN ASSAYS OF TARGET SPECIES.EXTRACT AND PRESERVE AN ARCHIVAL SPECIMEN FOR EACH FILTER. ANALYZE THE DERIVED SPECIES OCCURRENCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL DATA IN THE CONTACT OF ECOLOGICAL THREATS. COMPLETE EDNA ANALYSIS, SPECIES OCCURRENCE AND SAMPLE PRESERVATION BY AUGUST 2023.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT WILL SYSTEMICALLY REASSESS THE CONDITIONS OF PREVIOUSLY RECORDED ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES WITHIN SEVERAL, SPECIFIED CORRIDORS OF BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK (BIBE) PRONE TO PARTICULARLY HIGH VOLUMES OF HUMAN AND LIVESTOCK TRESPASS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:DURING THESE SITE REVISITS THE RECIPIENT WILL A) CONDUCT A CONDITION REASSESSMENT OF THE SITE AND DOCUMENT DAMAGE/DISTURBANCE TO THE SITES AND CLASSIFY THE TYPE OF DISTURBANCE AND DEGREE OF DISTURBANCE, B) RECORD SITE LOCATION CENTER POINT WITH A SUB-METER ACCURACY GPS AND ESTABLISH, BASED ON SURFICIALLY OBSERVABLE ARTIFACTS, FEATURES, OR TOPOGRAPHIC RESTRICTIONS, THE ESTIMATED SITE BOUNDARIES, C) PHOTOGRAPH THE SITE OVERVIEW WITH SCALE AND PHOTO BOARD AND DATE WITHIN PICTURE AND PROVIDE PHOTOS OF ANY SPECIFIC DAMAGE OR DISTURBANCE (ANTHROPOGENIC, LIVESTOCK, OR OTHER NATURAL DISTURBANCE) TO PHOTO DOCUMENT SITE CONDITION, D) COLLECT BASIC SITE INFORMATION DATA NECESSARY FOR TEXAS ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESEARCH LAB (TARL) SITE FORM SUBMISSION FOR SITES MISSING TRINOMIALS OR AS SITE-REVISIT FORMS TO UPDATE SITE CONDITIONS FOR THOSE WITH PREVIOUSLY ISSUED TRINOMIALS, E) PROVIDE ALL DATA TO BIBE IN ELECTRONIC FORM FORMAT CONSISTENT WITH THE NPS CULTURAL RESOURCE INVENTORY SYSTEM (CRIS) AND TARL SITE DATABASE NEEDSPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:CUMULATIVELY, THIS ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE DAMAGE ASSESSMENT PROJECT WILL ENCOMPASS AN AREA OFROUGHLY18,896 ACRESAND INVOLVE THE REASSESSMENT OF APPROXIMATELY39PREVIOUSLY RECORDED ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES.THE SITE CONDITION DATA COLLECTEDDURING THIS PROJECT SHALLCONFORM WITH STANDARD NPSCRITERIAFOR GAUGING ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE CONDITION.EACH REVISITED SITE WILL BE SYSTEMATICALLY PHOTOGRAPHED USING AMEASURING SCALE AND A PHOTO BOARD DISPLAYING THE SITE TRINOMIAL AND DATE.A FINAL REPORT WILL BE GENERATED IN THE FORM OF A FINAL TECHNICAL MEMO, SUMMARIZING THE SITE CONDITION REASSESSMENT PROJECT AND ITS FINDINGS AND OFFERING RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MITIGATION OF FURTHER SITE DEGRADATION WITHIN HEAVILY TRAFFICKED CORRIDORS OF BIBE. THIS REPORT WILL CONFORM TO ALL NPS AND TEXAS HISTORICAL COMMISSION (THC) STANDARDS.BENEFICIARIES: THE PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THIS PROJECT'S OBJECTIVE IS TO MONITOR GRAZING INTENSITY ON BROWSE PLANTS USING THE STEM COUNT METHOD. THE EXPECTED RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF PARK STAFF AND PARTNERS ON AOUDAD IMPACTS ON PARK RESOURCES THROUGH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN ESTABLISHING EXCLOSURES ON PLANTS TO PREVENT GRAZING FROM AOUDAD, WHILE ALSO CONDUCTING BROWSE SURVEYS AND MONITORING PLANT GROWTH. REMOTE CAMERAS WILL ALSO BE OPERATED TO DETERMINE UNGULATE SPECIES VISITATION FREQUENCY AND ABUNDANCE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:USE 40 REMOTE CAMERAS, TWO AT EACH NON-EXCLOSED MONITORING SITE, TO DETERMINE UNGULATE SPECIES VISITATION FREQUENCY AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE AT MONITORED BROWSE PLANTS. WE WILL UTILIZE TWO CAMERAS AT EACH SITE, PLACED ON OPPOSITE SIDES OF MONITORED AREAS FACING EACH OTHER, TO ENSURE FULL VISIBILITY OF ALL ANIMALS USING THE SITE. THEY WILL BE PLACED APPROXIMATELY 30 M APART TO ENSURE FULL FIELD OF VIEW OF THE MONITORED AREA. PROPORTIONAL INTENSITY OF AOUDAD BROWSING WILL BE CALCULATED AS THE PROPORTION OF ALL VISITING UNGULATES THAT ARE AOUDAD, RATHER THAN TOTAL TIME SPENT BY AOUDAD, WHICH MAY NOT CORRELATE WELL WITH FORAGE INTAKE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO DETERMINE THE MAGNITUDE OF AOUDAD (AMMOTRAGUS LERVIA) IMPACTS ON THE LANDSCAPE THROUGH FIELD MONITORING OF AOUDAD, VEGETATION, AND SOILS. THE STUDY AIMS TO QUANTIFY THE DIFFERENCE IN BROWSE FORAGE BETWEEN PLANTS EXCLUDED AND NON-EXCLUDED FROM AOUDAD GRAZING ACROSS FORT DAVIS NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE (FODA). BENEFICIARIES: THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND/OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS GAINS BY NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH RESEARCH AND RELATED RESULTS DISSEMINATION OF NATURAL, CULTURAL AND/OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE INFORMATION.PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE GOVERNMENT'S OBJECTIVE TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO LEARN ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT BY SPENDING TIME WORKING ON PROJECTS IN NATIONAL PARKS. THE NPS RECEIVES THE INDIRECT BENEFIT OF COMPLETING CONSERVATION PROJECTS.PROJECT WILL MOTIVATE YOUTH PARTICIPANTS TO BECOME INVOLVED IN THE NATURAL, CULTURAL AND /OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE PROTECTION OF THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):HAMPTON NATIONAL HISTORIC SITE IS REQUESTING A GIS SPECIALIST TO LINK A 700-SPECIMEN TREE DATABASE THAT DEFINES THE PARK'S CULTURAL LANDSCAPE TO ARCGIS ONLINE SUCH THAT IT IS EASILY ACCESSED IN A WEB MAP. ONCE LINKED, THE GIS SPECIALIST WILL FIELD VERIFY THE TREE DATA FIELDS AND FILL IN MISSING INFORMATION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:TASK 1 - GIS SPECIALIST BRINGS THE EXCEL INFORMATION INTO ARCGIS PRO AND CONNECT THE GEOMETRY TO THE TABULAR DATA FROM EXCEL.TASK 2 - GIS SPECIALIST WILL SEE THAT A RESULTING NEW FEATURE CLASS BE PUBLISHED TO ARCGIS ONLINE AND ACCESSIBLE THROUGH A WEB MAP.TASK 3 - GIS SPECIALIST UPDATES POINTS AND TABULAR INFORMATION BASED ON CURRENT FIELD ASSESSMENTS INTO THE EDITABLE COPY OF THE NEW FEATURE CLASS.TASK 4 - GIS SPECIALIST TRAINS THE PARK HORTICULTURIST TO USE THE ARCGIS WEBMAP AND ADD NEW FIELD DATA TO THE NEW FEATURE LAYER.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TASKS 1, 2, 3 SHOULD EACH TAKE 2-3 DAYS. TASK 3 INVOLVES ASSESSING THE 700 TREES AT HAMPTON. THE SPECIALIST SHOULD BE ABLE TO DO AT LEAST 10 TREES PER DAY, PROBABLY CLOSER TO 20.BENEFICIARIES:STUDENT INTERN WILL BE ABLE PRACTICE GIS DATABASE LINKING AND LEARN TREE IDENTIFICATION AND CONDITION ASSESSMENT. THE NPS WILL GAIN A CULTURAL LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT AND INTERPRETATION TOOL.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GREAT HOUSE IS A FOUR-STORY STRUCTURE USED BY THE ANCIENT SONORAN DESERT CULTURE GROUP, CONSTRUCTED OF CARBONATE-RICH SOIL (CALICHE) PUDDLED IN COURSES OR LAYERS, AND OCCUPIED FROM CA. 1350-1450 C.E. MOST OF THE WALLS RETAIN ANCIENT EARTHEN PLASTERS, DECORATIVE WASHES, AND REMNANTS OF ARCHITECTURAL DETAILS LIKE VIGA SOCKETS, IMPRESSIONS OF WOOD LINTELS, AND POSSIBLY ASTRONOMICAL FEATURES.ROOF/FLOOR FRAMES NO LONGER SURVIVE IN THE GREAT HOUSE, AND RESEARCHERS MUST RELY ON VIGA SOCKETS AND OTHER IMPRESSIONS LEFT BY ROOF FRAMING MEMBERS IN DECIPHERING ORIGINAL ROOF CONFIGURATIONS, INNOVATIONS IN THEIR CONSTRUCTION, THE LOCATION OF ROOF HATCHES, EVIDENCE OF FRAME REPAIR AND REPLACEMENT, ETC. MANY OF THESE VIGA SOCKETS CURRENTLY SERVE AS NESTING PLACES FOR PIGEONS AND OTHER ANIMAL PESTS, AND THIS OCCUPATION RESULTS IN THE SUBSTANTIAL DEGRADATION OF ORIGINAL ARCHITECTURAL FABRIC.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:TO ACCOMPLISH THIS WORK, THE COOPERATOR WILL WORK WITH THE PARK TO PRIORITIZE CONSERVATION AND REPAIR OF PEST-RELATED ARCHITECTURAL DAMAGE AT THE CASA GRANDE GREAT HOUSE. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF EXCLUSIONS FOR WALL CRACKS AND VIGA SOCKETS TO PREVENT FUTURE DAMAGE. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:CONDUCTING A PROJECT CALLED "EARTHEN MATERIALS CONSERVATION FOR THE GREAT HOUSE, CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT" FOR STUDENTS, NPS STAFF, AND PROFESSIONAL PARTNERS, AND FOCUSED ON:AN INITIAL SCOPING MEETING WITH CAGR AND SOAR TO PRIORITIZE THE CONSERVATION INTERVENTIONS ESSENTIAL TO MEETING THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF THE PARK; THE PRIORITIZED LIST IS LIKELY TO INCLUDE ACTIONS FOCUSED ON PEST MANAGEMENT AS WELL AS THE CONSERVATION OF EARTHEN FINISHES AFFECTED BY PEST-RELATED DAMAGEPEST MANAGEMENT INTERVENTIONS TO ADDRESS DETERIORATION CAUSED BY ANIMAL PESTS THAT INCLUDE ROOSTING BIRDS, RESULTING IN SITE-SPECIFIC APPROACHES ADAPTED TO GREAT HOUSE CONDITIONS MODIFICATION OF EXISTING VIGA SOCKET EXCLOSURES TO ADDRESS CURRENT DEFECTS IN THE DESIGNPRESENTATION OF EXCLOSURE OPTIONS TO NPS IN THE FORM OF A MOCK-UP; THE MOCK-UP IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE NPS WITH SUFFICIENT INFORMATION FOR MAKING IMPLEMENTATION DECISIONS IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SELECTED OPTION(S) TO THE EXTENT THE BUDGET WILL ALLOWPREPARING A SHORT PROJECT COMPLETION REPORT THAT INCLUDES:NARRATIVE DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT GOALS AND METHODOLOGYNARRATIVE DESCRIPTION OF PILOT TREATMENT METHODS AND IMPLEMENTED TREATMENTSRECOMMENDATIONS FOR MAINTENANCE PHOTODOCUMENTATION AND OTHER GRAPHICS PRODUCED FOR THE PROJECT BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO A WIDE ARRAY OF PEOPLE AND GROUPS INCLUDING NATIONAL PARK SERVICE RESOURCE MANAGERS, CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT STAFF, THE LARGER ARCHAEOLOGICAL, ARCHITECTURAL AND CONSERVATION COMMUNITIES, AND THE PUBLIC. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE MANAGERS WILL UTILIZE THIS INFORMATION TO BETTER PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE PARK'S PRIMARY RESOURCES FROM THE DAMAGING IMPACTS OF BIRDS AND BATS. CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT STAFF WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND AND INTERPRET THE CONSERVATION ISSUES AFFECTING THE PARK. FURTHERMORE, THE PROJECT'S OUTCOMES WILL BE COMMUNICATED AND INTEGRATED INTO CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT'S INTERPRETATION DIVISION TO BE RELAYED TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH EDUCATIONAL CONTENT. FINALLY, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF REPAIR, EXCLUSION AND CLEANING WILL HAVE A PUBLIC HEALTH BENEFIT BY REDUCING THE ACCUMULATION OF DROPPINGS AND OTHER PEST-RELATED DEBRIS THAT COULD RESULT IN EXPOSURE TO ILLNESS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR SKY ISLAND AND SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK TO WORK IN PARTNERSHIP TO FURTHER THE GOALS OF THE "SISTER PARK" RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN NPS AND PARKS IN NORTHERN MEXICO, WHICH INCLUDE IMPROVING SHARED NATURAL RESOURCES SUCH AS SPRINGS. WE WILL IMPROVE SPRINGS AS WILDLIFE HABITAT AND PRODUCE A BEST PRACTICES HANDBOOK FOR PARK MANAGERS, RANCHERS, AND OTHER USER GROUPS FOR AREA DE PROTECCION DE FLORA Y FAUNA BAVISPE IN SONORAN, SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK IN ARIZONA, AND OTHER BORDERLANDS NATURAL AREAS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:WE WILL CONDUCT WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP THE BEST PRACTICES HANDBOOK, SURVEY SPRINGS AND IDENTIFY RESTORATION NEEDS, AND CREATE DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS AND AN EDUCATION CAMPAIGN TO HIGHLIGHT THE BENEFITS OF SPRING RESTORATION FOR PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:HOLD 3 WORKSHOPS WITH SPRING MANAGERS FROM THE U.S. AND MEXICO; DEVELOP A BILINGUAL LANDOWNER'S BEST PRACTICES GUIDE ON HOW TO IMPROVE SPRING MANAGEMENT WITH SIMPLE STEWARDSHIP ACTIONS LIKE LIVESTOCK EXCLUSION FENCING.SURVEY 30 SPRINGS IN THE U.S. AND MEXICO TO IDENTIFY RESTORATION NEED. CONDUCT 3 SPRING RESTORATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS IN THE U.S. AND MEXICO IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SKY ISLAND ALLIANCE, PROFAUNA, NATURALIA, AND UNIVERSIDAD DE LA SIERRA.   SHARE RESTORATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT DESIGNS AS INDIVIDUAL CASE STUDIES ON SPRING MANAGEMENT IN THE BEST PRACTICES GUIDE. CONDUCT A BINATIONAL AND BILINGUAL OUTREACH CAMPAIGN TO SHARE THE BEST PRACTICES GUIDE TO LANDOWNERS WITH SPRINGS NEAR SISTER PARKS IN THE U.S. AND MEXICO.BENEFICIARIES: BENEFITS WILL BE TO INTERNS IN THE US AND MEXICO WHO WILL WORK WITH SKY ISLAND ALLIANCE, FRIENDS OF SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK, AND OTHER PARTNERS. THEY WILL GAIN CAREER SKILLS IN CONSERVATION BIOLOGY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. OTHER BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE PRIVATE PARTNERS SUCH AS RANCHERS, WILDERNESS GROUPS, CAMPERS, AND HIKERS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK AND NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE FOREST HEALTH OF THE RINCON MOUNTAINS IN THE PARK BY STUDYING TWO SPECIES: ASPENS, A RARE SPECIES ASSOCIATED WITH COOL, NORTHERLY CLIMATES, AND CHIHUAHUA PINE, A RARE SPECIES WITH A WARM SOUTHERLY DISTRIBUTION. WE WILL EXAMINE HOW FIRE AND CLIMATE AFFECT THE SURVIVAL AND GROWTH OF THESE SPECIES, AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE FIRE MANAGEMENT IN THE PARK. SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL ASSEMBLE EXISTING INFORMATION ON FIRE REGIMES AND CLIMATE SENSITIVITY, AND COLLECT ADDITIONAL DATA FROM TREE-RING SAMPLING. WE WILL APPLY CLIMATE-SENSITIVE MODELS OF WILDFIRE AND FOREST GROWTH TO EVALUATE PRACTICAL SCENARIOS TO SUPPORT FIRE MANAGEMENT DECISION-MAKING.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1) COMPILE EXISTING INFORMATION ON FIRE REGIMES AND CLIMATE SENSITIVITY; 2) CONDUCT FIELD WORK AT HIGH ELEVATIONS OF RINCONS DURING 2022-2023; 3) MEET WITH PARK STAFF TO DETERMINE MANAGEMENT NEEDS; 4) DEVELOP MODELS AND CREATE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.BENEFICIARIES: BENEFITS WILL BE TO NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK INTERNS, WHO WILL GAIN CAREER SKILLS IN CONSERVATION BIOLOGY AND NATURAL RESOUR

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSIST THE NPS ON THE CONTINUED IMPLEMENTATION OF ITS LONG-TERM BIRD MONITORING EFFORT. THE DATA AND INFORMATION FROM THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO TRACK CHANGES IN THE FOREST BIRD COMMUNITY COMPOSITION ON FEDERAL LANDS AND ASSIST PARKS IN THE FORMULATION OF MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COOPERATOR AND NPS STAFF WILL COLLECT AND ANALYZE DATA ON FOREST BIRD COMPOSITION OVER A PERIOD OF ONE YEAR.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:BY AUGUST 31, 2023 ALL DATA WILL BE COLLECTED, ENTERED INTO A PROJECT DATABASE, REVIEWED FOR QUALITY AND ACCURACY, AND THEN PROVIDED TO THE NPS.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE THE RECIPIENTS, PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES, AND/OR VISITORS IN SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP OF PARK NATURAL RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY FOR STUDENTS AND OTHER INDIVIDUALS INVOLVED AS SEASONAL TECHNICIANS TO GAIN "REAL WORLD" OR HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE OF THE CLASSROOM. IT WILL PROVIDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND/OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS WITH NEW KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THIS PROJECT. THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BE SHARED WITH, AND DISSEMINATED TO THE PUBLIC, CONSERVATION AGENCIES, THE STATES AND OTHER RELATED ENTITIES, INCLUDING ORGANIZATIONS PROMOTING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THE PROJECT ALSO ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND/OR IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL AREAS.

UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILLASSESS SMOKE IMPACTS AND PHYSIOLOGICAL STRESS TO FREE RANGING WILDLIFE IN YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK AND SEQUOIA AND KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARKS. THE ASSESSMENT INVOLVES MEASURING POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS (PAHS), WHICH ARE RELEASED DURING FIRES, AND CORTISOL STRESS HORMONES IN FISHER AND SQUIRRELS. UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY WILL DEVELOP LABORATORY METHODS, ANALYSIS OF PAHS AND CORTISOL, AND REPORTS OF FINDINGS. BENEFICIARIES ARE UTAH STATE UNVIERSITY.

THE PERFORMANCE GOALS IS TO IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE RUBYS INN THRUST FAULT AS A HYDROGEOLOGIC CONTROL TO GROUNDWATER MOVEMENT IN THE VICINITY OF BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK. THIS INFORMATION IS REQUIRED TO PROPERLY EVALUATE POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO PARK WATER RIGHTS AND WATER-DEPENDENT RESOURCES FROM PROPOSED GROUNDWATER WITHDRAWALS.PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO COLLECT A VARIETY OF GEOPHYSICAL DATA AT VARIOUS POINTS ALONG AND ON EITHER SIDE OF THE RUBYS INN THRUST FAULT. THIS DATA WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE DEPTHS TO GROUNDWATER ON EITHER SIDE OF THE THRUST FAULT WHICH, IN TURN, WILL INDICATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE THRUST FAULT AS A BARRIER TO GROUNDWATER MOVEMENT THROUGH THE THRUST FAULT. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED DURING THE SPRING AND FALL TO SEE IF THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN GROUNDWATER LEVELS ON BOTH SIDES OF THE THRUST FAULT CHANGES. IDENTIFY SUITABLE LOCATIONS FOR GROUNDWATER MONITORING WELLS IN CASE THESE CAN BE CONSTRUCTED IN THE FUTURE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE ON HISTORIC AND CANDIDATE SOILS AND ADOBE AND PLASTER MIXES TO FACILITATE FUTURE PROJECTS. THE PUBLIC, LOCAL PARTNERS, AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROFESSIONALS WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE IN THE PRACTICE OF HISTORIC ADOBE BRICK RESEARCH AND PRESERVATION THROUGH ADOBE BRICK SAMPLING, ADOBE BRICK MANUFACTURING AND TESTING.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:A RESEARCHER WILL SOURCE, SAMPLE, ANALYZE, AND TEST HISTORIC AND NEWLY MADE ADOBES AND PLASTERS USING LOCAL CLAY RICH SOILS FOR USE IN PROJECTS. SAMPLES WILL BE SENT FOR LABORATORY ANALYSIS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE COMPOSITION OF THE EXISTING HISTORIC ADOBE BRICKS AND TO DETERMINE THE MOST COMPATIBLE LOCAL CLAY SOILS. INVOLVEMENT OF PARTNERS WILL OCCUR DURING IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SOURCING, SAMPLING, AND TESTING. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:FIRST MILESTONE IS COMPLETE PARTICLE SIZE ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE CLAY-SILT-SAND RATIOS. THE SECOND MILESTONE WILL BE TO TEST THE BEST LOCAL CLAYS FOR USE IN BRICKS AND PLASTER. THE THIRD PHASE WILL INVOLVE EXPERIMENTS IN SURFACE TREATMENTS OF MUD PLASTER. THE EXPECTED RESULT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION THROUGH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN HISTORIC PRESERVATION-SPECIFIC SKILLS, AS THEY APPLY TO ADOBE BRICK RECIPES AND CONSTRUCTION.BENEFICIARIES: PARK STAFF, VOLUNTEERS, STUDENTS, AND INTERNS FROM PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTOR.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROVIDES HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE FOR POST-GRADUATES TO LEARN AND APPLY BEST PRACTICES FOR SCANNING, METADATA ATTACHMENT AND DESCRIPTION, AND ARCHIVES CATALOGING.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:SCAN PHOTOGRAPHIC IMAGES AND DEVELOP METADATA DESCRIPTION FOR AND ATTACH TO IMAGES. STUDENT WILL ALSO APPLY BEST PRACTICES FOR MUSEUM ARCHIVAL CATALOGING AND ACCOUNTABILITY.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TO ADDRESS LONG TERM PRESERVATION NEEDS OF UNSTABLE NITRATE NEGATIVES AND THE IMAGES MAKE MORE AVAILABLE THROUGH SCANNING.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:DIGITALLY CAPTURE UP TO 9,000 NITRATE NEGATIVES AND APPLY APPROPRIATE METADATA AND FILE LABELLING. PACKAGE DIGITAL FILES FOR SHIPMENT TO INDIVIDUAL PARK UNITS.CATALOG UP TO 14,828 DIGITAL FILES.UPDATE UP TO 4,858 LEGACY CATALOG RECORDS.BENEFICIARIES:NPS PARKS AND REPOSITORIES WITH NITRATE NEGATIVE COLLECTIONS AND UNIVERSITY POST-GRADUATE STUDENTS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE OVERALL GOAL IS TO MONITOR THE RESPONSES OF MULE DEER (ODOCOILEUS HEMIONUS), ELK (CERVUS CANADENSIS), MOUNTAIN LIONS (PUMA CONCOLOR), AND BLACK BEARS (URSUS AMERICANUS) TO FOREST RESTORATION TREATMENTS AND WILDFIRES IN THE JEMEZ MOUNTAINS, NEW MEXICO.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:OUR SPECIFIC PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) ASSESS      CHANGES IN ABUNDANCE OF KEY PLANT FORAGE SPECIES IN RESPONSE TO FOREST      RESTORATION TREATMENTS AND WILDFIRES INCLUDING HERBACEOUS FORAGE FOR ELK,      BROWSE FOR MULE DEER, AND MASS PRODUCING SPECIES FOR BLACK BEAR AND MULE      DEER; 2) ESTIMATE FORAGE QUALITY IN TREATED AND UNTREATED AREAS; 3)      DETERMINE HABITAT SELECTION AND SPACE USE PATTERNS OF MULE DEER, ELK,      MOUNTAIN LIONS, AND BLACK BEARS IN RELATION TO FOREST RESTORATION      TREATMENTS AND WILDFIRE INCLUDING THE TIME BETWEEN RESTORATION ACTIVITIES      AND USE BY LARGE MAMMALS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THE JEMEZ MOUNTAINS, NORTHCENTRAL NEW MEXICO. STUDY AREA WILL INCLUDE AREA WITHIN THE PREVIOUS SOUTHWEST JEMEZ MOUNTAINS COLLABORATIVE FOREST LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PROJECT AREA (SWJM-CFLRP) AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL PUBLIC AND TRIBAL LANDS TO THE SOUTH AND EAST OF THE SWJM-CFLRP PROJECT AREA. THE PROJECT AREA IS PRIMARILY NATIONAL PARK SERVICE LANDS MANAGED BY VALLES CALDERA NATIONAL PRESERVE (VALL) AND BANDELIER NATIONAL MONUMENT (BAND), FOREST SERVICE-MANAGED LANDS WITHIN THE SANTA FE NATIONAL FOREST (SFNF), AND JEMEZ PUEBLO TRIBAL LANDS. ELEVATION RANGES FROM APPROXIMATELY 1,670 M TO 3,400 M. VEGETATION TYPES INCLUDE PINON-JUNIPER (PINUS EDULIS-JUNIPERUS SPP.) WOODLANDS AND GRASSLANDS AT LOWER ELEVATIONS, TO PONDEROSA PINE (PINUS PONDEROSA) AT MID-ELEVATIONS, TO DRY AND MESIC MIXED-CONIFER AND SPRUCE-FIR (PICEA SPP.-ABIES SPP.) FORESTS AT UPPER ELEVATIONS (SFNF - VALL 2010). THERE ARE ALSO NUMEROUS, LARGE MONTANE MEADOWS AT HIGHER ELEVATIONS, PARTICULARLY ON VALL. BENEFICIARIES: THE PROJECT ENGAGES RECIPIENTS, PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES, AND/OR VISITORS IN SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AS PART OF THE LANDSCAPE RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM (LRMP) ON THE PRESERVE. THE OVERALL LRMP HAS 37 OFFICIAL COLLABORATING GROUPS/AGENCIES, AND NEW MEXICO STATE UNIVERSITY PROJECT WILL BE INTEGRATED WITH PROJECTS AND PARTICIPATION OF THESE MANY COLLABORATORS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE DRIVERS AND TIMESCALES OF CHANGE IN GROUND WATER LEVELS AND SALINITY AT FIRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE (FIRE ISLAND) DUE TO SEA LEVEL RISE AND STORM SURGE OVERWASH, AND TO DEVELOP A MODEL THAT CAN PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO WHERE MITIGATION EFFORTS WILL BE BEST DIRECTED TO PREVENT DIE-OFF IN THE SUNKEN FOREST.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY DRIVERS AND TIMESCALES OF CHANGES IN WATER LEVEL AND SALINITY USING EXISTING WELL DATA, ADDITIONAL DATA COLLECTED, AND OTHER EXISTING DATASETS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE INFLUENCE OF DRIVERS ACROSS THE MARSH TO FOREST TRANSITION ZONE BY UTILIZING TIME SERIES MODELS TO QUANTIFY THE RELATIVE INFLUENCE OF EACH OF THE DRIVERS IDENTIFIED. THESE TIME SERIES MODELS WILL THEN BE USED TO PREDICT CHANGES IN THE SALINITY AND WATER LEVEL UNDER SEA-LEVEL RISE AND FUTURE STORM SURGE CONDITIONS. THIS WILL ALLOW FIRE ISLAND TO ESTIMATE FUTURE VULNERABILITY TO BOTH SEA-LEVEL RISE AND STORM-SURGE INUNDATION ACROSS THE ISLAND AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL MITIGATION APPROACHES TO BE EMPLOYED IN THE SUNKEN FOREST.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1) COLLECT GROUNDWATER LEVEL AND SALINITY DATA AT EXISTING WELLS2) DEVELOP A MODEL TO PREDICT AREAS VULNERABLE TO FUTURE SEA-LEVEL RISE AND STORM SURGE OVERWASH3) PEER-REVIEWED REPORT OR MANUSCRIPT THAT DESCRIBES MODEL RESULTS AND THE MAIN DRIVERS OF INCREASED SALINITY ON GROUNDWATER4) COMMUNICATION PRODUCT (E.G., RESOURCE BRIEF) TO SHARE THE FINDINGS MORE WIDELY.PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES: VISITORS TO THE PARKANCILLARY BENEFICIARIES: PARK STAFF

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PARK WOULD LIKE TO ESTABLISH AN AGREEMENT WITH SOUTHERN UTAH UNIVERSITY (SUU) TO PROVIDE RESEARCH IN VISITOR INFORMATION MANAGEMENT TO MODERNIZE THE PARK'S VISITOR COUNTING PROCEDURES, WHICH SHOULD REDUCE THE EFFORT ASSOCIATED WITH ESTIMATING VISITOR USE COUNTS AND STAFF TIME TO COMPILE THE MONTHLY USE DATA. THE EXPERIMENTAL COUNTING SYSTEM MAY INCLUDE RADAR, VISION, AND ECO COUNTERS, WHICH WOULD BE INSTALLED AT ENTRANCE STATIONS BASED ON LOCATION PRIORITIZATIONSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:INVESTIGATORS FROM SUU AND NPS STAFF WILL COLLABORATE TO ACCOMPLISH THE TASKS. REVIEW PRIORITY LOCATION LIST AND EQUIPMENT OPTIONS. CREATE AN EQUIPMENT ORDERING LIST, INCLUDING VENDORS. REVIEW DATA MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATION OPTIONS AND CREATE A DATA MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATION PLAN. THIS WILL INCLUDE AN INTERNAL DASHBOARD FOR PARK MANAGEMENT AND UPDATING IRMA IN THE FUTURE WHEN THE PARK IS SATISFIED WITH THE DATA COLLECTION METHODS AND CONSISTENCYBENEFICIARIES: PARK MANAGEMENT AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC: THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY PROVIDING INFORMATION TO PARK MANAGEMENT ABOUT VISITOR USE PATTERNS, WHILE NOT IMPINGING ON VISITOR TIME OR HAVING TO ASK OR SURVEY VISITORS DIRECTLY. MANAGEMENT CAN THEN USE THE INFORMATION COLLECTED AS A PART OF THIS STUDY TO ENHANCE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE BY COORDINATING PROGRAMS, IMPROVING INFRASTRUCTURE, ADJUSTING STAFFING LEVELS, AND ADVERTISING BUSINESS OPPORTUNITIES. THE DATA WILL ALSO BE USEFUL FOR STATE AND LOCAL TOURISM PARTNERS; IN-PARK AND GATEWAY COMMUNITY BUSINESSES; THE PARK'S PHILANTHROPIC PARTNER AND MORE. THE STAFF FROM SUU WILL HELP PLAN AND DEVELOP A RIGOROUS METHOD OF DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS, REPORTING, AND PUBLICATION.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROVIDES HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE THE CLASSROOM FOR TECHNICIANS, STUDENTS, AND RECENT GRADUATES INTERESTED IN THE CONSERVATION OF MATERIAL CULTURE.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COOPERATORS WILL PERFORM CONSERVATION TREATMENTS, PACK COLLECTIONS; DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT STORAGE SUPPORTS, CREATE TUTORIAL VIDEOS ON STORAGE SUPPORTS, SURVEY COLLECTION CONDITION, IDENTIFY NEEDED SUPPLIES FOR PROJECTS, AND ASSIST WITH OTHER TASKS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE PREVENTATIVE CONSERVATION.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:TO ADDRESS LONG TERM PRESERVATION NEEDS TO PREPARE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS FOR PUBLIC EXHIBIT AND ACCESS FOR RESEARCH, WHILE PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL WORK OPPORTUNITIES.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - THE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE:TREAT 221 NPS COLLECTIONS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CODE OF ETHICS AND GUIDELINES FOR PRACTICE OF THE AMERICAN INSTITUTE FOR CONSERVATIONPACK, UNPACK, AND TRANSPORT MUSEUM COLLECTIONS BETWEEN PARKS AND WACCUPGRADE STORAGE CONDITIONS FOR 357 INDIVIDUAL ITEMS IN NPS PARK COLLECTIONSCREATE 3 TUTORIAL VIDEOS ON DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING STORAGE SUPPORTS FOR MUSEUM COLLECTIONSSURVEY APPROXIMATELY 4,000 ITEMS TO DOCUMENT STABILITY AND DEVELOP REPORTS ON CONSERVATION NEEDSASSIST WITH IDENTIFYING AND MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES NEEDED TO COMPLETE WORKBENEFICIARIES:NPS PARKS WITH MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND COOPERATORS.

THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE UNDERREPRESENTED COLLEGE STUDENTS EDUCATION IN ECOLOGY AND RELATED SCIENCES, HELP THEM BUILD AND REINFORCE A NATURE STEWARDSHIP ETHIC, AND STIMULATE THEIR INTEREST IN FURTHER EDUCATION AND CAREERS IN NATIONAL PARKS.OBJECTIVES ARE TO PLAN AND CONDUCT MULTI-DAY FIELD ECOLOGY STUDY TRIPS IN NATIONAL PARKS ASSOCIATED WITH NPS RESEARCH LEARNING CENTERS. PARTICIPANTS WILL BE COLLEGE STUDENTS PRIMARILY FROM DEMOGRAPHIC GROUPS THAT ARE UNDERREPRESENTED IN ECOLOGY. FIELD TRIP ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ABOUT PARK ECOSYSTEMS, HANDS-ON FIELD DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, AND FACILITATED DISCUSSIONS ABOUT CAREER OPPORTUNITIES RELATED TO NATIONAL PARK SCIENCE.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ASSESS THE IMMEDIATE OUTCOMES OF RINGTAIL TRANSLOCATION (SURVIVAL AND SITE FIDELITY) AND INVESTIGATE THE BROADER IMPLICATIONS OF RINGTAIL REMOVAL FOR HUMAN HEALTH AND SAFETY. SUCH ASSESSMENTS ARE ACCOMPLISHABLE VIA RADIO-COLLARING AND BIOLOGICAL SAMPLING OF TRANSLOCATED INDIVIDUALS FOR SURVIVAL, DIETARY, AND ZOONOTIC DISEASE ANALYSES. IN CONCERT, DIET AND DISEASE PROFILES FOR NUISANCE RINGTAILS MAY HELP TO INDICATE A THRESHOLD FOR THE RELATIVE DISEASE RISKS OF RINGTAILS AND THEIR PREY. DATA FROM THIS PROJECT MAY ALSO PROVIDE RELEVANT INSIGHTS TO THE MANAGEMENT OF OTHER GLOBALLY DISTRIBUTED URBANIZED SPECIES AND ZOONOTIC DISEASES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:UP TO 20 RINGTAILS WILL BE CAPTURED AND HAVE SMALL RADIO COLLARS PLACED ON THEM. THIS WILL ALLOW IDENTIFICATION OF INDIVIDUAL RINGTAILS AND ALLOW PROJECT STAFF TO DETERMINE MOVEMENTS AND THE ULTIMATE FATE OF EACH RINGTAIL. SAMPLES WILL BE TAKEN FROM ALL RINGTAILS FOR ZOONOTIC DISEASE ANALYSIS AND STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS (DIET), AND RINGTAILS WILL BE CHECKED FOR ECTOPARASITES AND ENDOPARASITES (SCAT ANALYSIS). PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL BE LED BY A GRADUATE STUDENT AND SUPPORTED BY GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK WILDLIFE PROGRAM STAFF.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE EFFECTS OF TRANSLOCATING NUISANCE RINGTAILS AND WILL CULMINATE IN THE COMPLETION OF A GRADUATE THESIS PROJECT AND PUBLICATION OF THE PROJECT FINDINGS IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK - SCIENCE AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DIVISION, AND NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY - COLLEGE OF ENVIRONMENT, FORESTRY, AND NATURAL SCIENCES. DATA RELATED TO RINGTAIL SURVIVAL, DIET, AND DISEASE NOT ONLY BENEFIT THE INTERESTS OF THE GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK WILDLIFE PROGRAM BUT POTENTIALLY THE INTERESTS OF ANY WILDLIFE MANAGER MITIGATING SAFETY RISKS PRESENTED BY URBANIZED CARNIV

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE IS TO CONDUCT BAT SURVEYS IN 16 ABANDONED MINES IN ORGAN PIPE CACTUS NATIONAL MONUMENT. SURVEYS ARE NEEDED TO HELP DETERMINE WHICH MITIGATIONS, IF ANY, SHOULD OCCUR IN EACH MINE AND HOW MITIGATIONS CAN REDUCE THE IMPACT ON BATS WHILE ALLOWING VISITOR ACCESS. IF NO BAT ACTIVITY IS FOUND, CERTAIN MINES MAY BE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FOR RECREATION IF OTHERWISE DEEMED SAFE. SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE RECIPIENTS "SUBTERRANEAN TEAM" WILL VISIT EACH MINE AND CONDUCT INTERNAL BIOLOGICAL SURVEYS (PROVIDED ALL SAFETY CONCERNS CAN BE MITIGATED). A LIST OF 16 ABANDONED MINES HAS BEEN DESIGNATED FOR THIS PROJECT. INTERNAL SURVEYS PROVIDE THE MOST EFFICIENT AND COMPREHENSIVE MEANS OF ASSESSING WILDLIFE USE OF SUBTERRANEAN FEATURES. THE SUBTERRANEAN TEAMS ARE GENERALLY ABLE TO DETERMINE TYPE AND SEASONALITY OF BAT USE FROM A SINGLE INTERNAL VISIT. REGARDLESS OF WHETHER BATS ARE PRESENT DURING THE SURVEY, AN INVESTIGATION OF BAT SIGN AND OTHER PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF THE SITE (E.G., EXTENSIVENESS, COMPLEXITY OF WORKINGS, MICROCLIMATE DIVERSITY, HYDROLOGY) ALLOW THE SURVEYORS TO ASSESS THE AVAILABLE HABITAT QUALITY OF THE FEATURE. THIS IN TURN INFORMS A CLOSURE RECOMMENDATION, WITH CONSIDERATION FOR METHODS AND TIMING OF CLOSURE TO BEST ACCOMMODATE WILDLIFE AND MINIMIZE DISTURBANCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:AN INVESTIGATION OF BAT SIGN WILL OCCUR TO DETERMINE BAT ACTIVITY IN EACH MINE (DROPPINGS, SKELETAL REMAINS, FORAGING REMAINS, ETC.). THE PHYSICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF EACH MINE WILL BE EVALUATED TO DETERMINE THE LIKELIHOOD AND EXTENT OF BAT USE (MICROCLIMATE DIVERSITY, HYDROLOGY, ETC.). THE PARK SERVICE WILL BE PROVIDED THE CLOSURE OR MITIGATION RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON THE FINDINGS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE A WRITTEN REPORT OF FINDINGS, CLOSURE RECOMMENDATIONS, PHOTOS, AND GEOSPATIAL DATA.BENEFICIARIES: THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, LOCAL COMMUNITIES, PARK VISITORS, BAT RESEARCHERS, AND WILDLIFE (BATS)
BIRD BANDING AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAM

WITHIN 3 NATIONAL PARKS, THE PROJECT WILL FULLY CHARACTERIZE THREATENED BAT SEASONAL AND POPULATION ECOLOGY, DOCUMENT SUMMER MATERNITY ACTIVITY, ROOST CHARACTERISTICS, AND DETERMINE GENETIC CONNECTEDNESS TO OTHER POPULATIONS IN THE REGION.(1) USE SUMMER ACOUSTIC DETECTORS AND MIST-NETTING TO CAPTURE, PROCESS, AND RADIO-TRACK BATS TO DAY-ROOSTS  AND FORAGING AREAS; (2) COLLECT TISSUE FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS, (3) PROVIDE INSIGHTS INTO POSSIBLE LOCAL OVERWINTERING USE.ACOUSTIC MONITORING, MIST-NETTING, TISSUE COLLECTION AND GENETIC ANALYSIS, VHF RADIO-TRACK, CHARACTERIZE DAY-ROOSTS, ANALYZE ACOUSTIC DATA WITH 2016-2019 PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA, SUBMIT ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORT 15 SEPT, CREATE DRAFT RESOURCE BRIEF, FINAL REPORT DEC 2024.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):TO CONDUCT AN INTERDISCIPLINARY STUDY FOCUSED ON BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE ROBERTS' GREAT HOUSE ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE (RGH SITE). THE STUDY WILL INCORPORATE ARCHAEOLOGICAL, GEOPHYSICAL, AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS TO ASSESS THE SITE'S CONDITION, ADDRESS CHACOAN ARCHAEOLOGY RESEARCH QUESTIONS, AND TO PROPOSE SITE PRESERVATION RECOMMENDATIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:COLLABORATE TO PREPARE A RESEARCH DESIGN; CONDUCT ARCHAEOLOGICAL, GEOPHYSICAL, AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL INVESTIGATIONS AT THE RGH SITE'S FOUNDATION AREA; COMPLETE A DRAFT AND FINAL REPORT; AND PRESENT FINDINGS TO TRADITIONALLY ASSOCIATED TRIBES AND OTHERS AS APPROPRIATE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROJECT MILESTONES: COMPLETE RESEARCH DESIGN, INADVERTENT DISCOVERIES PLAN, FIELDWORK (ARCHAEOLOGICAL, GEOPHYSICAL AND GEOMORPHOLOGICAL), DRAFT REPORT, REVIEW OF DRAFT REPORT, FINAL REPORT, AND PRESENTATION(S).EXPECTED OUTCOMES: COMMUNITIES EXTERNAL TO THE NPS WILL GAIN NEW KNOWLEDGE WHEN PROJECT COLLABORATORS SHARE FINDINGS FROM THE RGH SITE, IMPROVING THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF CHACOAN ARCHAEOLOGY. WITH STUDENT INVOLVEMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT FINDINGS, THERE WILL BE GREATER PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTICIPATION IN ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND HISTORIC PRESERVATION PROGRAMS/ACTIVITIES. FLIGHT 93 REFORESTATION MONITORING PLAN: SUMMER 2022

FORT LARAMIE NATIONAL      HISTORIC SITE (FOLA) IS KNOWN TO HAVE AN ACTIVE MATERNITY COLONY OF UP TO      SEVERAL THOUSAND LITTLE BROWN BATS (MYOTIS LUCIFUGUS; MYLU) THAT ARE      SUSCEPTIBLE TO WHITE-NOSE      SYNDROME (WNS). THE FUNGUS THAT CAUSES WNS, PSEUDOGYMNOASCUS DESTRUCTANS      (PD) WAS DETECTED ON BATS AT FOLA IN 2018, ALTHOUGH WNS HAS NOT BEEN      CONFIRMED. THE MAJORITY OF MYLUS ROOST IN A MANMADE BAT CONDOMINIUM THAT      WAS INSTALLED DURING PRIOR EFFORTS TO EXCLUDE BATS FROM THE MANY HISTORIC      BUILDINGS IN THE FORT. FOLA PRESENTS THE IDEAL SETTING FOR MONITORING A      WESTERN COLONY OF MYLU THROUGHOUT THE EPIDEMIC PHASES OF WNS (FROM FIRST      DISCOVERY OF PD TO PROGRESSION OF ANTICIPATED DISEASE, ALTHOUGH THIS IS      YET TO BE SEEN IN THIS COLONY). IT IS ALSO AN OPPORTUNITY TO ASSESS POPULATION      CHANGE, AND THE IMPORTANCE OF MANMADE ROOST STRUCTURES FOR CONSERVING      COLONIAL ROOSTING BAT POPULATIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE EXPECTED RESULT OF THE PROJECT ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) CONDUCT MARK-RECAPTURE STUDIES OF MYLU TO ASSESS SURVIVAL AND ABUNDANCE CHANGES; (2) MONITOR MYLU POPULATIONS AT AN ESTABLISHED BAT CONDOMINIUM AND AT A NEWLY-CONSTRUCTED BAT CONDOMINIUM TO ASSESS USE OF THESE STRUCTURES BY BATS AND EFFECTS ON SURVIVAL, REPRODUCTION AND HEALTH OF BATS; AND (4) PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FOLA VISITORS TO APPRECIATE AND LEARN ABOUT BATS AND BAT CONSERVATION EFFORTS. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SEE SUMMARY

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO-DENVER SHALL COMPLETE HISTORIC AMERICAN BUILDING SURVEY (HABS) LEVEL 1 MEASURED DRAWINGS FOR SAKURA SQUARE IN DOWNTOWN DENVER. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL HISTORIC AMERICAN BUILDINGS SURVEY (HABS) DATA AND DOCUMENTATION ON THE EXISTING CONDITION OF SAKURA SQUARE, A HISTORIC GATHERING PLACE FOR JAPANESE AMERICAN COMMUNITIES IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION. THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO-DENVER AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO DEVELOP PROJECT GOALS THAT WILL FOLLOW THESECRETARY OF THE INTERIOR'S STANDARDSFOR HISTORICAL DOCUMENTATION AND HABS GUIDELINES (HTTPS://WWW.NPS.GOV/HDP/STANDARDS/GUIDELINES.HTM) TO PRODUCE MEASURED DRAWINGS FOR SAKURA SQUARE IN DOWNTOWN DENVER. THE RECIPIENT SHALL CONDUCT FIELD WORK AT SAKURA SQUARE, COLLECTING BASELINE DATE THROUGH THE USE OF LIDAR SCANNING TECHNOLOGY. HABS DOCUMENTATION WILL BE COMPLETED UNDER A METHODOLOGY DEVELOPED BY NPS (HERITAGE PARTNERSHIPS PROGRAM (HPP)) AND THE RECIPIENT. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THE UNIVERSITY WILL ASSIST HPP WITH COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT,SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO-DENVER SHALL CONDUCT FIELD WORK AT SAKURA SQUARE, COLLECT DATA THROUGH LIDAR SCANNING TECHNOLOGY, MAINTAIN FIELD NOTES DURING DATA COLLECTION EFFORTS, DEVELOP A MEASURED DRAWINGS PACKET THAT MEETS HABS LEVEL 1 SECRETARY OF INTERIOR STANDARDS, REVIEW AND REVISE MEASURED DRAWINGS BASED ON NPS REGIONAL AND WASHINGTON OFFICE COMMENTS AND GUIDANCE, COMPLETE HABS LEVEL 1 MEASURED DRAWING PACKET.KEY PERFORMANCE GOALS AND PROJECT MILESTONES INCLUDE:PHASE 1 (FY 22 - $ 24,679)FIELD WORK & DATA COLLECTIONLIDAR SCANNING OF SAKURA SQUARE BENEFICIARIES:PROJECT WILL MOTIVATE YOUTH PARTICIPANTS TO BECOME INVOLVED IN THE NATURAL, CULTURAL AND /OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE PROTECTION OF THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BEYOND.STUDENTS GAIN "REAL WORLD" OR HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE OF THE CLASSROOM OF NATURAL, CULTURAL AND/OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE PROJECTS.THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND/OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS GAINS BY NEW KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED THROUGH RESEARCH AND RELATED RESULTS DISSEMINATION OF NATURAL, CULTURAL AND/OR HISTORICAL RESOURCE INFORMATION.PROJECT ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND/OR IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL, CULTURAL, HISTORIC, RECREATIONAL AND OTHER ASPECTS OF AREAS SUCH AS ECOLOGICAL CONSERVATION AREAS, AND STATE AND LOCAL PARKS.
