PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL IS TO ASSIST THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND OTHER ECOREGIONAL ORGANIZATIONS OF THE SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL SEED STRATEGY FOR REHABILITATION AND RESTORATION. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO PROVIDE A RANGE OF RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION SERVICES TO INCREASE CAPACITY AND SUPPORT THE NEEDS OF THE SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP, BROADLY INCLUDING NATIVE SEED ASSESSMENTS, COLLECTION, PRODUCTION, STORAGE, RESTORATION, RESEARCH AND MONITORING, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND ECOREGIONAL COLLABORATION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS WORK IS FUNDED THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW AND PRIORITY ECOSYSTEMS FOR THE NPS INCLUDE SOUTHWESTERN DESERTS, GRASSLANDS, AND SAGEBRUSH. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING AND SPECIFICS WILL BE AGREED UPON BETWEEN THE NPS AND RECIPIENT AS PART OF THE SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT: 1. ASSESSMENTS 2. RESEARCH 3. MONITORING AND SURVEYS 4. NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS DEVELOPMENT 5. RESTORATION 6. TECHNICAL SUPPORT/TRAINING 7. EDUCATION/OUTREACH 8. COLLABORATION.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:INCREASE NATIVE SEED COLLECTION AND PRODUCTION FOR NPS UNITS IN THE SOUTHWEST BY MAY 2027.BENEFICIARIES:PARTNERS OF THE SOUTHWEST SEED PARTNERSHIP, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEED PRODUCERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO INCREASE THE EASE AND ACCURACY OF NPS PLANT IDENTIFICATION FOCUSING MAINLY ON INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANTS, TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF WHERE INVASIVE PLANTS ARE IN THE LANDSCAPE, AND TO SHARE KNOWLEDGE OF WHERE INVASIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS ARE LOCATED AND TREATED THROUGH CURATED STATE WIDE DATABASES.ALL ACTIVITIES NECESSARY FOR A YEARLY SPRING PLANT IDENTIFICATION TRAINING THAT IS GIVEN TO THE NPS, THIS CAN INCLUDE THINGS LIKE WORKSHEETS, POWERPOINTS, IDENTIFICATION BOOKS, GROWING OUT SPECIMENS IN GREENHOUSES, PLANT AND SEED PROCUREMENT AND PRESERVATION, AND THE PURCHASING OF EQUIPMENT TO MAKE IDENTIFICATION EASIER LIKE DISSECTING SCOPES AND JEWELER LOOPS. ALL ACTIVITIES NECESSARY FOR THE IDENTIFICATION AND POTENTIAL PRESERVATION OF SPECIMENS COLLECTED THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER SEASON, THIS CAN INCLUDE THINGS LIKE HERBARIUM PAPER, DISSECTING SCOPES, HIGH END CAMERAS, THE MAILING OF LARGE FRAGILE PACKAGES. ALL ACTIVITIES NECESSARY AND RELATED TO THE CURATION OF LARGE DATABASES THAT ARE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC OF THE LOCATION OF INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANTS AND ANIMALS, THIS CAN INCLUDE ACTIVITIES LIKE THE PURCHASING OF LICENSING FOR SPECIALIZED PROGRAMS LIKE ARCGIS OR ARCPRO, THE CREATION OR MAINTENANCE OR UPDATING OF WEBSITES. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: "SPRING TRAINING AROUND MAY OF EACH YEAR "IDENTIFICATION OF INVASIVE PLANTS SUBMITTED VIA PHOTO OR SAMPLE BY NPS THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER "QUALITY CONTROL AND CURATION OF DATA COLLECTED THROUGHOUT THE SEASON ON THE LOCATION OF INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANTS AND ANIMALS, THIS DATA IS TO BE POSTED ON A SITE THAT IS ACCESSIBLE BY THE GENERAL PUBLIC. BENEFICIARIES: THE NPS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE EXPERT KNOWLEDGE PROVIDED BY THE RECIPIENT. THE RECIPIENT WILL BENEFIT FROM THE SAMPLES AND KNOWLEDGE OF TYPE AND LOCATIONS OF INVASIVE EXOTIC SPECIES, AND THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE SHARED KNOWLEDGE AND DATA ABOUT THESE SPECIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:SPRING TRAINING AROUND MAY OF EACH YEAR.IDENTIFICATION OF INVASIVE PLANTS SUBMITTED VIA PHOTO OR SAMPLE BY NPS THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER.QUALITY CONTROL AND CURATION OF DATA COLLECTED THROUGHOUT THE SEASON ON THE LOCATION OF INVASIVE EXOTIC PLANTS AND ANIMALS, THIS DATA IS TO BE POSTED ON A SITE THAT IS ACCESSIBLE BY THE GENERAL PUBLIC.BENEFICIARIES:UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE WILL BENEFIT FROM THE SAMPLES AND KNOWLEDGE OF TYPE AND LOCATIONS OF INVASIVE EXOTIC SPECIES, AND THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE SHARED KNOWLEDGE AND DATA ABOUT THESE SPECIES.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: P-CESU-2022-002328ASSISTANCE LISTING NUMBER (FORMERLY CFDA):15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMSAPPLICANT NAME: DR. ANNETTE WATSON, DIRECTOR, MASTER OF SCIENCE IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND SUSTAINABILITY STUDIES ASSOCIATE PROFESSOR, GEOGRAPHY, DEPARTMENT OF POLITICAL SCIENCE, COLLEGE OF CHARLESTONDESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT: GATES OF THE ARCTIC NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE DALL'S SHEEP TRADITIONAL CULTURAL LANDSCAPE STUDYPROJECT ABSTRACT:THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO DOCUMENT THE TRADITIONAL CULTURAL LANDSCAPE CREATED AND SUSTAINED BY THE PEOPLE LIVING IN THE ALASKA NATIVE VILLAGES OF ALATNA AND ALLAKAKET AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP WITH DALL'S SHEEP (OVIS DALLI) IN THE SOUTHERN BROOKS RANGE, WITHIN GATES OF THE ARCTIC NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE. A CULTURAL LANDSCAPE IS A PLACE SHAPED BY BOTH SOCIAL AND NATURAL SYSTEMS-AND THE DELIVERABLE OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE A REPORT DESCRIBING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE PEOPLE AND THE ECOLOGY OF DALL'S SHEEP. THE ALASKA NATIONAL INTEREST LANDS CONSERVATION ACT (ANILCA) PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY FOR QUALIFIED RURAL RESIDENTS TO HARVEST SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES IN NATIONAL PARKS, PRESERVES AND MONUMENTS IN ALASKA. UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF ANILCA, SUBSISTENCE HARVESTS BY LOCAL RURAL RESIDENTS ARE CONSIDERED TO BE THE PRIORITY CONSUMPTIVE USE OF PARK RESOURCES. DALL'S SHEEP ARE AN IMPORTANT SUBSISTENCE SPECIES TO THE PEOPLE OF THIS REGION, WHO LIVE ALONG A HISTORIC BORDERLAND BETWEEN INUPIAT AND ATHABASCAN CULTURAL GROUPS, A BORDER CURRENTLY LOCATED ALONG THE UPPER ALATNA RIVER. SHEEP ARE EXPERIENCING POPULATION DECLINES IN A REGION ABOUT TO UNDERGO ROAD DEVELOPMENT-REASONS THAT LOCAL PEOPLE HAVE STATED IN THE IMPORTANCE OF DOCUMENTING THEIR CULTURAL AND TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THEIR SUBSISTENCE RESOURCES. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT HAS DEVELOPED A COLLABORATIVE PRACTICE OF RESEARCH WITH BOTH TRIBES, THAT WILL INCLUDE CONDUCTING INTERVIEWS WITH SHEEP HUNTERS FROM THE TWO VILLAGES AS THE PRIMARY DATA COLLECTION FOR THIS PROJECT, ALONG WITH ARCHIVAL AND SECONDARY LITERATURE, TO CREATE AN ETHNOGRAPHIC REPORT ON THE TRADITIONAL CULTURAL LANDSCAPE OF DALL'S SHEEP.

PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLABORATE WITH THE FLAG CURATOR IN THE CREATION OF A PUBLIC FINDING AID FOR THE FLAGSTAFF AREA NATIONAL MONUMENTS (FLAG) ARCHIVES (WHICH INCLUDE SUNSET CRATER VOLCANO [SUCR], WALNUT CANYON [WACA], AND WUPATKI NATIONAL MONUMENTS [WUPA]) AT THE MUSEUM OF NORTHERN ARIZONA (MNA), AND DIRECTIONS FOR HOW TO ACCESS THEMALL THE FLAG ARCHIVES ARE PHYSICALLY LOCATED AT MNA UNDER AN OFFICIAL NPS GENERAL AGREEMENT. WORK WILL TAKE PLACE AT MNA UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF BOTH THE MNA ANTHROPOLOGY COLLECTIONS MANAGER AND THE FLAG CURATOR WHO IS STATIONED AT MNA. THE FLAG CURATOR IS THE ATR ON THIS PROJECT.THE MNA WILL HIRE A QUALIFIED ARCHIVIST WITH KNOWLEDGE OF MANAGING NPS ARCHIVES, AND PREFERABLY WITH INTERIOR COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (ICMS) DATABASE EXPERIENCE.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:ONCE THE SUCR, WACA, AND WUPA FINDING AIDS ARE COMPLETE, THE FLAG CURATOR WILL PROVIDE THEM TO MONUMENT WEBSITE STAFF WHO WILL POST THEM IN THEIR 508 COMPLIANT FORMATS FOR THE WWW.NPS.GOV/SUCR, WWW.NPS.GOV/WACA, WWW.NPS.GOV/WUPA WEBSITES RESPECTIVELY. THE FLAG CURATOR WILL INCLUDE INSTRUCTIONS FOR HOW TO ACCESS THE ARCHIVES.BENEFICIARIES: MUSEUM OF NORTHERN ARIZONA AND ALL VIRTUAL VISITORS TO THE SUCR, WACA, AND WUPA WEBSITES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD: THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT REEF-FISH VISUAL CENSUS SURVEYS OF THE REEF-FISH COMMUNITY, ENCOMPASSING ALL MAPPED CORAL REEF HABITATS DOWN TO DEPTHS OF 35 M, THAT HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED IN DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARK AND TORTUGAS BANK CORAL REEFS SINCE 1999.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:ANALYZE THE REEF FISH DATASETS PARTICULARLY INSIDE VERSUS OUTSIDE THERESEARCH NATURAL AREA (RNA) TO DETERMINE RNA EFFICACY. DEVELOP STATISTICALLY ROBUST ESTIMATION METHODS FOR DECISION METRICS FOR BOTH TARGET AND NON-TARGET SPECIES AMONG PROTECTED ANDUNPROTECTED ZONES INCLUDING AVERAGE LENGTH IN THE EXPLOITED PHASE; RELATIVE ABUNDANCE; AND FREQUENCY OF OCCURRENCE.PRODUCE TECHNICAL REPORT(S) WITH RECOMMENDATIONS AND JOURNAL PUBLICATIONPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE GOAL OF THIS COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WITH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE'S DRY TORTUGASNATIONAL PARK IS TO PROVIDE QUANTITATIVE SPATIOTEMPORAL EVALUATION OF THE EFFICACY OF THERESEARCH NATURAL AREA, AND TO DEVELOP METHODS FOR COST-EFFECTIVE MONITORING ANDASSESSMENT OF LONG-TERM PRODUCTIVITY AND SUSTAINABILITY OF CORAL REEF FISH IN THE PARK.BENEFICIARIES:15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PROJECT STATEMENT - TO PROTECT REMAINING INTACT GRASSLANDS, RESTORE DEGRADED GRASSLANDS, AND INCREASE THE ECOLOGICAL VALUE OF MANY CULTURAL LANDSCAPES (E.G., BATTLEFIELDS), PARKS NEED TO KNOW WHAT GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES CURRENTLY EXIST IN THEIR PARKS, THE COMPOSITION AND DISTRIBUTION OF THOSE GRASSLANDS, AND GUIDANCE ON BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR HABITAT RESTORATION/RE-CREATION PROJECTS FOR NATIVE GRASSLANDS. IN PARTICULAR, THE WORK WILL SUPPORT OUR EFFORTS TO MANAGE HABITAT FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED GRASSLAND SPECIES SUCH AS THE CUMBERLAND SANDWORT (ARENARIA CUMBERLANDENSIS) AND THE GREEN PITCHER-PLANT (SARRACENIA OREOPHILA). PLEASE SEE THE GRASSLAND PROJECT PARKS ATTACHMENT.PERFORMANCE GOALS:  COMPILE A LIST OF GRASSLAND PLANT COMMUNITIES PRESENT OR HISTORICALLY PRESENT IN THE PARKSPRODUCE SPECIES LISTS, DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION, AND INFORMATION ABOUT THE GEOGRAPHIC EXTENT OF FORMER AND CURRENT GRASSLANDSPERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES:PRODUCE CHECKLISTS OF THE GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES FOR EACH PARK FOLLOWING THE FORMAT OF ESTES ET AL. (2016) 'GUIDE TO MID-SOUTH GRASSLANDS' PUBLICATION. THE SAME FORMAT WILL BE USED TO DESCRIBE GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES AT EACH INDIVIDUAL PARK. (HTTPS://ISSUU.COM/DWAYNEESTES/DOCS/A_GUIDE_TO_GRASSLANDS_OF_THE_MID-SO).ALL CHECKLIST SPECIES WILL BE CROSS-WALKED TO NATURESERVE'S ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS AND TO NVC ASSOCIATIONS.FLORISTIC CHECKLISTS FOR ALL GRASSLAND COMMUNITIES FOUND IN EACH PARK IN THE STUDY WILL BE ANNOTATED WITH THEIR GFI SCORE. WE WILL CREATE A SUMMARY TABLE OF GFI SCORES WITHIN PARKS AND ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST REGION THAT REFERENCE CONDITIONS SUITABLE FOR PLANTINGS. A SUMMARY OF RECOMMENDED 'BEST PRACTICES' FOR USING FLORISTIC CHECKLISTS TO DESIGN PARK-SPECIFIC SEED-MIXES FOR SPECIFIC SITES AND SOURCE SEEDS AND OTHER NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS FOR RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL BE INCLUDED. CFDA - 15.945

PROJECT STATEMENT - THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY (BLRI) WILL ESTABLISH A NEW PARTNERSHIP WITH VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE & STATE UNIVERSITY STUDENT TO BE INTRODUCED TO LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE. THIS STUDENT WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO BUILD HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN CULTURAL LANDSCAPE DESIGN, PLANNING, MANAGEMENT, RESEARCH, AND DIGITAL MAPPING/GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS (GIS).PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO BUILD A LADDER OF ENGAGEMENT FOR FUTURE, UNIQUE CAREERS IN THE NPS; AND TO DOCUMENT AND PRESERVE KNOWLEDGE CRITICAL TO THE BLRI CULTURAL LANDSCAPE; TO FOSTER A GREATER AWARENESS AND APPRECIATION OF THE COMPLEXITY OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM AND THE INTERSECTION OF CULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN A DESIGNED LANDSCAPE SUCH AS BLRI; AND TO PROMOTE COLLABORATION BETWEEN NPS DESIGN PROFESSIONALS AND INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES:ASSIST IN THE DOCUMENTATION OF A HISTORIC SEGREGATED PICNIC AREA IN THE DOUGHTON PARK (BLUFFS) AREA OF THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY,ANALYZE AND DOCUMENT THE EFFECTIVENESS OF SCENIC OVERLOOK MAINTENANCE AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES AND RECOMMENDING IMPROVEMENTS,CONDUCT SCENIC IMPACT ANALYSES FOR CONSTRUCTION, RIGHT OF WAY, AND SPECIAL USE PERMIT ISSUANCES AND RENEWALS, ANDASSIST IN THE IDENTIFICATION, ASSESSMENT, AND REMEDIATION OF TRESPASS ISSUES.CFDA - 15.945

PURPOSE OF AWARD:CONDUCT AN EVALUATION OF THE LONG-TERM ECOLOGICAL STATUS AND TRENDS OF SEAGRASS COMMUNITY TYPES IN DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARKSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:ANNUALLY MONITOR 18 LONG-TERM SEAGRASS MONITORING SITES IN DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARK DURING THE SUMMER PEAK BIOMASS PERIOD (JULY-SEPTEMBER). AT EACH SITE, SPECIES COMPOSITION AND RELATIVE COVER OF ALL CONSPICUOUS BENTHIC ORGANISMS WILL BE MEASURED. CARE WILL BE TAKEN IN SEARCHING FOR AND DOCUMENTING THE PRESENCE OF THE INVASIVE SEAGRASS AT EACH SITE AS WELL AS DOCUMENTING THREATENED SEA TURTLE FORAGING/GRAZING PLOTS. SEA URCHINS AND BISCUITS ABUNDANCE WILL ALSO BE RECORDED.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:PROVIDE NPS, THE PUBLIC, AND STAKEHOLDERS WITH IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT THE STATUS AND CONDITION OF SEAGRASS COMMUNITIES AND ASSOCIATED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES.BENEFICIARIES:15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

PROJECT STATEMENT - PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO RESOURCE EDUCATION PROGRAMS TO OUR VISITORS TO GRSM. PROGRAMS PRESENTED BY THE INTERNS WILL BE ON THE GRSM'S NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. INTERNS MAY PERFORM BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL PROGRAMS INCLUDING WALK, TALK, AND JR RANGER PROGRAMS AND PERFORM INFORMAL ROVING INTERPRETATION AT SEVERAL SITES WITHIN GRSM PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE OVERARCHING GOAL IS TO PROVIDE A GATEWAY TO LIFELONG ENGAGEMENT IN NPS STEWARDSHIP. TO BE RELEVANT, INTERNS WILL ENGAGE IN PROJECTS THAT WILL INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE TO LEARN ABOUT AND ENJOY PARKS WITH A FOCUS ON DIVERSE AUDIENCES THAT MAY NOT TRADITIONALLY VISIT NATIONAL PARKS. KEY TO THIS GOAL IS THE FOCUS ON EDUCATING THE COMMUNITY THROUGH INTERNSHIPS BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PERSONAL, ACADEMIC AND PROFESSIONAL GROWTH RELATED TO NPS RESOURCES.  PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES:OBJECTIVE 1: PROVIDE VISITOR ORIENTATION AND RECREATION INFORMATION SERVICES AT VISITOR CENTERS AND BUSY AREAS IN THE PARK THAT MEET THE DIVISION OF RESOURCE EDUCATION'S PROGRAMMATIC GOALS. OBJECTIVE 2: PROVIDE POP-UP (UNSCHEDULED) PROGRAMS AT BUSY AREAS OF THE PARK AS DESIGNATED BY THE DISTRICT LEAD RESOURCE EDUCATION RANGEROBJECTIVE 3: LEARN ABOUT OTHER PARK SERVICE CAREERS BY ASSISTING WITH THE WORK OF OTHER DIVISIONS BASED ON THE PERSONAL INTEREST OF THE INTERN. OBJECTIVE 4: PARTICIPATE IN APPROXIMATELY 2-WEEKS OF TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE INTERNSHIP THAT WILL PROVIDE CONTENT FOR PROGRAMS AND INFORMATIONAL SERVICES AS WELL AS ADVICE ON NAVIGATING THE FEDERAL HIRING SYSTEM. TRAINING WILL INCLUDE TECHNIQUES ON HOW TO ENGAGE AUTHENTICALLY WITH DIVERSE AUDIENCES AND INFORMATION THAT RELATES TO THE UNDER-REPRESENTED STORIES AND EXPERIENCES OF SMOKIES INHABITANTS. CFDA 15.931

BACKGROUND - MERCURY IS ONE OF THE MOST HARMFUL CONTAMINANTS TO FRESHWATER STREAMS. A POTENT NEUROTOXIN IN ITS METHYLATED FORM, THIS HEAVY METAL IS GLOBALLY WIDESPREAD AND SUBJECT TO BIOACCUMULATION AND BIOMAGNIFICATION IN STREAM FOOD WEBS.PROJECT STATEMENT - DESPITE THE LACK OF POINT SOURCES, SMALLMOUTH BASS MICROPTERUS DOLOMIEU ARE BECOMING CONTAMINATED WITH MERCURY TO UNSAFE LEVELS IN GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK STREAMS, THREATENING PARK VISITOR HEALTH AND STREAM RECREATION ACTIVITIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY WILL BE TO DETERMINE THE INTERMEDIARY MERCURY PATHWAYS FROM ATMOSPHERIC DEPOSITION TO UPTAKE BY LARGE PREDATORS LIKE SMALLMOUTH BASS.OBJECTIVE 1: STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSIS WILL BE USED TO CHARACTERIZE TROPHIC PATHWAYS IN THE THREE DRAINAGES.OBJECTIVE 2: MERCURY CONCENTRATIONS (AS MEHG AND/OR TOTAL HG) WILL BE MEASURED IN THE TISSUES OF THE SAME SET OF ORGANISMS AND BASAL RESOURCES THAT WERE SAMPLED FOR OBJECTIVE 1.OBJECTIVE 3: ADDITIONAL BIOLOGICAL DATA, INCLUDING LENGTH, WEIGHT, AND AGE WILL BE COLLECTED FROM FISHES SAMPLED FOR CONTAMINANT AND STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSES.CFDA - 15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PROJECT STATEMENT - A STUDY INVESTIGATING FEMALE TRI-COLORED BAT ECOLOGY (I.E., ROOSTING AND FORAGING) IN GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK WOULD ALLOW MANAGERS TO DEVELOP SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES THAT BENEFIT TRI-COLORED BAT CONSERVATION. THIS IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT IN LIGHT OF A POTENTIAL DECISION TO LIST THEM AS THREATENED OR ENDANGERED.PERFORMANCE GOALS - THE GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO EXPLORE THE ROOSTING AND FORAGING ECOLOGY OF PREGNANT, LACTATING, AND NON-REPRODUCTIVE FEMALE TRI-COLORED BATS DURING THE SPRING/SUMMER MATERNITY SEASON.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES:A. CONDUCT A RADIO-TELEMETRY PROJECT TO:DETERMINE SPRING/SUMMER MATERNITY SEASON DIURNAL ROOST SITE SELECTION BY FEMALE TRI-COLORED BATS AT THREE SPATIAL SCALES (I.E., ROOST TREE, STAND, AND LANDSCAPE).DEFINE FORAGING RANGE SIZE OF FEMALE TRI-COLORED BATS DURING THE SPRING/SUMMER MATERNITY SEASON.DETERMINE FORAGING AREA SELECTION OF FEMALE TRI-COLORED BATS AT TWO SPATIAL SCALES (I.E., OVERALL AND CORE) DURING THE SPRING/SUMMER MATERNITY SEASON.B. ENTER ALL RESEARCH DATA INTO APPROPRIATE GIS-LINKED DATABASES.CFDA - 15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT ECOLOGICAL CONDITIONS AND DESIRED CONDITIONS OF GRASSLANDS AT RICHMOND NATIONAL BATTLEFIELD PARK (RICHMOND) AND TO PROVIDE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS THAT SUPPORT A DIVERSE COMMUNITY OF NATIVE GRASSLAND VEGETATION FOR POLLINATORS, BIRDS, AND OTHER WILDLIFE SPECIES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL CHARACTERIZE CURRENT CONDITIONS OF VEGETATION, BIRDS, AND INSECTS IN GRASSLANDS AT RICHMOND AND WILL DEVELOP MEANINGFUL DESIRED CONDITIONS THAT ARE INFORMED BY EXISTING LITERATURE AND RESEARCH, LOCAL CONDITIONS AND NEARBY HIGH-QUALITY REFERENCE SITES, AND VETTED BY GRASSLAND SPECIALISTS. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY MANAGEMENT TASKS THAT WORK TOWARD ACHIEVING DESIRED CONDITIONS AND SUPPORT ONGOING MONITORING.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1) SURVEYS OF PLANTS, BIRDS, AND INSECTS AT RICHMOND GRASSLANDS2) MAPS OF CONCERNING INVASIVE SPECIES3) PEER-REVIEWED REPORT OR MANUSCRIPT THAT DESCRIBES THE CURRENT GRASSLAND CONDITIONS AND DESIRED FUTURE CONDITIONS4) COMMUNICATION PRODUCT (E.G., RESOURCE BRIEF) TO SHARE THE FINDINGS MORE WIDELY.BENEFICIARIES: PARK VISITORS

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE NORTHEAST COASTAL AND BARRIER NETWORK (NCBN), IN COOPERATION WITH THE NORTH ATLANTIC COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNIT AND STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY, HAS DEVELOPED A LONG-TERM PROJECT TO MONITOR ESTUARINE WATER CHEMISTRY, WATER QUALITY, WATER CLARITY, AND SEAGRASS CONDITION FIRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE (FIIS) AND GATEWAY NATIONAL RECREATION AREA (GATE). THIS CURRENT PROJECT COVERS A TWO-YEAR PERIOD BEGINNING MAY 1, 2022 AND ENDING JUNE 30, 2024 WITH MONITORING EFFORTS FOCUSED ON EACH PARK IN ALTERNATE CALENDAR YEARS. IT IS A CONTINUATION OF THE LONGER-TERM NORTHEAST COASTAL AND BARRIER NETWORK VITAL SIGNS MONITORING PROGRAM WHICH STARTED IN 2008 AND HAS BEEN CONDUCTED SINCE THEN BY STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY FOR THE VITAL SIGNS MONITORING PROGRAM AT THESE PARKS. VITAL SIGNS MONITORING IS A KEY COMPONENT IN THE SERVICE'S STRATEGY TO PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC DATA AND INFORMATION NEEDED FOR MANAGEMENT DECISION-MAKING AND EDUCATION.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NORTHEAST COASTAL AND BARRIER NETWORK ESTUARINE WATER QUALITY VITAL SIGNS MONITORING PROTOCOLS WILL BE CONTINUING AT ALTERNATING PARKS PER YEAR UNDER THIS TWO YEAR PLAN. THE PARKS INCLUDE FIRE ISLAND NATIONAL SEASHORE AND GATEWAY NATIONAL RECREATION AREA. THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THIS PROJECT, MEASUREMENTS OF WATER COLUMN INDICATORS WILL BE CONTINUED AT GATE AND FIIS, IN ALTERNATE YEARS; AND MEASUREMENTS OF SEAGRASS INDICATORS WILL BE CONTINUED AT FIRE ISLAND NS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:ANNUAL DATA COLLECTION OF THE NORTHEAST COASTAL AND BARRIER NETWORK WATER QUALITY AND SEAGRASS DATA FOR TWO NATIONAL PARKS WILL BE COMPLETED AS PART OF THIS PROJECT. EACH YEAR, EQUIPMENT WILL BE CALIBRATED AND MAINTAINED, SAMPLING WILL TAKE PLACE DURING A SUMMER INDEX PERIOD WHERE SAMPLING WILL OCCUR WEEKLY FOR FOUR WEEKS. DATA WILL BE ENTERED, QA/QC PROCEDURES CONDUCTED, AND PROVIDED TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE NORTHEAST COASTAL AND BARRIER NETWORK FOR REVIEW, ANALYSIS AND REPORTING TO EACH OF THE PARKS. ALL DATA WILL BE ARCHIVED AND MADE AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC ON THE NPS DATA STORE.BENEFICIARIES:THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE STONY BROOK UNIVERSITY, THE RECIPIENTS, OTHER PARTNERS, COMMUNITIES, AND/OR VISITORS IN SHARED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP OF PARK NATURAL RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITY FOR STUDENTS AND INTERNS TO GAIN "REAL WORLD" OR HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE OUTSIDE OF THE CLASSROOM. IT WILL PROVIDE THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND/OR RESEARCHERS EXTERNAL TO NPS WITH NEW KNOWLEDGE GAINED THROUGH THIS PROJECT. THE RESULTS OF THE PROJECT WILL ALSO BE SHARED WITH, AND DISSEMINATED TO THE PUBLIC, CONSERVATION AGENCIES, THE STATES AND OTHER RELATED ENTITIES, INCLUDING ORGANIZATIONS PROMOTING ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THE PROJECT ALSO ASSISTS IN THE CREATION, PROMOTION, FACILITATION, AND/OR IMPROVEMENT OF THE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL AREAS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):PROJECT GOALS - CONNECT YOUTH TO THEIR NATIONAL PARKS THROUGH ENGAGEMENT IN OUTDOOR RECREATION, CITIZEN SCIENCE, RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP, AND SERVICE LEARNING AT GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK.PROJECT OBJECTIVES - BY PARTICIPATING IN THE PROJECT, YOUTH WILL LEARN AND DEVELOP VALUABLE SKILLS IN CITIZEN SCIENCE (I.E., AQUATIC FOOD BASE STUDY, ACOUSTIC BAT MONITORING, AND AVIAN SURVEY), NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP (I.E. REMOVAL OF VEGETATION ENCROACHING ON CAMPABLE AREAS), OUTDOOR LIVING (I.E., CAMPING IN THE GREAT OUTDOORS), AND RECREATION (I.E., HIKING, WHITEWATER RAFTING). IN ADDITION, PROJECT PARTICIPANTS WILL GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:CITIZEN SCIENCE ACTIVITIES: AQUATIC FOOD BASE STUDY, ACOUSTIC BAT MONITORING, AND AVIAN SURVEY;RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES: REMOVE OF VEGETATION ENCROACHING ON CAMPABLE AREAS;ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES THAT ENABLE PARTICIPANTS TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THROUGH PROJECT ENGAGEMENT, FOSTER DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEXT GENERATION NPS AMBASSADORS.BENEFICIARIES: ALL PROJECT PARTICIPANTS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO MONITOR BATS IN SHENANDOAH NATIONAL PARK TO UNDERSTAND ABUNDANCE, SEASONAL ACTIVITY, AND HABITAT USE. WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME HAS CAUSED SEVERE DECLINES IN BAT POPULATIONS THAT HIBERNATE IN CAVES, AND THIS PROJECT WILL HELP WITH MANAGEMENT OF THE REMAINING POPULATIONS OF THESE SPECIES, INCLUDING NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT AND INDIANA BAT, WHICH ARE LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:USE ACOUSTIC MONITORING TO RECORD BAT CALLS TO UNDERSTAND ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTIONUSE TARGETED MIST NETTING TO CAPTURE AND RADIO-TAG NORTHERN LONG-EARED BATS TO UNDERSTAND HABITAT USEDETERMINE WINTER USE OF TALUS HABITAT WITHIN THE PARKPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ANNUAL INFORMATION ON THE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF BATS LISTED UNDER THE ESA TO ALLOW FOR PROTECTION. IT WILL ALSO PRODUCE HABITAT MAPS AND SEASONAL HABITAT USE FOR THE EASTERN SMALL-FOOTED MYOTIS, WHICH IS OF CONSERVATION CONCERN DUE TO WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME IMPACTS BUT IS NOT CURRENTLY LISTED.BENEFICIARIES:THE PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM INFORMATION ON THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ESA AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN. THE INFORMATION WILL HELP THE PARK IMPROVE MANAGEMENT. THE RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED KNOWLEDGE ON THE EFFECTS OF WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME.

THIS COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING TO CONDUCT FIELD STUDIES AND COMPUTER SIMULATIONS TO HELP FIRE MANAGERS AT YELLOWSTONE AND GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARKS ADAPT TO CLIMATE CHANGE. NEW UNDERSTANDING OF HOW FIRE EFFECTS ARE CHANGING IS NEEDED TO BALANCE FIRE RISKS AND BENEFITS, AND INFORM A RESIST, ADAPT, OR DIRECT (RAD) FRAMEWORK.SCIENTISTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN MADISON WILL INVESTIGATE THE 1988 FIRES FOR NEW UNDERSTANDING OF FOREST CONVERSION AND USE STATE-OF-THE-ART MODELS TO DETERMINE WHETHER STRATEGICALLY MANAGING FIRE TO PROTECT SEED SOURCES COULD STOP OR SLOW FOREST CONVERSION.THE RESULTS WILL PROVIDE ECOLOGICALLY-BASED GUIDANCE FOR THE PARKS TO HELP THEM DECIDE WHEN TO ALLOW FIRE ON THE LANDSCAPE VS. WHEN TO INTERVENE IN THE COMING DECADES WHEN THE POSSIBILITY OF TOO MUCH RATHER THAN TOO LITTLE FIRE LOOMS ON THE HORIZON.THIS STUDY WILL ALSO EXPLORE WHAT PLANT COMMUNITIES AND FUEL BEDS TAKE THE PLACE OF FORESTS WHEN TREE REGENERATION FALTERS, AND WHETHER FIRE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES SUCH AS MANAGING FOR FIRE REFUGIA COULD SLOW OR STOP FOREST LOSS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS RESEARCH PROJECT TAKES A TWO-PRONGED APPROACH TO INVESTIGATE THE ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCES OF THE 1988 WILDFIRES IN SOME AREAS OF THE YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM. THESE AREAS BURNED OVER 30 YEARS AGO, BUT NEW TREE GROWTH IS MINIMAL OR ABSENT IN SOME AREAS. SCIENTISTS WILL VISIT THESE AREAS TO COLLECT DATA THAT WILL HELP UNDERSTAND THE FIRE REGIME OF HIGH ELEVATION FORESTS AND PREDICT FUTURE FIRE EFFECTS. THEY WILL THEN USE COMPUTER MODELLING TO DEMONSTRATE AN APPROACH TO MITIGATE FUTURE FOREST LOSSES USING FUELS TREATMENTS AND FIRE SUPPRESSION TO PROTECT KEY FOREST SEED SOURCES AND HABITATS TO PERPETUATE TREE REGENERATION. THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS WILL BE ADDRESSED WITH BOTH FIELD AND MODELING STUDIES THAT BUILD ON A LONG HISTORY OF RESEARCH IN THE GYE BY THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN SCIENTISTS.QUESTION 1: WHAT ARE THE ECOLOGICAL CONSEQUENCES OF POSTFIRE FOREST CONVERSION?QUESTION 2: WHAT ARE THE POTENTIAL BENEFITS OF MANAGING FOR FIRE REFUGIA?PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE FOLLOWING PROJECT OUTCOMES AND DATES WILL BE COMPLETED AS PART OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT:FIELD STUDIES WILL BE COMPLETED TO DETERMINE IF POST-1988 BURNED FORESTS IN THE YELLOWSTONE AREA THAT DO NOT APPEAR TO HAVE TREE COVER DECADES LATER HAVE BEEN CONVERTED TO NON-FORESTED COMMUNITIES FOR THE FORESEEABLE FUTURE. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FROM AT LEAST 60 PLOT LOCATIONS (SUMMER 2022). ANALYSIS OF FIELD DATA WILL PREDICT AND DESCRIBE THE FUTURE VEGETATION COMMUNITIES AND POTENTIAL FIRE REGIMES THAT ARE EXPECTED TO TAKE THE PLACE OF THESE FORMER FORESTS (2022-2023). POTENTIAL FIRE REFUGIA WILL BE LOCATED AND MAPPED WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF PARK FIRE MANAGERS TO TEST WHETHER STRATEGIC FUEL BREAKS THAT PRESERVE ISLANDS OF UNBURNED FORESTS CAN MITIGATE HABITAT LOSSES WITH INCREASED FIRE DISTURBANCES ON THE LANDSCAPE (2022). COMPUTER SIMULATION OF FOREST GROWTH AND DISTURBANCE WILL ALLOW COMPARISON OF THE LONG-TERM RATES OF FOREST DECLINE IN LANDSCAPES WITH AND WITHOUT THESE PROTECTED FOREST PATCHES IN A VARIETY OF SPATIAL PATTERNS. CHARACTERISTICS THAT PRODUCE THE MOST EFFECTIVE REFUGIA WILL BE DERIVED (2022-2024).BENEFICIARIES:THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INSIGHTS FOR CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION FOR BOTH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND THE FIELD OF FIRE ECOLOGY. THESE BENEFITS WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO THE AMERICAN PUBLIC THOUGH INFORMED FIRE MANAGEMENT THAT PROTECTS HIGHLY VALUES RESOURCES AND NATURAL PROCESSES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS TO ENJOY.

THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT UNDERGROUND SURVEYS AT THE LIPPINCOTT MINE TO DETERMINE HOW BATS (AND OTHER WILDLIFE) ARE USING THE MINE AND THEN USE THAT INFORMATION TO SELECT APPROPRIATE CLOSURE TYPES. BAT SURVEYS OF THIS MINE WILL DOCUMENT OBSERVED BAT SIGN (LIVE, BATS, GUANO, ROOST STAINING, ETC.) AND INCLUDE A SITE ASSESSMENT BASED ON QUALITY OF POTENTIAL ROOSTING HABITAT. CLOSURES RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON BAT HABITAT ASSESSMENT WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED FOR EACH MINE OPENING. GUANO, IF PRESENT, MAY BE COLLECTED FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS BY THE BAT ECOLOGY & GENETICS LAB AT NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY (NAU) TO DETERMINE SPECIES COMPOSITION. THESE SURVEYS WILL ALSO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON UNDERGROUND CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE PAPER MAPS AND LIDAR SCAN WILL BE VALUABLE TOOLS FOR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND INTERPRETATION.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): FACULTY AND PHD-LEVEL STUDENT RESEARCH ASSISTANTS (RAS) FROM TWO UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO (UNM) DEPARTMENTS-HISTORY AND GEOGRAPHY & ENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES (GES)-WILL COORDINATE WITH STAFF FROM THE NATIONAL TRAILS - NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NTIR) AND FACULTY FROM THE UNM NTIR TRAILS ADVISORY COMMITTEE TO UNDERTAKE A PROJECT ON NATIVE TRAILS AND ROUTES OF TRAVEL INTERSECTING WITH AND/OR CONNECTED TO THE NINE NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAILS ADMINISTERED BY NTIR.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: TWO STUDENT RAS WILL WORK AS A TEAM UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF PIS SAMUEL TRUETT (DEPARTMENT OF HISTORY) AND MARIA LANE (GEOGRAPHY & ENVIRONMENTAL STUDIES) TO LOCATE, GEO-REFERENCE, AND VISUALLY REPRESENT DATA RELATED TO NATIVE TRAILS. THE STUDENTS WILL USE HISTORICAL-RESEARCH AND SPATIAL METHODS, AND THEIR RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON IMPORTANT HUBS AND HINGE POINTS IN INDIGENOUS NETWORKS OF TRADE AND CROSS-COMMUNITY RELATIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO (1) DEVELOP A SET OF METHODS AND PRACTICES FOR LINKING DATA ON NATIVE TRAILS TO EXISTING NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAILS, (2) CHOOSE RELEVANT DATA THAT DEMONSTRATES HOW THESE METHODS AND PRACTICES CAN BE APPLIED BROADLY ACROSS THE NATIONAL TRAILS SYSTEM, (3) PROVIDE HISTORICAL AND SPATIAL DATA DIRECTLY TO THE PUBLIC AND TRAIL PARTNERS, AND (4) ENGAGE WITH UNM STUDENTS AND COURSES.AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, NTIR WILL GAIN VALUABLE HISTORICAL AND SPATIAL INFORMATION ABOUT "BLIND SPOTS" IN THE OFFICE'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE TRAILS IT ADMINISTERS-PARTICULARLY WITH REGARD TO INDIGENOUS GROUPS. THIS WILL ALLOW NTIR TO FOSTER GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPLEX HISTORICAL NARRATIVES SURROUNDING ITS TRAILS IN ITS TRAIL ASSOCIATIONS AND, IMPORTANTLY, FOR THE PUBLIC AT LARGE. IN ADDITION TO PUBLICIZING THEIR FINDINGS IN ACADEMIC FORUMS, RAS WILL ALSO PROVIDE NTIR WITH USEABLE DELIVERABLES (I.E. ANNOTATED BIBLIOGRAPHY, METHODOLOGICAL STATEMENT, SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT, ARCGIS STORYMAPS) THAT COMMUNICATE THE PROJECT'S FINDINGS TO A PUBLIC AUDIENCE.BENEFICIARIES: RAS WILL WORK DIRECTLY ON TRAIL PROJECTS THAT WILL ENHANCE THEIR SKILLS AND CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR EDUCATION, AND PROVIDE NEW HISTORICAL INFORMATION AND VISUALIZATIONS TO THE PUBLIC AND TRAIL PARTNERS. IMPORTANTLY, THIS AGREEMENT WILL ENABLE NPS TO ENGAGE YOUNG PEOPLE IN INITIATIVES THAT MEET THE NTIR GOALS OF PROTECTING, DEVELOPING, AND PROMOTING NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAILS FOR THE PUBLIC.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO SUPPORT UP TO A DOZEN SMALL RESEARCH GRANTS FOR UNIVERSITY OR OTHER CREDIBLE RESEARCH INSTITUTION RESEARCH PROJECTS TO STUDY THE NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES, AS WELL AS HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF RESOURCES, IN THE NATIONAL PARKS OF THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM (INCLUDING GRAND TETON AND YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARKS AND JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR. MEMORIAL PARKWAY). ADDITIONALLY THIS AGREEMENT ALSO SUPPORTS TWO STUDENT INTERNSHIPS. THROUGH SMALL RESEARCH GRANTS AND INTERNSHIPS, THIS AGREEMENT FURTHERS STUDENT EDUCATION, ADVANCES RESEARCH AND STEWARDSHIP OF RESOURCES TO BENEFIT NATIONAL PARKS, AND ENCOURAGES THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES FOR THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDE: DEVELOPING RESEARCH PRIORITIES, ISSUING AN ANNUAL CALL FOR SMALL GRANT PROPOSALS, ADVERTISE AND ASSIST IN RECRUITMENT OF INTERNS, ADMINISTER GRANT AND INTERN FUNDS, PROVIDING HOUSING FOR INTERNS AT NO COST AND TO RESEARCHERS FOR A SMALL FEE, COLLABORATING ON INTERNSHIP PROJECTS AND GRANT PROPOSAL SELECTION.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:WRITTEN REPORTS FROM EACH PRINCIPLE INVESTIGATOR THAT RECEIVES A GRANT IS TO BE SUBMITTED ELECTRONICALLY TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE IN ACCORDANCE WITH RESEARCH PERMITTING AND REPORTING GUIDELINES. ADDITIONALLY, REPORTS WILL ALSO BE SHARED WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING TO BE INCLUDED IN THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING- NATIONAL PARK SERVICE GRAND TETON RESEARCH CENTER ANNUAL REPORT. EACH STUDENT INTERN WILL ALSO SUBMIT A SHORT REPORT THEIR INTERNSHIP TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING.BENEFICIARIES: THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COOPERATIVELY ENGAGE IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE NPS VISITOR USE STATISTICS PROGRAM AND ALLOWING OPPORTUNITIES FOR CSU STUDENTS INTERESTED IN DATA MANAGEMENT TO GAIN PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE WORKING WITH A VITAL FEDERAL DATA COLLECTION AND REPORTING SYSTEM. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS IMPROVING THE DELIVERY OF CONSISTENT, RELIABLE, AND HIGH-QUALITY INFORMATION ABOUT VISITOR USE FOR UNITS OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PURPOSE OF AWARD: THIS PROJECT WILL FUND A COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAININGS PROGRAM FOR NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT RELATED PROJECTS BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI AND DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARK.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL PARTNER WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI TO RECRUIT STUDENTS FOR 3- TO 12- MONTH INTERNSHIPS INVOLVING ONGOING NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROJECTS AT DRY TORTUGAS NATIONAL PARK. PROJECT AND ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO SEA TURTLE NEST MONITORING AND HATCH SUCCESS DETERMINATION, NATIVE PLANT RESTORATION, INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT, CORAL RESTORATION AND DISEASE RESPONSE, LIONFISH REMOVALS, WATER QUALITY SAMPLING, AND/OR CREEL SURVEYS.PERFORMANCE GOALS:AS A RESULT OF THE INTERNSHIP, THE FOLLOWING PRODUCTS ARE EXPECTED:SUMMARY REPORT(S) FOR COMPLETED FIELD WORK INCLUDING DATA ANALYSIS AND MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS UPDATED INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS FOR THE PARK DERIVED FROM CONTENT CREATED VIA THE INTERNSHIP PRESENTATION(S) OF THE FIELD WORK/INTERNSHIP PROVIDED TO PARK STAFF, VOLUNTEERS, AND VISITING PUBLIC.ASSISTANCE LISTING - TITLE - BENEFICIARIES:CFDA 15.945 COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAININGS PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.TO SUPPORT COORDINATED COOPERATIVE RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION AND TRAINING, AND USABLE KNOWLEDGE DEVELOPMENT TO INFORM SCIENCE-BASED MANAGEMENT OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS FOR SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK AND UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA RESEARCHERS AND STUDENTS TO WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO INVENTORY SIDEWINDERS (CROTALUS CERASTES), AN UNCOMMON SPECIES IN SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK, AND TO SUPPORT PARK MANAGEMENT GOALS BY DETERMINING ITS DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND CONSERVATION STATUS. ADDITIONAL GOALS INCLUDE ESTABLISHING A LONG-TERM MONITORING PROTOCOL AND MAKING MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL DETERMINE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF SIDEWINDERS BASED ON OCCUPANCY SURVEYS, LINE-TRANSECT DISTANCE SAMPLING, AND OTHER SURVEYS SUCH AS TIME-AREA CONSTRAINED SEARCH AND ROAD SURVEYS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO DEVELOP A REPEATABLE MONITORING PROTOCOL AND MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR MANAGERS TO PROTECT THIS RARE SPECIES THAT IS THREATENED BY HABITAT LOSS AND LOSS OF CONNECTIVITY TO POPULATIONS OUTSIDE THE PARK.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1) CONDUCT OCCUPANCY AND DISTANCE SAMPLES THROUGHOUT ACTIVE SEASON (MAY-SEPTEMBER 2022) 2) CONDUCT ADDITIONAL SURVEYS AND WORK WITH PARK STAFF, INTERNS, AND VOLUNTEERS TO COLLECT DATA ON SIDEWINDERS DURING SUMMER; 3) PROVIDE DELIVERABLES USING NPS STANDARDS AND FOLLOWING DATA MANAGEMENT POLICIES.BENEFICIARIES: BENEFITS WILL BE TO UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA AND FRIENDS OF SAGUARO NATIONAL PARK YOUTH INTERNS, WHO WILL GAIN CAREER SKILLS IN CONSERVATION BIOLOGY AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.

PURPOSE OF AWARD: THIS PROJECT WILL FUND A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY AND EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE FISHING GUIDE COMMUNITY TO HELP BETTER REPORT FISHING CATCH AND HARVEST DATA WITHIN THE PARK AND CREATE A PLATFORM FOR COLLECTIONS OF THE SAME.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:   ESTABLISH WORKING GROUP TO DEVELOP REPORTING OPTIONS & GUIDE SURVEY QUESTIONS, SURVEY APPROVAL PROCESS INITIATED. ASSESSMENT OF REPORT COMPLIANCE DATA FROM PREVIOUS REPORTING PROGRAM.PRESENT SURVEY TO GUIDE COMMUNITY & ANALYSIS OF FINDINGS.CONDUCT WORKING GROUPS TO ASSESS SURVEY FINDINGS & TO IDENTIFY PREFERRED REPORTING METHOD. BETA TESTING OF PREFERRED OPTION/OPTIONS.ANALYSIS OF RESULTS OF PREFERRED OPTION BETA TESTING & DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS:CONVENE A WORKING GROUP OF FISHING GUIDES AND SCIENTISTS,EVALUATE PREVIOUS REPORTING REQUIREMENTS AND IDENTIFY AREAS FOR IMPROVEMENT,DEVELOP AND BETA TEST POSSIBLE REPORTING TOOLS FOR FUTURE USE AND,REPORT FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS TO STATE AND EVERGLADES FISHERIES RESOURCE MANAGERS.BENEFICIARIESCFDA 15.945 COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAININGS PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM: FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS, TRIBES, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION. TO FACILITATE MULTI-DISCIPLINARY SCIENCE AND INTEGRATED INFORMATION PRODUCTS RELATED TO THE RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.
FACILITATE INTERAGENCY BISON MANAGEMENT COORDINATION

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):  AT CASA GRANDE RUINS, ORGAN PIPE CACTUS, AND TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENTS, BIOCRUSTS PERFORM CRITICAL ROLES OF STABILIZING SOIL AND RESISTING EROSION. RESTORATION OF DISTURBED AREAS USING BIOCRUSTS HAS GREAT POTENTIAL AT PARKS THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHWEST. HOWEVER, BASELINE INFORMATION ON THE BIOCRUST COMMUNITY, IMPACT OF DROUGHT, AND APPLICABILITY OF RESTORATION METHODS USING BIOCRUSTS REMAINS POOR. THIS PROJECT IS A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY EFFORT TO INVESTIGATE THE INTERACTIVE EFFECTS OF DROUGHT AND DISTURBANCE ON BIOCRUST COMMUNITIES AND ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES; AND EXAMINE RESTORATION OPTIONS ACROSS THREE DRYLAND PARKS. PROJECT RESULTS WILL ALLOW FOR ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT OF BIOCRUSTS AT PARKS THROUGHOUT THE SOUTHWEST.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:ASSESS CAGR'S BIOCRUST COMMUNITY AND DEVELOP A MONITORING PLAN FOR ASSESSING; USE AN IN SITU EXPERIMENT TO ELUCIDATE THE IMPACT OF DROUGHT, DISTURBANCE, AND RESTORATION ON BIOCRUST COMMUNITIES AND THEIR FUNCTION; ASSESS THE DETERMINANTS OF SUCCESSFUL BIOCRUST RESTORATION ACROSS THREE NPS PARKS; ANDPERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:A SPECIES LEVEL INVENTORY OF BIOCRUSTS AT CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT;AN ASSESSMENT PLAN FOR CASA GRANDE RUINS NATIONAL MONUMENT'S BIOCRUST COMMUNITY;A DETAILED FINAL REPORT; STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE FOR RESTORATION USING BIOCRUSTS SPECIFIC TO THE SONORAN DESERT AND BASED ON THE EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS; AND PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS ON THE EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS BENEFICIARIES:BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE THREE NPS UNITS, LAND MANAGERS AND ARCHAEOLOGISTS IN THE SONORAN DESERT, RESTORATION ECOLOGISTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

PROJECT TITLE: ASSESSMENT OF THE PHYSICAL ACCESSIBILITY OF WRIGHT BROTHERS NATIONAL MEMORIAL VISITOR CENTER AND GROUNDSPERFORMANCE GOALS - THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A LIST OF COMPREHENSIVE RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE ACCESSIBILITY AT WRBR. THIS LIST OF RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP PROJECTS TO ADDRESS ANY ISSUES THAT ARE UNCOVERED.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES - THERE ARE THREE OBJECTIVES FOR THIS PROJECT: EVALUATE THE ACCESSIBILITY OF THE VISITOR CENTER FACILITY INCLUDING THE DOORS, RESTROOMS, AND TERRACEASSESS THE ACCESSIBILITY OF PARK GROUNDS AND PEDESTRIAN ROUTESPROVIDE ACCESSIBILITY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PLANNED AVIATION TRAIL THROUGH TIME OUTDOOR EXHIBIT.15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):MUMMY CAVE IS THE LARGEST ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITE IN CANYON DE CHELLY NATIONAL MONUMENT. THE SITE IS THREATENED BY EROSION THAT COULD LEAD TO THE LOSS OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL DEPOSITS. REMNANT PLASTER AND MASONRY ARCHITECTURE IS AT RISK OF DETERIORATION AND COLLAPSE. THROUGH VISUAL AND INSTRUMENTAL EVALUATION AND ANALYSES, PROJECT PARTICIPANTS WILL IDENTIFY THREATENED SITE COMPONENTS AND RECOMMEND PRESERVATION TREATMENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS DEFERRED MAINTENANCE AT ONE OF ITS MOST SIGNIFICANT ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES IN CANYON DE CHELLY NATIONAL MONUMENT.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:PROJECT GOALS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH STRUCTURAL STABILITY ASSESSMENTS, GEOTECHNICAL EVALUATIONS, AN ANALYSIS OF CONSTRUCTION SEQUENCES, ANCIENT PLASTER SURVEYS AND CHARACTERIZATIONS, AND PILOT PLASTER CONSERVATION TREATMENTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:STRUCTURAL STABILITY ASSESSMENTS WILL IDENTIFY AREAS OF HIGH STRESS, CRITICAL WEAKNESS AND SIGNIFICANT MOVEMENT. GEOTECHNICAL EVALUATIONS WILL EXPLORE IMPACTS TO ARCHAEOLOGICAL MIDDEN DEPOSITS. CONSTRUCTION SEQUENCING WILL CONTRIBUTE TO AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE CONSTRUCTION METHODS EMPLOYED BY THE SITE'S INHABITANTS. A SITEWIDE PLASTER SURVEY WILL RESULT IN PRESENCE/ABSENCE DATA FOR COLORED WASHES AND PAINTED OR INCISED EMBELLISHMENTS. PILOT PLASTER CONSERVATION TREATMENTS WILL BE PERFORMED USING INFORMATION GATHERED DURING THE PLASTER SURVEY AND FROM MATERIAL CHARACTERIZATIONS.BENEFICIARIES:THE INFORMATION DERIVED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT ACADEMICS WORKING IN THE FIELDS OF HISTORIC PRESERVATION, ENGINEERING, ARCHEOLOGY, AND ANTHROPOLOGY. THE PROJECT ALSO PROVIDES STAFF AND STUDENTS FROM THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO WITH IMPORTANT ON-SITE TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES.
CUTTHROAT TROUT INDIVIDUAL GROWTH PRE- AND POST- LAKE TROUT INVASION

THE GOAL OF THIS TASK AGREEMENT IS TO IMPLEMENT THE COOPERATIVE AMPHIBIAN AND WETLAND MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE NETWORK IN COLLABORATION WITH THE RECIPIENT AND THE NPS. COLLABORATING IN THE DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF MONITORING RESULTS WILL ADD AND ENHANCE THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE STATUS AND TRENDS OF AMPHIBIAN SPECIES AND ASSOCIATED WETLAND HABITAT IN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM. THIS WORK IS OF GREAT INTEREST TO A WIDE RANGE OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND SCIENTISTS THROUGHOUT THE WORLD WHO ARE FACING SIMILAR CONSERVATION CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH PROTECTING AMPHIBIAN SPECIES AND THEIR WETLAND HABITAT UNDER CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. BOTH PARTIES COMMUNICATE SAMPLING METHODS AND RESULTS WITH NEIGHBORING AGENCIES AND COMMUNITIES AND OTHERS BEYOND THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM WHO ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR MANAGING WETLAND HABITAT FOR AMPHIBIANS AND OTHER WETLAND DEPENDENT SPECIES (E.G., WATERFOWL).THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON COLLECTING AND ANALYZING DATA ON AMPHIBIANS AND WETLAND HABITAT IN NATIONAL PARKS WHICH WILL ENABLE LAND MANAGERS, THE PUBLIC, AND NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES TO USE THESE DATA TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THESE CRITICAL WETLAND WATER RESOURCES. MANY PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES RELY ON WETLANDS. AMPHIBIANS ARE STRONG INDICATORS FOR TRACKING THE OVERALL HEALTH OF THESE SENSITIVE ECOSYSTEMS OVER TIME SINCE THEY SOLELY RELY ON WETLANDS FOR BREEDING.
VEGETATION MONITORING AT TOMALES POINT TULE ELK RESERVE, POINT REYES NATIONAL SEASHORE

RECENT INCREASES IN FIRE FREQUENCY, SIZE, AND INTENSITY WITHIN THE TONTO BASIN AND SURROUNDING AREAS ARE CONCERNING, AS THIS POSES MAJOR THREATS TO NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. RESEARCHERS AT ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA WILL EVALUATE EVIDENCE FOR CHANGES IN FIRE REGIMES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND LONG-TERM HUMAN-FIRE RELATIONSHIPS.TO ACCOMPLISH THIS WORK SITE SAMPLING SELECTION WILL BE DETERMINED BASED ON CONDUCTING A DETAILED GEOMORPHOLOGICAL AND SOIL STUDY USING ALREADY AVAILABLE DATASETS FOR TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT. TO COLLECT SAMPLES FROM THE SITES THAT ARE SELECTED, FIELDWORK WILL BE REQUIRED TO COLLECT 1-2 PALEOENVIRONMENTAL CORES/COLUMNS. BEFORE COLLECTING THESE SAMPLES, POTENTIAL SAMPLES WILL BE ASSESSED IN THE FIELD FOR SEDIMENT DEPTH AND STRATIGRAPHIC INTEGRITY BY USING 2 CM DIAMETER PUSH PROBES.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL BE BENEFICIAL TO A WIDE ARRAY OF PEOPLE AND GROUPS INCLUDING NATIONAL PARK SERVICE RESOURCE MANAGERS, TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT STAFF, THE LARGER ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMMUNITY, AND THE PUBLIC. NATIONAL PARK SERVICE MANAGERS WILL UTILIZE THIS INFORMATION TO BETTER PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE PARK'S RESOURCES AS THE RISK FOR FIRE INCREASES IN FREQUENCY, SIZE, AND INTENSITY. TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT STAFF WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE HISTORY OF THE PARK WITH FIRE IN RELATION TO THE RESOURCES BOTH CULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL. THE PROJECT'S OUTCOMES AND DISCUSSION WILL BE COMMUNICATED AND INTEGRATED INTO TONTO NATIONAL MONUMENT'S INTERPRETATION DIVISION TO BE RELAYED TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH EDUCATIONAL CONTENT. AND THE REPORT MAY BE SHARED WITH THE LARGER ARCHAEOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL COMMUNITY TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE TONTO BASIN AND ITS INTERACTION WITH THE LARGER SONORAN AND SOUTHWEST REGION.

PROJECT STATEMENT - THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY AND SEVERAL STATE AGENCIES HAVE BEEN COLLECTING ACOUSTIC BAT DATA ON NATIONAL PARK LANDS SINCE 2011 TO ASSESS BAT DIVERSITY AND DISTRIBUTION. ALTHOUGH THE DATA MAY BE DIFFICULT TO DETERMINE ABUNDANCE, THE DATA WOULD BE ABLE TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE SPATIAL OCCUPANCY OF BAT SPECIES ON THE PARKWAY AND HOW THOSE GEOGRAPHICAL DISTRIBUTIONS HAVE CHANGED SINCE 2011.PERFORMANCE GOALS - BLRI WOULD LIKE TO UNDERSTAND 1) IF BATS AT HIGH ELEVATIONS (ABOVE 3,500 FEET) ARE DECLINING AT SIMILAR RATES TO BATS AT LOWER ELEVATIONS, 2) WHICH OF THE FOURTEEN SPECIES OF BAT THAT OCCUR ON THE BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY ARE IN DECLINE, STABLE, OR INCREASING, AND 3) WHAT THE LONG-TERM OUTLOOK FOR THE PERSISTENCE OF EACH OF THESE SPECIES IS IN THE LANDSCAPE.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES - ASSESS WHETHER THE BAT SPECIES THAT ARE VULNERABLE TO WHITE NOSE SYNDROME ARE STABLE, DECLINING OR INCREASING. THE RESULTS OF THIS WORK WILL GUIDE ACTIONS BY OTHER REGULATORY SCIENTISTS MANAGING BAT SPECIES, OTHER LAND MANAGERS IN THE REGION, AND THE NPS, BY SHARING THIS INFORMATION, WILL PLAY A LEADING ROLE IN THE CONSERVATION OF THIS SPECIES.ASSISTANCE LISTING - 15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PROJECT IS PART OF AN EFFORT TO KEEP GLACIER NATIONAL PARK WATERS FREE OF AQUATIC INVASIVE SPECIES (AIS), SUCH AS ZEBRA AND QUAGGA MUSSELS. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROCESS WATER SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM PARK LAKES FOR ENVIRONMENTAL DNA, CRITICAL FOR EARLY DETECTION AND CONTAINMENT OF INFESTATIONS. AN INFESTATION IN GLACIER NATIONAL PARK WOULD THREATEN DOWNSTREAM WATERS AS THE PARK SITS IN THE HEADWATERS OF THREE CONTINENTAL SCALE WATERSHEDS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:NPS TO COLLECT WATER SAMPLES ANNUALLY, DURING SUMMER MONTHS. SAMPLES ARE THEN SHIPPED TO THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA GENETICS CENTER FOR TESTING. RESULTS OF SAMPLE TESTING ARE PROVIDED TO THE NPS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THE EXPECTATION IS THAT SAMPLES ARE PROCESSED WITHIN 60 DAYS OF RECEIPT.BENEFICIARIES: NPS, UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA, BLACKFEET AND CONFEDERATED SALISH AND KOOTENAI TRIBES, STATE OF MONTANA, LOCAL GOVERNMENTS ALL BENEFIT FROM AIS EARLY DETECTION AND MONITORING EFFORTS IN GLACIER NATIONAL PARK.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAP THE LOCATIONS TREE SPECIES AND THE CONDITION OF TREE HEALTH IN ACADIA NATIONAL PARK (ACADIA) AND KATAHDIN WOODS AND WATERS NATIONAL MONUMENT (KATAHDIN) SO THAT THE PARKS CAN UNDERSTAND THE THREAT OF INVASIVE INSECT PESTS AND PROTECT THREATENED TREE SPECIES TRADITIONALLY USED BY THE WABANAKI TRIBES, SUCH AS ASH.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL MAP SELECT SPECIES OF TREES AND TREE HEALTH FOR ALL FORESTED LANDS IN ACADIA AND KATAHDIN USING EXISTING GROUND, AIRBORNE, AND SATELLITE IMAGERY. THESE MAPS WILL ASSIST RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN: 1) MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE INSECT PESTS AND DISEASES, SUCH AS EMERALD ASH BORER, HEMLOCK WOOLY ADELGID, AND RED PINE SCALE, AND 2) ANTICIPATING AND MANAGING CHANGES IN FOREST SPECIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1) MAP OF TREE SPECIES COMPOSITION AND TREE HEALTH IN ACADIA AND KATAHDIN2) PEER-REVIEWED REPORT OR MANUSCRIPT THAT DESCRIBES THE CONDITION OF A RANGE OF FOREST TYPES ACROSS BOTH PARKS.3) TWO IN-PERSON WORKSHOPS, ONE EACH IN ACADIA AND KATAHDIN, TO COMMUNICATE FINDINGS TO PARK STAFF AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AND TO GET INPUT TO IMPROVE AND REVISE THE MAPS.4) COMMUNICATION PRODUCT (E.G., WEB ARTICLE) TO SHARE THE FINDINGS MORE WIDELY.BENEFICIARIES: PARK STAFF AND VISITORS, WABANAKI TRIBES

APPLICANT NAME: ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAMEDESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT: EVALUATE GENETIC ANALYSIS OF COPPER RIVER SOCKEYE SALMON STOCKS FOR IN-SEASON DECISION MAKINGPROJECT ABSTRACT: THE ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (ADF&G) MANAGES SEVERAL FISHERIES THAT HARVEST COPPER RIVER (CR) SALMON (PRIMARILY SOCKEYE SALMON, BUT ALSO KING SALMON) THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO BE HARVESTED BY FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE USERS IN FISHERIES MANAGED BY WRANGELL-ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE (WRST) OR TO ESCAPE HARVEST AND REACH SPAWNING GROUNDS IN WRST OR ELSEWHERE IN THE CR DRAINAGE. THE WRST SUPERINTENDENT HAS BEEN DELEGATED AUTHORITY FROM THE FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE BOARD TO ISSUE EMERGENCY SPECIAL ACTIONS AFFECTING THREE OF THESE ADF&G-MANAGED SALMON FISHERIES WHEN NECESSARY TO CONSERVE HEALTHY STOCKS OF FISH OR ENSURE THE CONTINUATION OF FEDERAL SUBSISTENCE USES. BECAUSE OF THIS DUAL-MANAGEMENT REGIME AND THE VITAL IMPORTANCE OF CR SOCKEYE SALMON STOCKS FOR THEIR ECOLOGICAL, CULTURAL, AND ECONOMIC VALUES, BOTH WRST AND ADF&G HAVE A STRONG INTEREST IN DECISION MAKING THAT ENSURES LONG-TERM HEALTH OF CR SALMON STOCKS AND THE ECOSYSTEMS AND LIVELIHOODS THAT DEPEND ON THEM.THE NEED FOR BETTER INFORMATION TO SUPPORT IN-SEASON DECISION MAKING IS BECOMING INCREASINGLY URGENT GIVEN THE CONTEXT OF CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS WITH UNCERTAIN IMPACTS ON CR SALMON, RECENT LOW CR SALMON RUNS, AND INCREASING PUBLIC CONCERN AND SCRUTINY OF MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING THAT HAS IMPLICATIONS FOR THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF CR SALMON STOCKS AND ASSOCIATED FISHERIES AND LIVELIHOODS. GENETIC MIXED STOCK ANALYSIS (MSA) HAS BEEN INCREASINGLY APPLIED IN MIXED-STOCK FISHERIES AS A TOOL FOR DETERMINING THE STOCK COMPOSITION OF FISHERY HARVESTS AND SUPPORTING MANAGEMENT DECISION MAKING THAT MINIMIZES RISKS TO SMALL STOCKS WHILE MAXIMIZING HARVEST OF ABUNDANT STOCKS AND STILL ACHIEVING THE DRAINAGE-WIDE ESCAPEMENT GOAL. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE THE USE OF MSA IN CR SOCKEYE SALMON FISHERIES MANAGEMENT TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY OF CR SOCKEYE SALMON STOCKS AND ASSOCIATED FISHERIES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): INVESTIGATE VISITOR USE PATTERNS THAT HAVE EMERGED FOLLOWING FEDERAL WILDERNESS DESIGNATION, RAPIDLY INCREASING ANNUAL VISITATION, AND COVID-19 PANDEMIC. STUDY INCLUDES PLATTE RIVER, CRYSTAL RIVER, AND NORTH MANITOU ISLAND.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: FIELD EFFORTS SCHEDULED FOR 2022/2023 SEASONS FROM MAY TO SEPTEMBER. FIELD STAFF WILL CONSIST OF UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, FACULTY, RESEARCHERS, AND PARK STAFF AND INTERNS. PARK STAFF ASSISTANCE WITH DATA COLLECTION AT NORTH MANITOU ISLAND WILL BE CRITICAL FOR EFFICIENCY AND COSTS, AS TRAVEL LOGISTICS PRESENT UNIQUE CHALLENGES. SOCIAL SCIENCE EFFORTS INCLUDE ONSITE VISITOR USE SURVEYS, PARKING LOT COUNTS, AND TRAIL COUNTERS. QUICK RESPONSE CODE SURVEY LINKS, POSTCARDS, AND INFORMATION SIGNAGE WILL BE DEPLOYED AS INDIRECT METHODS TO COLLECT DATA DURING LOWER USE TIMES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROVIDE UPDATED INFORMATION ON VISITOR USE PATTERNS, MOTIVATIONS, AND PREFERENCES, AND PREFERENCES ACROSS PREVIOUSLY STUDIED SITES AND NEW AREAS OF INTEREST AT PARK. EXAMINE VISITOR ATTITUDES TOWARDS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND ACTIONS IMPLEMENTED TO ADDRESS VISITOR USE. PROVIDE INFORMATION FOR UTILIZATION IN FUTURE POTENTIAL PLANNING EFFORTS (E.G., RIVER USE PLANS, MANAGEMENT PLANS, MANAGEMENT PLAN UPDATES, WILDERNESS CHARACTER MONITORING).BENEFICIARIES: MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY
UNDERSTANDING NUTRIENT DYNAMICS AND WATER QUALITY TRENDS IN LAKE MCDONALD, GLACIER NATIONAL PARK.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):THE PARK PROTECTS APPROXIMATELY 185 MILES OF FLOODPLAIN FOREST, MUCH OF WHICH IS THREATENED BY INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES. DESPITE KNOWN CONSEQUENCES OF EXOTIC SPECIES, LITTLE IS UNDERSTOOD REGARDING IMPACTS TO THE ARTHROPOD COMMUNITY. THIS PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY AND EXAMINE CORRELATIONS BETWEEN INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES AND INVERTEBRATE DISTRIBUTION, RICHNESS, AND ABUNDANCE. WE WILL IDENTIFY ARTHROPODS COLLECTED FROM MONITORING PLOTS AND ANALYZE DATA TO IDENTIFY CORRELATIONS WITH INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:WE WILL FIRST RECRUIT FOR AND TRAIN STUDENTS TO PARTICIPATE IN AND WORK ON THE TASKS; NAMELY, THE SPECIMEN IDENTIFICATION. ARTHROPODS WILL BE IDENTIFIED TO THE LOWEST FEASIBLE TAXONOMIC RESOLUTION AS COLLABORATIVELY IDENTIFIED BY NPS AND THE RECIPIENT. IDENTIFIED TAXA WILL BE INCLUDED IN STATISTICAL ANALYSES TO IDENTIFY CORRELATIONS BETWEEN ARTHROPODS AND THE SPECIES, DENSITY, AND PHYSICAL STRUCTURE OF SAMPLED INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE TAXONOMIC IDENTIFICATION OF APPROXIMATELY 30,000 COLLECTED ARTHROPOD SPECIMENS AND STATISTICAL ANALYSES OF THE RESULTANT DATA. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE A LIST OF IDENTIFIED TAXA, SEPARATED BY INDIVIDUAL MONITORING PLOT AND SAMPLE DATE. A FINAL REPORT WILL ALSO INCLUDE METHODS USED AND RESULTS OF ANY STATISTICAL ANALYSES COMPLETED IN COOPERATION WITH NPS.BENEFICIARIES:THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE NPS TO PRIORITIZE INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES FOR CONTROL EFFORTS BY ASSESSING WHICH PLANT SPECIES MOST NEGATIVELY AFFECT THE ARTHROPOD COMMUNITY.

THE PROJECT WILL CREATE A CULTURAL LANDSCAPE REPORT (CLR) FOR THE PAW PAW TUNNEL AREA OF THE CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK (CHOH). THE PAW PAW TUNNEL AREA COMPRISES APPROXIMATELY 340 ACRES OF LAND AND IS A LINEAR LANDSCAPE. MUCH OF THE CULTURAL LANDSCAPE FOLLOWS THE CANAL TOWPATH AND PRISM FROM ROUTE 51 NORTH BY THE CAMPGROUND AND SUPERINTENDENT'S HOUSE; TO THE UPSTREAM (SOUTH) PORTAL OF THE PAW PAW TUNNEL; OUT THROUGH THE DOWNSTREAM (NORTH) PORTAL; THROUGH THE PAW PAW TUNNEL HOLLOW, ALONG LOCKS 66, 64 2/3, 63 1/3,& 62 AND CULVERT 210; TO THE NORTHERN SPOILS PILES. THE ENTIRE CLR PROJECT AREA IS AN HISTORICALLY SIGNIFICANT AND MODIFIED LANDSCAPE ASSOCIATED WITH THE CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL, BUT BECAUSE A LARGE PORTION OF THE PROJECT AREA IS FORESTED AND WILL NOT NEED TO BE PHYSICALLY INSPECTED THE CLR'S AREA OF EMPHASIS SHALL BE THE HOLLOW NORTH OF THE PAW PAW TUNNEL.THE CLR WILL ACT AS A PREREQUISITE TO AND INFORM TREATMENT ACTIONS AND BROADER CULTURAL LANDSCAPE PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT. THE CLR WILL FOCUS TREATMENT RECOMMENDATIONS ON COMPREHENSIVE GUIDELINES FOR THE PROPERTY. THE CLR WILL INCLUDE PARTS I AND II (AS OUTLINE IN THE STATEMENT OF WORK) AND WILL BE PREPARED FOLLOWING NPS CLR GUIDANCE AS STATED IN DIRECTOR'S ORDERS 28, CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES AND GUIDANCE INCLUDED IN THE THE SECRETARY OF INTERIOR STANDARDS FOR THE TREATMENT OF HISTORIC PROPERTIES WITH GUIDELINES FOR THE TREATMENT OF CULTURAL LANDSCAPES (HTTP://WWW.NPS.GOV/TPS/STANDARDS/FOUR-TREATMENTS/LANDSCAPE-GUIDELINES/INDEX.HTM) AND PROTECTING CULTURAL LANDSCAPES: PLANNING, TREATMENT AND MANAGEMENT OF HISTORIC LANDSCAPES (HTTP://WWW.CR.NPS.GOV/TPS/HOW-TO-PRESERVE/BRIEFS/36-CULTURAL-LANDSCAPES.HTM).

TRAINING YOUTH TO EVALUATE DIETARY OVERLAP OF LARGE HERBIVORES USING DNA BARCODINGTHE RECIPIENT WILL RECRUIT AND HIRE TWO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN A SUMMER WORK-STUDY PROGRAM AT BROWN UNIVERSITY. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL SPEND 4-6 WEEKS IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK WORKING ALONGSIDE BIOLOGISTS. ONE STUDENT WILL WORK WITH THE PARK BOTANIST TO COLLECT AND PREPARE HERBARIA SPECIMENS AND SECURE PLANT TISSUE SAMPLES FOR DNA ANALYSIS. THE OTHER STUDENT WILL WORK WITH THE PARK BISON BIOLOGIST TO COLLECT FECAL SAMPLES FROM MIGRATING LARGE HERBIVORES AND COMPLETE PLANT INVENTORY SURVEYS IN EXISTING LONG-TERM MONITORING SITES. STUDENTS WILL EVALUATE COLLECTED SAMPLES DURING THE REMAINDER OF THE WORK-STUDY PROGRAM IN THE PI'S LABORATORY AT BROWN UNIVERSITY. THEIR WORK DIRECTLY SUPPORTS BUILDING A PLANT DNA REFERENCE LIBRARY TO EVALUATE LARGE HERBIVORE DIETS. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES "REAL WORLD" EXPERIENCE TO YOUNG SCIENTISTS BY WORKING SIDE-BY-SIDE WITH NPS STAFF, WITH THE INDIRECT BENEFIT TO THE NPS OF COLLECTING INFORMATION ASSESSING DIETARY OVERLAP OF LARGE GRAZING ANIMALS IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT AN INVENTORY OF RARE AND SENSITIVE PLANT SPECIES AT MOUNT RUSHMORE NATIONAL MEMORIAL, AND ASSESS THE CONDITION OF AVAILABLE HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES. USE EXISTING DATA TO IDENTIFY RARE PLANT HABITAT AND GUIDE THE INVENTORY EFFORT, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION TO GUIDE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE ON BEST MANAGEMENT DECISIONS REGARDING THE HABITAT CONDITION. INTERPRETATION DIVISION AT THE PARK WILL USE THE STUDY'S RESULTS WITH THE PUBLIC THROUGH INTERPRETATIVE AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS, AND SOCIAL MEDIA.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: PLANNING, LITERATURE SEARCHES, AND PERMITTING, CONDUCT FIELD WORK AND HERBARIUM SPECIMEN SUBMISSION ALONG WITH DATA ANALYSIS FOR PUBLICATION OF FINAL REPORT.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: THIS WILL BENEFIT THE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM BY BROADENING THE KNOWLEDGE BASE AND DEVELOPING A MORE ACCURATE PLANT SPECIES LIST FOR THE PARK, AND ALLOW MANAGEMENT TO EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF SEVERAL PROJECTS THAT ARE PROPOSED AT THE PARK IN THE NEXT FIVE YEAR.BENEFICIARIES: UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING, WYOMING NATURAL DIVERSITY DATABASE

PURPOSE OF AWARD: TO PROVIDE INFORMATION NECESSARY FOR ESTABLISHING TOTAL PHOSPHORUS THRESHOLDS FOR BIG CYPRESS NATIONAL PRESERVE (BICY).SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: THE NPS AND FLORIDA INTERNATIONAL UNIVERSITY WILL STUDY PAST AND PRESENT ECOSYSTEM CONDITIONS AND HABITAT STRUCTURE WITHIN BICY. THERE ARE THREE MAJOR TASKS EACH ENDING WITH A PRESERVE TECHNICAL REPORT AND/OR MANUSCRIPTS FOR JOURNAL PUBLICATION. TASKS INCLUDE ASSESSING CURRENT AND HISTORIC CONDITIONS IN BICY COMPARED TO OTHER SIMILAR MARSH HABITATS; COLLECTING SEDIMENT CORES TO ASSESS MICROFOSSILS FOR RECONSTRUCTING PAST NUTRIENT CONDITIONS; AND DESIGNING AN EXPERIMENTAL FIELD STUDY TO ESTABLISH TOTAL PHOSPHORUS THRESHOLDS FOR THE PRESERVE.PERFORMANCE GOALS:  PERFORMANCE WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF DATA AND LITERATURE SYNTHESIS, TECHNICAL REPORT GENERATION FOR ALL THREE TASKS; AND MANUSCRIPT DEVELOPMENT FOR PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATION. FINALLY, A SERIES OF WORKSHOPS WILL BE HELD WITH PRESERVE STAKEHOLDER TO (1) GET FEEDBACK AND APPROACH REFINEMENT FOR THE DESIGNED STUDY AND (2) TO SOLICIT FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THE STUDY DESIGN IMPLEMENTATION.15.945 - COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND TRAINING PROGRAMS - RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM.STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, PUBLIC/PRIVATE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, NONPROFIT INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AND INDIVIDUALS (INCLUDING MEMBERS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC).

THIS PROJECT WILL HELP TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE OCCURRENCE, DISTRIBUTION, DIVERSITY, ABUNDANCE AND HABITAT USE OF MEDIUM-LARGE CARNIVORES IN CENTRAL MD AND WV.THIS PROJECT WILL DEPLOY APPROXIMATELY 40 CAMERAS IN CENTRAL MD AND WV ALONG THE RIPARIAN FOREST CORRIDOR. ASSESSMENTS OF RIVER OTTER POPULATIONS, FERAL CAT DISTRIBUTION, AND EVALUATION OF CHOH TO PROVIDE A SOURCE FOR DISPERSING FOREST CARNIVORES FROM RURAL WESTERN MD.THE RECIPIENT WILL HIRE GRADUATE AND/OR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO ASSIST IN FIELD WORK AND DATA MANAGEMENT; SET UP AND MAINTAIN APPROXIMATELY 40 CAMERA TRAPS SET UP THROUGHOUT THE PARK; COLLECT AND ORGANIZE DATA GAINED THROUGH CAMERA TRAPS; ANALYZE DATA ASSOCIATED WITH MAMMAL OCCURRENCE, DIVERSITY, AND OCCUPANCY; AND ASSIST IN PRODUCING PEER-REVIEWED MATERIAL.BENEFIT: FROSTBURG STATE UNIVERSITY

INVESTIGATORS WITH THE INSTITUTE FOR WILDLIFE STUDIES AND NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) RESOURCE MANAGERS AT CHANNEL LSLANDS NATIONAL PARK WILL CONTINUE AN ONGOING COLLABORATION TO RE-ESTABLISH AND MONITOR BALD EAGLES (HALIAEETUS LEUCOCEPHALUS) AND PEREGRINE FALCONS (FALCO PEREGRINUS) ON THE CHANNEL LSLANDS. BALD EAGLES AND PEREGRINE FALCONS WERE EXTIRPATED FROM THE CHANNEL LSLANDS BY THE 1960S, LARGELY AS A RESULT OF DDTS THAT WERE MANUFACTURED AND DISTRIBUTED IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. PROTECTED HABITAT ON THE CHANNEL LSLANDS HAS PROVIDED THE BEST OPPORTUNITY FOR BALD EAGLE AND PEREGRINE FALCON REINTRODUCTION AND CONSERVATION IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. SINCE THE 1980S, THE INSTITUTE FOR WILDLIFE STUDIES HAS BEEN INVOLVED IN THE REARING, FEEDING, RELEASE, AND MONITORING OF BALD EAGLES ON THE CHANNEL LSLANDS. SIMILAR WORK ON PEREGRINES WAS INITIATED BY THE SANTA CRUZ PREDATOR RESEARCH GROUP DURING THIS SAME TIME PERIOD. IN 2002, WITH FUNDING THROUGH THE MONTROSE SETTLEMENTS RESTORATION PROGRAM, THE INSTITUTE FOR WILDLIFE STUDIES AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE BEGAN IMPLEMENTATION OF A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH, MANAGEMENT, MONITORING, AND RESTORATION EFFORT FOR BALD EAGLES ON THE CHANNEL LSLANDS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): PERFORMANCE GOALS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ADDITIONAL FIELD WORK/DATA ANALYSIS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE IMPACTS OF ROAD MORTALITY ON VULNERABLE, WETLAND-BREEDING AMPHIBIANS. DEVELOP A PREDICTIVE TOOL TO IDENTIFY WHEN SPECIES WILL MIGRATE BASED ON WEATHER CONDITIONS, WHICH WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A DECISION-SUPPORT MODEL FOR IDENTIFYING WHEN TEMPORARY ROAD CLOSURES WOULD BE USEFUL.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: FINAL PRODUCT INCLUDES PUBLISHED TECHNICAL REPORT IN THE NPS NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP AND SCIENCE PUBLICATION SERIES, MANUSCRIPT FOR PUBLICATION IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL, RESOURCE BRIEF WITH INFORMATION THAT CAN BE SHARED AT THE PARK'S VISITOR CENTER AND WEBSITES, GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM DATABASE OF WETLAND BREEDING AMPHIBIAN OCCURRENCE/POPULATION STATUS, DIGITAL DATA LAYERS FOR PREDICTED HABITAT SUITABILITY AND ROAD MORTALITY HOTSPOTS, A DECISION-SUPPORT MODEL FOR IDENTIFYING WHEN TEMPORARY ROAD CLOSURES SHOULD BE IMPLEMENTED, COST ESTIMATES TO INFORM RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LONG-TERM ENGINEERING SOLUTIONS (UNDERPASSES, BARRIERS, ETC.) TO MITIGATE ROAD MORTALITY AT SELECT SITES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROJECT WILL SERVE AS A UNIQUE CASE STUDY AND PROVIDE FRAMEWORK FOR SCIENTIFIC AND PUBLIC COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF ROAD MORTALITY MORE BROADLY.BENEFICIARIES: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): PROVIDE SCIENCE-BASED DATA AND CORRESPONDING INTERPRETATION TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) WHICH WILL HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES IN ITS CHARGE AND DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE REGARDING NATURAL RESOURCES AT ISLE ROYALE NATIONAL PARK FOR THE PURPOSES OF EDUCATING THE PUBLIC AND TO THE BENEFIT OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: MONITOR THE PARK'S WOLF POPULATION; MONITOR THE PARK'S MOOSE POPULATION; DETERMINE PREDATION RATE; MONITOR VEGETATION RESPONSE TO MOOSE HERBIVORY; AND COMPLETE MAMMAL OCCURRENCE AND INDEX COUNTS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: IN THE PUBLIC DOMAIN, PROJECT DATA AND RESULTS WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP CURRICULUM FOR STUDENTS AND EDUCATORS AT ALL LEVELS OF INSTRUCTION. BOTH NPS AND RECIPIENT USE RESEARCH FINDINGS AND PRODUCTS TO ENGAGE THE PUBLIC, INCLUDING ON SOCIAL MEDIA. NPS USES THE DATA AND ASSOCIATED PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS TO HELP INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND PLANNING THAT IMPACT THESE RESOURCES.BENEFICIARIES: MICHIGAN TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY

THE RECIPIENT WILL RECRUIT AND HIRE A GRADUATE STUDENT TO RESEARCH THE PARK ARCHIVES TO CREATE A DATABASE OF HISTORIC BISON OBSERVATIONS. THE STUDENT WILL INTEGRATE THESE DATA WITH MORE CURRENT INFORMATION ON BISON MOVEMENTS TO CREATE MAPS OF THE KNOWN BISON RANGE AND EXTENT OF SEASONAL MIGRATIONS EVERY FIVE YEARS DURING 1900-2020. THE MAPS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE NPS TO FACILITATE, PROMOTE, AND IMPROVE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE BISON RECOVERY STORY AND COULD BE USED TO CREATE ROADSIDE EXHIBITS, DEVELOP WEB PAGE AND SOCIAL MEDIA CONTENT, AND WRITE POPULAR SCIENCE ARTICLES. THIS PROJECT WILL FACILITATE, PROMOTE, AND IMPROVE THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE HISTORY OF BISON REINTRODUCTION AND THEIR SUBSEQUENT RECOVERY TO YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, INCLUDING DOCUMENTING THE RELEARNING OF LONG-DISTANCE MIGRATIONS.

THE RECIPIENT WILL RECRUIT AND HIRE UP TO FOUR UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN A SUMMER WORK-STUDY PROGRAM AT WASHINGTON AND LEE UNIVERSITY. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL SPEND TWO WEEKS IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK WORKING ALONGSIDE BIOLOGISTS. THE STUDENTS WILL COMPLETE PLANT INVENTORY SURVEYS, COLLECT MEASUREMENTS ON PLANT GROWTH AND HERBIVORY, COLLECT ARTHROPOD SAMPLES, AND COLLECT SOIL SAMPLES. STUDENTS WILL EVALUATE PLANT, SOIL AND ARTHROPOD SAMPLES DURING THE REMAINDER OF THE WORK-STUDY PROGRAM AT WASHINGTON AND LEE UNIVERSITY. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES "REAL WORLD" EXPERIENCE TO YOUNG SCIENTISTS BY WORKING SIDE-BY-SIDE WITH NPS STAFF, WITH THE INDIRECT BENEFIT TO THE NPS OF COLLECTING INFORMATION ASSESSING HOW LANDSCAPE LEVEL CHANGES IN PLANT GROWTH PATTERNS AND COMMUNITY COMPOSITION CAUSED BY BISON GRAZING AFFECT ARTHROPOD COMMUNITIES, NUTRIENT CYCLING, AND SOIL HEALTH IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK.

THIS AGREEMENT WILL FUND A MASTERS STUDENT TO WORK WITH GREATER YELLOWSTONE NETWORK SCIENTISTS AND PARK MANAGERS ON ANALYZING AND PUBLISHING FINDINGS FOCUSED ON IDENTIFYING CLIMATE REFUGIA FOR WHITEBARK PINE NOW AND AT 30-YEAR TIME STEPS OUT TO 2099. INVESTIGATORS FROM THE MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE NETWORK WILL COLLABORATE TO ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES:FORMALIZE RESEARCH GOALS AND A STUDY PLAN USING THE EXISTING FOCUS CONDITION ASSESSMENT DEVELOPMENT IMPLEMENTATION PLAN. CONDUCT ANALYSES, DEVELOP STATISTICAL CODING, GEOSPATIAL DIGITAL MAPS, AND SYNTHESIZE/REPORT FINDINGS VIA MANUSCRIPTS, REPORTS, AND/OR VISUALIZATION TOOLS FOCUSED ON WHITEBARK PINE IN THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM AND THE IMPLICATIONS OF CLIMATE CHANGE LINKED TO WHITEBARK PINE LIFE HISTORY TRAITS AND DISTURBANCE AGENTS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:P-P-CESU-22-006CFDA:15.945APPLICANT NAME:UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE, KNOXVILLEDESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT:ENHANCING CLIMBING RECREATION AND CONSERVATION IN VERTICAL ENVIRONMENTS SHARED BY HUMANS AND BATS THROUGH INPUT FROM CLIMBERS VISITING NATIONAL PARKSPROJECT ABSTRACT:THE GOALS OF THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE RECREATION AND RESOURCE CONSERVATION IN VERTICAL GEOLOGIC ENVIRONMENTS (E.G., CLIFFS, ARCHES, TALUS) USED BY CLIMBERS IN NATIONAL PARKS BY INTEGRATING SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH WITH BIOLOGICAL DATA TO DEVELOP BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR CONSERVING BATS IN THESE HABITATS. INFORMATION GAINED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO ENHANCE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, MAKE INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS MORE RESPONSIVE TO PUBLIC PERCEPTIONS AND INTERESTS, AND SUPPORT PUBLICLY-ACCEPTABLE STEWARDSHIP OF BATS AND VERTICAL ENVIRONMENTS.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT):INVESTIGATE A VARIETY OF ECOLOGICAL COMPONENTS (SOILS, VEGETATION, HYDROLOGY, WETLANDS) TO ASSIST BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK (BRCA) IN DEVELOPMENT OF A MEADOW RESTORATION PLAN TO ENHANCE RESILIENCY OF MEADOW ECOSYSTEMS.SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:- COMPLETE AN INVENTORY AND VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENT OF MEADOW HABITAT OF BRCA TO FACILITATE RESTORATION.-DELINEATE BRCA HIGH ELEVATION MEADOWS USING A COMBINATION OF NEWLY COLLECTED DATA AND DATA FROM PREVIOUS STUDIES.-ASSESS HYDROLOGICAL CAUSES OF MEADOW WETNESS.- IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE RESTORATION ACTIONS.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:-COMPLETION OF A RESTORATION PLAN BASED ON THE TARGETED GOALS FOR RESTORING MEADOW ACREAGE, HABITAT QUALITY, AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES.-SYNTHESIS OF A REPORT THAT PRESENTS BASELINE DATA ON MEADOW CHARACTERISTICS AND EXTENT AND SYNTHESIZES VULNERABILITY AND IMPLICATIONS FOR MEADOW RESTORATION, MONITORING, AND RESEARCH.-CREATION OF A SPATIAL DATABASE OF THE EXTENT OF MEADOW HABITAT WITHIN THE NORTHERN SECTOR OF THE PARK AND AN ASSOCIATED SET OF GEOREFERENCED DIGITAL PHOTOGRAPHS ILLUSTRATING CONDITIONS AT EACH SAMPLING LOCATION.BENEFICIARIES:THE VISITING PUBLIC WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PRESERVATION OF A SPECIALIZED ECOSYSTEM THAT SUPPORTS MANY ASPECTS OF OUR NATURAL HERITAGE, INCLUDING WILDLIFE, VEGETATION, WATER, AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL RESOURCES.

PURPOSE OF AWARD (SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT): AS OF 2021, PIRO'S ON-WATER USE INCLUDES FOUR MAIN USER GROUPS: COMMERCIAL KAYAKERS (UNDER COMMERCIAL USE AUTHORIZATIONS), COMMERCIAL CRUISE PASSENGERS ON LARGE, MOTORIZED VESSELS (VIA AUTHORIZED CONCESSION), RENTAL PONTOON USERS (PONTOONS RENTALS ARE LOCATED OUTSIDE OF PARK WATERS AND ARE NOT CONSIDERED COMMERCIAL USERS AT THIS TIME), AND PRIVATE VESSELS, INCLUDING PRIVATE KAYAKS AND MOTORIZED VESSELS. DUE TO INCREASED ON WATER USE, CONGESTION AND SAFETY CONCERNS HAVE ARISEN.TO ACCOMPLISH THE ABOVE GOAL, THE PROJECT'S OBJECTIVES ARE TO:CONDUCT SYSTEMATIC ON-WATER OBSERVATION FROM LAND AND ON-THE-WATER TO ASSESS THE NUMBER OF BOATS AT KEY AREAS OF CONCERNESTIMATE CURRENT ON-WATER CONDITIONS WHILE UNDERSTANDING HOW VARIOUS LEVELS OF BOAT USE EFFECT USE LEVELS, BEHAVIOR, AND EXPERIENCESPRESENT DATA TO PARK MANAGERS AND THE WIDER SOCIAL SCIENCE COMMUNITY TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND FUTURE STUDIESSUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES:1. SYSTEMATIC ON-WATER OBSERVATION WILL OCCUR TO ASSESS THE NUMBER AND TYPE OF BOATS AT KEY AREAS OF CONCERN, SPECIFICALLY MINERS BEACH THROUGH CHAPEL BEACH.2. AN OBSERVATIONAL SURVEY INSTRUMENT (OBSERVATION TOOL) WILL BE DEVELOPED TO SYSTEMATICALLY ADDRESS THE NUMBER AND TYPE OF BOATS TO DETERMINE SAFETY ISSUES, CROWDING, AND OTHER VISITOR USE ISSUES.3. CONSISTENT BOUNDARIES AND SECTIONS FOR OBSERVATIONS WILL BE DETAILED DURING A SPRING OR EARLY SUMMER 2022 SITE VISIT.4. OBSERVATIONAL FORMS WILL BE DEVELOPED TO ADDRESS KEY QUESTIONS FOR THE SYSTEMATIC OBSERVATIONS INCLUDING 1) NUMBER OF COMMERCIAL AND NON-COMMERCIAL VESSELS, 2) TYPES AND NUMBERS OF PARTICULAR VESSELS (CANOE, PONTOON, CRUISE SHIP, OTHER), 3) USE PATTERNS BY TIME OF DAY, 4) VESSEL-INTERACTIONS (INCLUDING AS POSSIBLE ESTIMATED DISTANCES BETWEEN GROUPS, TIME SPENT CLUSTERED, AND TIME SPENT SPREAD OUT, SAFETY CONCERNS).5. OBSERVATIONS WILL OCCUR THROUGH BOTH ON-THE-WATER AND ON-LAND BY TRAINED STAFF. ON-THE-WATER, UMN STAFF WILL PARTICIPATE IN SELECT COMMERCIAL TRIPS, FITTING INTO THE SCENE AND NOT INFLUENCING VISITOR BEHAVIOR.6. CONCURRENTLY, LAND-STATIONED OBSERVERS WILL ALSO INTEGRATE INTO THE SCENE AND SYSTEMATICALLY COUNT AND IDENTIFY BOATS CAPTURING THE WIDEST BERTH POSSIBLE OF THE AREAS OF INTEREST.7. OBSERVATIONS WILL OCCUR BETWEEN JULY AND AUGUST 2022, ACKNOWLEDGING LATE JULY AND EARLY AUGUST ARE USUALLY THE BUSIEST TIMES. BOTH WEEKDAYS AND WEEKEND OBSERVATIONS WILL OCCUR.8. IN ADDITION, PURCHASED CRUISE SHIP ROUTING DATA WILL BE USED TO ASSESS DISTANCES BETWEEN ON-WATER DATA COLLECTORS AND THE SHIP.9. NPS PERSONNEL OR PARTNERS WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT, REVIEW DOCUMENTS, AND PROVIDE ACCESS TO FACILITIES AS NEEDED.10. ANALYSIS WILL BE DESCRIPTIVE AND COMPARATIVE AS POSSIBLE.11. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE DEVELOPED IN WINTER 2023 AND PRESENTATIONS WILL OCCUR TO NPS STAFF AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES.PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES:1. VISITOR OBSERVATIONAL REPORT: A TECHNICAL REPORT WHICH INCLUDES A 3-5 PAGE EXECUTIVE SUMMARY;2. PRESENTATIONS TO CORE TEAM AND OTHER INTERESTED AUDIENCES.BENEFICIARIES: PUBLIC, LOCAL COMMUNITY, UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE ALASKA REGION OF THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) AND SAINT MARY,S UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA (SMUMN) TO EXTEND PREVIOUSLY DEVELOPED NATIONAL HYDROGRAPHY DATASET (NHD) EDITING PROTOCOLS TO ACCOMMODATE WETLANDS AND OTHER VALUE ADDED ATTRIBUTES (E.G, FISH SPAWNING LOCATIONS) IN THE DATA DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A SET OF DATA DEVELOPMENT PROTOCOLS THAT ARE COMPLIANT WITH BOTH US GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS) NHD AND AKHYDRO SPATIAL DATA FORMATS AND EXTEND THE ABILITY TO CAPTURE ADDITIONAL HYDROGRAPHIC FEATURES AND CHARACTERISTICS OF ARCTIC LANDSCAPES. THE CAPTURE OF THESE ADDITIONAL FEATURES WILL PROVIDE A MORE COMPREHENSIVE HYDROGRAPHIC DATABASE FOR ONGOING MAPPING EFFORTS (E.G., UPDATING USGS US TOPO MAP PRODUCTION) AND WILL PROMOTE ENHANCED MODELING AND ANALYSIS CAPABILITIES INCLUDING MIGRATION TO THE USGS NHDPLUS DATA MODEL.

FOUNDATION NECESSARY TO DEVELOP NEW PROJECTS TO IDENTIFY YET UNKNOWN RESOURCES.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF ALASKA ANCHORAGE DEPARTMENT OF ANTHROPOLOGY (UAA) AND THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) IS FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT AND PRESERVATION TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO UNIVERSITY STUDENTS THROUGH THEIR PARTICIPATION IN PROCESSING THE BACKLOG OF COLLECTIONS HELD AT THE ALASKA REGIONAL CURATORIAL CENTER (ARCC). STUDENT PARTICIPANTS WILL PROVIDE CURATORIAL SUPPORT TO THE NPS ALASKA REGIONAL CURATORIAL CENTER BY ASSISTING WITH THE PROCESSING AND PRESERVATION OF COLLECTIONS FROM NATIONAL PARKS ACROSS THE STATE, INCLUDING BERING LAND BRIDGE NATIONAL PRESERVE, THE WESTERN ARCTIC PARKLANDS, KENAI FJORDS NATIONAL PARK, AND OTHER PARK UNITS. STUDENTS WILL BE TRAINED IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE CURATORIAL WORK THEY WILL BE CONDUCTING, PROVIDING THEM WITH A FOUNDATION OF KNOWLEDGE THAT MAY BE UTILIZED IN OTHER ASPECTS OF THEIR STUDIES OR CAREER TRAJECTORIES.

STRAIT SCHOOL DISTRICT, CHATHAM SCHOOL DISTRICT, LAKE AND PENINSULA SCHOOLS DISTRICT AND
KENAI PENINSULA SCHOOL DISTRICT.

OPPORTUNITIES TO RURAL STUDENTS AND YOUNG PEOPLE.

THE TWO WORKSHOPS ARE SCHEDULED TO TAKE PLACE IN YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, AND WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE DISSEMINATION OF HONORING TRIBAL LEGACIES (HTL). THIS PROJECT WILL GATHER DETAILED, SCIENTIFICALLY RIGOROUS AND SPATIALLY COMPREHENSIVE POPULATION ASSESSMENTS FOR TWO CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SHOREBIRD SPECIES'THE SPOON-BILLED SANDPIPER AND THE RED KNOT. THESE TWO POPULATIONS BREED ONLY IN BERINGIA, AND THEIR CRITICAL CONSERVATION STATUS REFLECTS POTENTIAL ISSUES PRESENT IN THEIR RESPECTIVE FLYWAYS.  OUR ABILITY TO MANAGE THESE SPECIES IS LIMITED BY A LACK OF SUITABLE POPULATION ASSESSMENTS SUCH AS PROPOSED HERE. PROJECT BIOLOGISTS WILL ALSO SEEK OUT AND INCORPORATE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE OF THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE REGARDING PAST AND PRESENT OBSERVATIONS OF THE SPOON-BILLED SANDPIPER (SBS) AND RED KNOT SHOREBIRDS IN THE BERINGIA REGION. THE PROJECT RESULTS AND INFORMATION SHARING EFFORTS WILL ADVANCE LOCAL, NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL UNDERSTANDING AND PRESERVATION OF THESE TWO CHARISMATIC SPECIES OF SHOREBIRDS, AND WILL INVOLVE COLLABORATION AND INFORMATION SHARING ACROSS RUSSIA AND ALASKA.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROCESS BAT CALLS RECORDED FROM SEKI.  AT LEAST NINE ACOUSTIC RECORDING UNITS HAVE BEEN DEPLOYED IN SEKI- YEAR ROUND, SINCE 2015- COLLECTING OVER 400,000 CALLS FOR PROCESSING.  PARK BIOLOGISTS AT SEKI HAVE BEEN UNABLE TO PROCESS THE BACKLOG BECAUSE IT IS A VERY TIME CONSUMING AND TECHNICAL PROCESS.  THIS PROJECT WILL PARTNER WITH BAT SPECIALISTS AT FRESNO STATE UNIVERSITY TO PROCESS CALLS.  THE PROCESSING OF THE BAT CALLS WILL ALLOW PARK BIOLOGISTS TO ADDRESS POPULATION-LEVEL BAT RESEARCH QUESTIONS, AND WILL ALSO PROVIDE A TRAINING OPPORTUNITY FOR LOCAL STUDENTS.  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE TO HAVE ALL AVAILABLE BAT CALLS IDENTIFIED AND PROCESSED TO THE SPECIES LEVEL.  THE CALLS WILL THEN BE PROVIDED TO SEKI BIOLOGISTS IN A FORMAT THAT WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR ANALYSIS, REPORT WRITING, AND PUBLICATION.

THIS PROJECT IS INTENDED TO UTILIZE THE ARCTIC INVENTORY AND MONITORING BASELINE DATA COLLECTED THROUGH THE LAGOON COMMUNITIES MONITORING VITAL SIGN TO MORE FULLY DEVELOP AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE FUNCTIONING OF THE LAGOON SYSTEMS OF BERING LAND BRIDGE NATIONAL PRESERVE AND CAPE KRUSENSTERN NATIONAL MONUMENT. THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE BEAUFORT LAGOON LONG TERM ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH (LTER) SITE, AND OTHER DEVELOPING LAGOON ASSESSMENT RESEARCH EXTERNAL TO NPS MANAGED LANDS, IS GIVING THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AN EXTREMELY VALUABLE OPPORTUNITY TO EXAMINE THE FUNCTIONING OF THE THEIR MANAGED LAGOONS IN THE CONTEXT OF A BROADER ARCTIC LAGOON SCOPE. THIS CONTEXT WILL PROVIDE THE NPS WITH THE AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPLICATIONS OF ONGOING ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES, IN PARTICULAR INCREASING OCEANIC TEMPERATURES, ON THE FLORA AND FAUNA OF THE LAGOONS, AND THE NATURE OF THE LAGOONS IN REGARDS TO ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONING AND SUBSISTENCE OPPORTUNITIES.

POPULAR SPORT AND COMMERCIAL FISHERIES EXISTS FOR RAZOR CLAMS AND MUSSELS IN LAKE CLARK
NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE. THEY ARE ALSO A FOOD SOURCE FOR COASTAL BEARS IN LAKE CLARK NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE AND KATMAI NATIONAL PARK & PRESERVE. THE BEARS ARE ALSO VERY POPULAR WITH WILDLIFE PHOTOGRAPHERS. RECENT POPULATION CRASHES ON NEARBY CLAMMING BEACHES (FOR REASONS POORLY UNDERSTOOD) HAVE LEAD TO FISHERY CLOSURES FOR LOCATIONS OUTSIDE THE PARK, INCREASING PUBLIC USE OF THE FISHERY IN THE PARK. THERE IS ALSO CONCERN THE REMAINING CLAMS MAY BE SUSCEPTIBLE TO THE SAME THREATS THAT LEAD TO THEIR DEMISE ELSEWHERE, WHICH COULD LEAD TO CONFLICTS BETWEEN BEARS, PEOPLE CLAMMING, AND PEOPLE PHOTOGRAPHING THE BEARS. THE LOCATIONS ARE REMOTE AND REGULAR TESTING OR SAMPLING IS EXPENSIVE. THIS PROJECT DEVELOPS AN EASIER AND ULTIMATELY CHEAPER METHOD TO DETECT STRESS AND IMPACTS TO CLAM BEACHES THAT COULD BE USED TO PROACTIVELY MINIMIZE CONFLICTS BETWEEN HUMANS AND BEARS. THIS APPROACH COULD ALSO HELP ENSURE THAT BOTH BEARS AND CLAMMERS RETAIN ACCESS TO A PRIZED FISHERY, AND WILDLIFE PHOTOGRAPHERS RETAIN ACCESS TO WORLD CLASS BEAR VIEWING.

RESULTS WILL BE SHARED PUBLICLY AND WITH ALASKA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME. THIS
PROJECT BUILDS ON PREVIOUS WORK TO UNDERSTAND THE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN BEARS, PEOPLE AND CLAMS IN THESE PARKS.

THIS AGREEMENT IMPLEMENTS A NUMBER OF COLLABORATIONS AIMED AT EXPANDING THE SCOPE OF THE SOUTHEAST ALASKA NETWORK (SEAN) OCEANOGRAPHIC MONITORING PROGRAM TO INCORPORATE MARINE AND COASTAL PORTIONS ALONG THE OUTER COASTS OF GLACIER BAY NATIONAL PARK AND PRESERVE AND WRANGELL-ST. ELIAS NATIONAL PARK, AN AREA OFTENTIMES REFERRED TO AS THE 'LOST COAST'. THE EXPANDED SCOPE OF MONITORING WILL INCORPORATE ADDITIONAL WATER COLUMN HYDROGRAPHIC PROFILES FROM AN EXPANDED SET OF TRANSECT ALONG THE LOST COAST, AND CONTINUOUS MONITORING OF OCEAN CONDITIONS THROUGH OPERATION OF A NEW FIXED-LOCATION MOORING.  THE CURRENT SEAN OCEANOGRAPHIC MONITORING PROTOCOL WILL BE REVISED TO INCORPORATE THE EXPANDED SCOPE, NEW PROCEDURES FOR MOORING INSTRUMENT OPERATION AND DATA HANDLING, AND A STREAMLINED ANNUAL REPORTING SOLUTION.
THE PLAN IS TO USE CITIZEN SCIENTISTS, AS WE HAVE DONE SUCCESSFULLY IN THE PAST WITH SURVEYS OF SNAILS/SLUGS AND BUMBLEBEES, TO SURVEY PRIMARILY FOR BEES WITH A SECONDARY FOCUS ON OTHER POLLINATORS.
